Before you sit, and if you need to relieve yourself, go far away from the camp. And if you depart, perform two Rak'ahs, then bid farewell to the land you stayed in, and greet it and its inhabitants, for every spot has inhabitants from the angels. And if you can avoid eating food until you begin by giving some of it in charity, then do so. And you must recite the Book of Allah, the Exalted and Mighty, as long as you are riding, and you must glorify Allah as long as you are doing work, and you must supplicate as long as you are alone. And beware of traveling from the beginning of the night, and you must rest and travel from the middle of the night until the end of it. And beware of raising your voice on your journey (1).
146 - From him, from Ibn Najran, from someone who mentioned it, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: Traveling the stages...

T Footnote:
---
1 - Vol. 16, "Chapter on Good Manners, Good Companionship, and Other Travel Etiquette," (p. 74, line 17). I say: Since this part "And you must recite the Book of Allah, the Exalted and Mighty" of the Hadith was in the version of Al-Muhaddith Al-Nuri (may his soul rest in peace), like some other versions, with the phrase "And you must recite the Quran," and given that the Glorious Quran had not yet been revealed during the time of Luqman the Wise (peace be upon him) for him to advise his son to recite it, the aforementioned Muhaddith addressed the problem by mentioning several possibilities with this phrase: ""It is possible that the advice from its beginning to here (i.e., to this part "And if you can avoid eating food until you begin by giving some of it in charity, then do so") is from the words of Luqman (peace be upon him), and from this part (i.e., "And you must recite the Quran") to the end of the Hadith is from the words of Al-Sadiq (peace be upon him), making it a complement to the advice of Luqman (peace be upon him) regarding what the traveler should do, and the narrator omitted what distinguished between them, or the context was situational. It is also possible that the term 'Quran' correctly applies to every revealed book that has not been abrogated. It is also likely that the wording of the Hadith was 'the word of Allah' or 'the book of Allah' and the like, and the narrator did not notice the problem and thus conveyed it with the meaning that was apparent to his mind, among other possibilities, for its apparent meaning is certainly not intended."" I say: This very narration is narrated in Al-Wasa'il from Al-Kafi, Al-Faqih, Al-Mahasin, and Aman Al-Akhtar by Ibn Tawus (may his soul rest in peace), and he نقلها from Al-Mahasin, and the wording in all of them, based on what is نقلها in Al-Wasa'il, is as in the text (see Kitab Al-Hajj, "Chapter on a collection of what the traveler should use of etiquette"). And Al-Sayyid Ban Tawus (may his soul rest in peace), after he نقلها the narration from Al-Mahasin as in the text, said at the end of it: "This is the last of its words, we نقلناها as we found it, and Allah knows best." And he said previously when نقلها the narration what reads: "Chapter Thirteen on what we mention of the etiquette in travels from Al-Sadiq, the son of the truthful righteous ones, peace be upon them, he narrated it about Luqman, we mention from it what is needed now, we have narrated from the book of Al-Mahasin with its chain of narration to Hammad bin Uthman or Ibn Isa from Abu Abdullah, peace be upon him," and he mentioned what is in the text (see the end of the sixth chapter of the aforementioned book). Al-Majlisi (may his soul rest in peace), although he included the phrase in the sixteenth volume of Al-Bihar, نقلها from Al-Mahasin as it was in the version of Al-Muhaddith Al-Nuri (may his soul rest in peace), he نقلها in the fifth volume in the chapter on the stories of Luqman (peace be upon him) and his wisdom from Al-Kafi as in the text (see p. 324, line 14). And Al-Muhaddith Al-Nuri (may his soul rest in peace) also narrated the narration in Ma'alim Al-'Ibar in the chapter on the wisdom of Luqman (peace be upon him) from Al-Kafi as in the text (see p. 268, line 5). Thus, it is known that what we نقلناها in the text is correct, so pay attention.

ينفد الزاد، ويسئ الأخلاق، ويخلق الثياب، السير ثمانية عشر (1).
147 - عنه، عن النوفلي، عن السكوني، باسناده، قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: السير قطعة من العذاب، وإذا قضى أحدكم سفره فليسرع الإياب إلى أهله (2).
148 - وباسناده عن أبي عبد الله (ع) عن أبيه، عن جابر بن عبد الله الأنصاري، قال: نهى رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله أن يطرق الرجل أهله ليلا إذا جاء من الغيبة حتى يؤذنهم (3).
38 - باب تهنئة القادم 149 - عنه، قال حدثني أبي مرسلا، عن أبي عبد الله (ع)، عن آبائه (ع) أن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله كان يقول للقادم من مكة، " تقبل الله منك وأخلف عليك نفقتك، وغفر ذنبك " (4).
39 - باب المشي 150 - عنه، عن جعفر بن محمد، عن ابن القداح، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) عن أبيه (ع) أن قوما مشاة أدركهم النبي صلى الله عليه وآله فشكوا إليه شدة المشي، فقال لهم: " استعينوا بالنسل (5).
151 - عنه، عن محمد بن إسماعيل بن بزيع، عن منذر بن جفير، عن يحيى بن طلحة النهدي، قال: قال لنا أبو عبد الله (ع): سيروا وانسلوا فإنه أخف عليكم (6).
152 - عنه، عن ابن فضال، عن القداح، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) عن أبيه (ع) أن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله رأى قوما قد جهدهم المشي، فقال: " أخببوا انسلوا "، ففعلوا فذهب عنهم الاعياء (7).
153 - عنه، عن ابن محبوب، عن هشام بن سالم، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: جاءت المشاة إلى النبي صلى الله عليه وآله فشكوا إليه الاعياء، فقال: " عليكم بالنسلان ". ففعلوا، فذهب عنهم الاعياء، فكأنما نشطوا من عقال. عنه، عن ابن محبوب، عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) مثله إلا أنه قال: " عليكم بالنسلان فإنه يذهب بالاعياء ويقطع الطريق " (8).

Provisions run out, morals worsen, and clothes wear out; traveling eighteen (1).
147 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, with his chain of narration, who said: The Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, said: "Traveling is a piece of torment, and when one of you finishes his journey, let him hasten back to his family" (2).
148 - And with his chain of narration from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), from his father, from Jabir bin Abdullah al-Ansari, who said: The Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, forbade a man from arriving at his family at night when coming from absence until he informs them (3).
38 - Chapter on Congratulating the Returnee 149 - From him, who said: My father narrated to me in mursal form, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), from his forefathers (peace be upon them), that the Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, used to say to the one returning from Mecca, "May God accept from you, compensate you for your expenditure, and forgive your sins" (4).
39 - Chapter on Walking 150 - From him, from Jaafar bin Muhammad, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), from his father (peace be upon him), that a group of pedestrians caught up with the Prophet, may God bless him and his family, and complained to him about the hardship of walking, so he said to them: "Seek help by trotting (nasl)" (5).
151 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ismail bin Bazi', from Munthir bin Jufayr, from Yahya bin Talha al-Nahdi, who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said to us: "Walk and trot, for it is lighter on you" (6).
152 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from al-Qaddah, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), from his father (peace be upon him), that the Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, saw a group of people exhausted from walking, so he said: "Hurry and trot (akhbibu insalu)," so they did, and the fatigue left them (7).
153 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Hisham bin Salim, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: The pedestrians came to the Prophet, may God bless him and his family, and complained to him of fatigue, so he said: "You must trot (al-naslan)." So they did, and the fatigue left them, as if they had been released from a tether. From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Abdullah bin Sinan, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) similarly, except that he said: "You must trot (al-naslan), for it removes fatigue and shortens the journey" (8).

154 - وعنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن عبد الرحمان بن أبي هاشم، عن إبراهيم بن يحيى المدني، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: راح رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله من كراع الغميم فصف له المشاة وقالوا: نتعرض لدعوته فقال صلى الله عليه وآله: " اللهم أعطهم أجرهم، وقوهم. " ثم قال:
" لو استعنتم بالنسلان لخفف أجسامكم وقطعتم الطريق " ففعلوا فخفف أجسامهم (1).
155 - عنه، عن الحجال، عن ابن إسحاق المكي قال: تعرضت المشاة للنبي صلى الله عليه وآله بكراع الغميم ليدعو لهم فدعا لهم وقال خيرا وقال: " عليكم بالنسلان والبكور وشئ من الدلج، فإن الأرض تطوى بالليل (2).
تم كتاب السفر من المحاسن. ثم وجدنا هذه الزيادة من نسخة أخرى باب [كذا فيما عندي من النسخ] 156 - محمد بن أحمد، عن محمد بن الحسن، عن ابن سنان، عن داود الرقي، قال:
خرجت مع أبي عبد الله (ع): إلى ينبع، قال: وخرج على وعليه خف أحمر، قال: قلت: جعلت فداك ما هذا الخف الذي أراه عليك؟ - قال: خف اتخذته للسفر وهو أبقى على الطين والمطر.
قال: قلت: فأتخذها وألبسها؟ - فقال: أما للسفر فنعم، وأما الخف فلا تعدل بالسود شيئا (3).
157 - الحسن بن بندار، عن علي بن الحسن بن فضال، عن بعض أصحابنا، عن منصور بن العباس، عن عمرو بن سعيد، عن عيسى بن أبي حمزة، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: من اعتم ولم يدر العمامة تحت حنكه فأصابه ألم لا دواء له فلا يلومن إلا نفسه. وروى " أن المسومين المعتمون " وروى " الطابقية عمة إبليس " (4).

4 - هذا الحديث لم أجده في مظانه لا في البحار ولا في أجزائه الساقطة المطبوعة أخيرا، المشار إليها في ذيل ص 106 من الكتاب الحاضر، نعم قال في ج 18، في كتاب الصلاة، في باب الرداء وسد له والتوشح فوق القميص، (في ص 91، س 3): " قال في المنتهى: المستفاد من الاخبار كراهة ترك التحنك في حال الصلاة وغيرها بعد أن أورد الروايات في ذلك وهي ما رواه الكليني والشيخ بطرق كثيرة عن الصادق (ع) قال: من تعمم ولم يتحنك فأصابه داء لا دواء له فلا يلومن إلا نفسه " وفى الفقيه " عنه (ع) انى لاعجب ممن يأخذ في حاجته وهو معتم تحت حنكه كيف لا تقضى حاجته. وقال النبي صلى الله عليه وآله: الفرق بين المسلمين والمشركين التلحي بالعمائم وذلك في أول الاسلام وابتدائه ثم قال وقد نقل عنه صلى الله عليه وآله أهل الخلاف أيضا أنه أمر بالتلحي ونهى عن الاقتعاط " (انتهى كلام الفقيه) ونقل العلامة (ره) في المختلف ومن تأخر عنه عن الصدوق القول بالتحريم و كلامه في الفقيه هكذا " وسمعت مشايخنا رضي الله عنهم يقولون: لا تجوز الصلاة في الطابقية ولا يجوز للمعتم أن يصلى إلا وهو متحنك " وقال الشيخ البهائي قدس سره: " لم نظفر في شئ من الأحاديث بما يدل على استحبابها لأجل الصلاة ومن ثم قال في الذكرى: استحباب التحنك عام ولعل حكمهم في كتب الفروع بذلك مأخوذ من كلام علي بن بابويه (ره) فإن الأصحاب كانوا يتمسكون بما يجدونه في كلامه عند إعواز النصوص فالأولى المواظبة على التحنك في - جميع الأوقات ومن لم يكن متحنكا وأراد أن يصلى به فالأولى أن يقصد أنه مستحب في نفسه لا أنه مستحب لأجل الصلاة " (انتهى) أقول: يمكن أن يستدل على ذلك بما رواه الكليني رفعه إلى أبى عبد الله (ع) قال: طلبة العلم ثلاثة وساق الحديث إلى أن قال: وصاحب الفقه والعقل ذو كأبة وزن وسهر قد تحنك في برنسه وقام الليل في حندسه إلى آخر الخبر وفيه أيضا ما ترى ولنرجع إلى معنى التحنك فالظاهر من كلام بعض المتأخرين هو أن يدير جزءا من العمامة تحت حنكه ويعززه في الطرف الآخر كما يفعله أهل البحرين في زماننا ويوهمه كلام بعض اللغويين أيضا والذي نفهمه من الاخبار هو إرسال طرف العمامة من تحت الحنك إسداله كما مر في تحنيك الميت وكما هو المضبوط عند سادات بنى الحسين (ع) أخذوه عن أجدادهم خلفا عن سلف ولم يذكر في تعمم الرسول صلى الله عليه وآله والأئمة (ع) إلا هذا ولنذكر بعض عبارات اللغويين وبعض الأخبار ليتضح لك الامر في ذلك قال الجوهري: التحنك = التلحي وهو أن تدير العمامة من تحت الحنك.
وقال: الاقتعاط = شد العمامة على الرأس من غير إدارة تحت الحنك وفى الحديث أنه نهى عن الاقتعاط وأمر بالتلحي. وقال: التلحي = تطويق العممة تحت الحنك ثم ذكر الخبر. وقال الفيروزآبادي:
اقتعط = تعمم ولم يدر تحت الحنك وقال: العمة الطابقية هي الاقتعاط. وقال: تحنك إذا أدار العمامة تحت حنكه. وقال الجزري: فيه أنه نهى عن الاقتعاط، هو أن يعتم بالعمامة ولا يجعل منها شيئا تحت ذقنه، وقال: فيه أنه نهى عن الاقتعاط وأمر بالتلحي، هو جعل بعض العمامة تحت الحنك، والاقتعاط أن لا يجعل تحت حنكه منها شيئا. وقال الزمخشري في الأساس: اقتعط العمامة إذا لم يجعلها تحت حنكه ثم ذكر الحديث. وقال الخليل في العين يقال: اقتعط بالعمامة إذا اعتم بها ولم يدرها تحت الحنك. وأما الاخبار فقد روى الكليني في الصحيح عن الرضا (ع) في قول الله عز وجل " مسومين " قال: العمائم، اعتم رسول الله فسدلها من بين يديه ومن خلفه، واعم جبرئيل فسدلها من بين يديه ومن خلفه " أقول: كلامه طويل الذيل والصدر فمن أراد الاطلاع على جميعه فليراجع البحار.

154 - And from him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Hashim, from Ibrahim bin Yahya al-Madani, from Abi Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) returned from Kura' al-Ghamim, and the pedestrians lined up for him and said: We expose ourselves to his supplication. So he (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: "O God, give them their reward and strengthen them." Then he said:
"If you had used the *nislaan*, it would have lightened your bodies and you would have crossed the road." So they did, and it lightened their bodies (1).
155 - And from him, from al-Hajjal, from Ibn Ishaq al-Makki who said: The pedestrians exposed themselves to the Prophet (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) at Kura' al-Ghamim so that he would supplicate for them, so he supplicated for them and said good things, and said: "You must use the *nislaan* and early rising and something of night travel, for the earth is folded at night (2)."
The book of travel from al-Mahasin is completed. Then we found this addition from another copy, chapter [as it is in my copies] 156 - Muhammad bin Ahmad, from Muhammad bin al-Hasan, from Ibn Sinan, from Dawood al-Raqqi, who said:
I went out with Abi Abd Allah (peace be upon him) to Yanbu'. He said: And he went out wearing a red slipper. He said: I said: May I be your ransom, what is this slipper that I see you wearing? He said: A slipper I made for travel, and it is more durable against mud and rain.
He said: I said: So I should take them and wear them? He said: As for travel, yes, but as for the slipper, do not consider anything equal to the black (3).
157 - Al-Hasan bin Bundar, from Ali bin al-Hasan bin Faddal, from some of our companions, from Mansur bin al-Abbas, from Amr bin Saeed, from Isa bin Abi Hamza, from Abi Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: Whoever wears a turban and does not let the turban go under his chin, and is afflicted with a pain that has no cure, let him blame only himself. And it is narrated "that the marked ones are those who wear turbans" and it is narrated "the *tabaqiyyah* is the turban of Iblis" (4).

4 - This hadith I did not find in its sources, neither in Bihar al-Anwar nor in its recently printed missing parts, referred to in the footnote on p. 106 of the present book. Yes, he said in vol. 18, in the book of prayer, in the chapter on the cloak and letting it hang down and wearing it over the shirt, (on p. 91, line 3): "He said in al-Muntaha: What is understood from the reports is the dislike of abandoning the *tahannuk* in the state of prayer and otherwise, after mentioning the narrations about that, which is what al-Kulayni and al-Shaykh narrated through many paths from al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) who said: Whoever wears a turban and does not let it go under his chin, and is afflicted with a disease that has no cure, let him blame only himself." And in al-Faqih "From him (peace be upon him): I am amazed at whoever goes about his business while wearing a turban under his chin, how is his need not fulfilled. And the Prophet (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: The difference between Muslims and polytheists is the *talhi* with turbans, and that was in the beginning of Islam and its beginning. Then he said, and it has been narrated from him (peace and blessings of God be upon him) by the people of disagreement also that he commanded the *talhi* and forbade the *iqti'at*." (End of the words of al-Faqih) And al-Allama (may God have mercy on him) and those who came after him narrated in al-Mukhtalif from al-Saduq the statement of prohibition, and his words in al-Faqih are thus: "And I heard our Shaykhs, may God be pleased with them, saying: It is not permissible to pray in the *tabaqiyyah*, and it is not permissible for the turbaned person to pray unless he is *mutahannik*." And Shaykh al-Baha'i, may his secret be sanctified, said: "We have not found in any of the hadiths anything that indicates its desirability for the sake of prayer, and therefore he said in al-Dhikra: The desirability of *al-tahannuk* is general, and perhaps their ruling in the books of branches is taken from the words of Ali bin Babawayh (may God have mercy on him), for the companions used to adhere to what they found in his words when the texts were scarce, so it is better to adhere to *al-tahannuk* in - all times, and whoever is not *mutahannik* and wants to pray with it, then it is better that he intends that it is desirable in itself, not that it is desirable for the sake of prayer." (End) I say: It is possible to infer that from what al-Kulayni narrated, raising it to Abi Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: There are three seekers of knowledge, and he narrated the hadith until he said: And the possessor of jurisprudence and reason is one who is gloomy, weighty, and stays up late, has put his turban under his chin in his *burnus* and spent the night in its darkness, to the end of the report, and in it also is what you see. And let us return to the meaning of *al-tahannuk*, the apparent meaning from the words of some of the later scholars is that one should run a part of the turban under his chin and reinforce it on the other side, as the people of Bahrain do in our time, and the words of some linguists also suggest that, and what we understand from the reports is letting the edge of the turban hang down from under the chin, as it passed in the *tahnik* of the dead, and as it is firmly established among the Sayyids of Bani al-Hussein (peace be upon him), they took it from their ancestors, generation after generation, and nothing was mentioned in the turbanning of the Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) and the Imams (peace be upon them) except this. And let us mention some of the expressions of the linguists and some of the reports so that the matter becomes clear to you in that. Al-Jawhari said: *Al-tahannuk* = *al-talhi* which is to run the turban from under the chin.
And he said: *Al-iqti'at* = tightening the turban on the head without running it under the chin, and in the hadith that he forbade *al-iqti'at* and commanded *al-talhi*. And he said: *Al-talhi* = encircling the turban under the chin, then he mentioned the report. And al-Fayruzabadi said:
*Iqta'ata* = he wore a turban and did not run it under the chin. And he said: The *ammah tabaqiyyah* is *al-iqti'at*. And he said: *Tahanaka* if he ran the turban under his chin. And al-Jazari said: In it, he forbade *al-iqti'at*, which is to wear a turban and not make anything of it under his chin, and he said: In it, he forbade *al-iqti'at* and commanded *al-talhi*, which is to put some of the turban under the chin, and *al-iqti'at* is not to put anything under his chin from it. And al-Zamakhshari said in al-Asas: *Iqta'ata* the turban if he did not put it under his chin, then he mentioned the hadith. And al-Khalil said in al-Ain, it is said: *Iqta'ata* with the turban if he wore it and did not run it under the chin. As for the reports, al-Kulayni narrated in the Sahih from al-Rida (peace be upon him) in the saying of God Almighty and Majestic "marked" he said: Turbans, the Messenger of God wore a turban and let it hang down from in front of him and from behind him, and Gabriel wore a turban and let it hang down from in front of him and from behind him." I say: His words are long-tailed and fronted, so whoever wants to see all of it should refer to Bihar al-Anwar.

سنة من السنين ونحن في طريق مكة فأقمنا ثلاثة أيام نطلب الطريق فلم نجده، فلما أن كان في اليوم الثالث وقد نفد ما كان معنا من الماء عمدنا إلى ما كان معنا من ثياب الاحرام ومن الحنوط، فتحنطنا وتكفنا بازار إحرامنا، فقام رجل من أصحابنا فنادى: " يا صالح، يا أبا الحسن " فأجابه مجيب من بعد، فقلنا له: " من أنت يرحمك الله؟ - " فقال: أنا من النفر الذي قال الله عز وجل في كتابه: " وإذ صرفنا إليك نفرا من الجن يستمعون القرآن، (إلى آخر الآية) " ولم يبق منهم غيري، فأنا مرشد الضال إلى الطريق " قال: فلم نزل نتبع الصوت حتى خرجنا إلى الطريق (1).
159 - عنه، عن العباس بن عامر القصباني، عن عبد الله بن بكير، عن زرارة قال: سمعت أبا جعفر (ع) يقول: إن العفاريت من أولاد الأبالسة تتخلل وتدخل بين محامل المؤمنين فتنفر عليهم إبلهم، فتعاهدوا ذلك بآية الكرسي (2).
160 - عنه، عن إبراهيم بن إسحاق النهاوندي، عن علي بن محمد، عن زكريا بن يحيى رفعه إلى علي بن الحسين (ع): أن هاتفا هتف به، فقال: يا علي بن الحسين أي شئ كانت العلامة بين يعقوب ويوسف؟ - فقال: لما قذف إبراهيم (ع) في النار هبط عليه جبرئيل (ع) بقميص في قصبة فضة فألبسه إياه، ففرت عنه النار ونبت حوله النرجس، فأخذ إبراهيم (ع) القميص، فجعله في عنق إسحاق (ع) في قصبة فضة، وعلقها إسحاق (ع) في عنق يعقوب (ع) وعلقها يعقوب (ع) في عنق يوسف (ع) وقال له: إن نزع هذا القميص من بدنك علمت أنك ميت أو قد قتلت، فلما دخل عليه إخوته أعطاهم القصبة وأخرجوا - القميص، فاحتملت الريح رائحته فألقتها على وجه يعقوب بالأردن فقال: " إني لاجد ريح يوسف لولا أن تفندون " (3).
تم كتاب السفر مع زيادته من المحاسن بمن الله وجوده وصلى الله على محمد وآله الطاهرين وسلم تسليما كثيرا.

One year, we were on the road to Mecca, and we stayed for three days searching for the way, but we could not find it. When the third day came, and we had run out of water, we resorted to what we had with us of the clothes of Ihram and Hanut (perfume for the dead). So we perfumed ourselves and shrouded ourselves in the Izar (lower garment) of our Ihram. A man from our companions stood up and called out: "O Salih, O Abu al-Hasan!" A respondent answered him from afar, so we said to him: "Who are you, may God have mercy on you?" He said: "I am one of the group about whom God Almighty said in His Book: 'And [mention, O Muhammad], when We directed to you a company of the jinn, listening to the Qur'an...' (to the end of the verse). And none of them remain except me, and I am a guide for the lost to the way." He said: "We continued to follow the voice until we came out to the road" (1).

159 - From him, from al-Abbas bin Amer al-Qasbani, from Abdullah bin Bukair, from Zurara who said: I heard Abu Jaafar (a.s.) saying: "Indeed, the 'Afarit (strong and rebellious jinn) from the offspring of the devils infiltrate and enter between the litters of the believers, so they frighten their camels. So protect yourselves from that with Ayat al-Kursi (the Verse of the Throne)" (2).

160 - From him, from Ibrahim bin Ishaq al-Nahawandi, from Ali bin Muhammad, from Zakariya bin Yahya, who traced it back to Ali bin al-Hussein (a.s.): That a voice called out to him, saying: "O Ali bin al-Hussein, what was the sign between Jacob and Joseph?" He said: "When Abraham (a.s.) was thrown into the fire, Gabriel (a.s.) descended upon him with a shirt in a silver tube and dressed him in it, so the fire fled from him and narcissus grew around him. So Abraham (a.s.) took the shirt and placed it around the neck of Isaac (a.s.) in a silver tube, and Isaac (a.s.) hung it around the neck of Jacob (a.s.), and Jacob (a.s.) hung it around the neck of Joseph (a.s.) and said to him: 'If this shirt is removed from your body, know that you are dead or have been killed.' So when his brothers entered upon him, he gave them the tube and they took out the shirt, and the wind carried its scent and cast it upon the face of Jacob in the Jordan, and he said: 'Indeed, I find the smell of Joseph - were you not to accuse me of being senile'" (3).

The book of al-Safar (Travel) is completed with its augmentations from al-Mahasin, by the grace and generosity of God. May God bless Muhammad and his pure family, and grant them abundant peace.

أتحب إخوانك يا حسين؟ - قلت: نعم، قال، تنفع فقراءهم؟ - قلت،: نعم، قال: أما إنه يحق عليك أن تحب من يحب الله أما والله لا تنفع منهم أحدا حتى تحبه، أتدعوهم إلى منزلك؟ - قلت: ما آكل إلا ومعي منهم الرجلان أو الثلاثة أو أقل أو أكثر، فقال أبو عبد الله (ع):
فضلهم عليك أعظم من فضلك عليهم، فقلت: أدعوهم إلى منزلي، وأطعمهم طعامي وأسقيهم، وأوطئهم رحلي، ويكونون على أفضل منا؟! قال: نعم إنهم إذا دخلوا منزلك دخلوا بمغفرتك ومغفرة عيالك، وإذا خرجوا من منزلك خرجوا بذنوبك وذنوب عيالك (1) 29 - عنه، عن النوفلي، عن السكوني، عن أبي عبد الله (ع)، عن آبائه (ع) قال:
قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: أضف بطعامك من تحب في الله (2).
30 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن الحسن بن علي بن يوسف، عن سيف بن عميرة، عن سعيد بن الوليد قال: دخلنا مع أبان بن تغلب على أبى عبد الله (ع) فقال أبو عبد الله (ع) لأن أطعم مسلما حتى يشبع أحب إلى من أن أطعم أفقا من الناس، قيل: وما الأفق من الناس؟ - قال: مائة ألف إنسان من غيركم (3).
31 - عنه، عن محمد بن الحسن بن شمون، عن عبد الله بن عمرو بن الأشعث، عن عبد الله بن حماد الأنصاري، عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن عمرو بن أبي المقدام، عن أبيه قال:
قال لي أبو جعفر (ع): يابا المقدام والله لأن أطعم رجلا من شيعتي أحب إلى من أن أطعم أفقا من الناس، قلت: كم الأفق؟ - قال: مائة ألف (4).
32 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن محمد بن مقرن، عن عبيد الله الوصافي، عن أبي جعفر (ع) قال: لأن أطعم رجلا مسلما أحب إلى من أن أعتق أفقا من الناس، قلت:
وكم الأفق؟ - قال: عشرة آلاف (5).
33 - عنه، عن علي بن الحكم، عن سيف بن عميرة، عن حسان بن مهران، عن صالح بن ميثم، عن أبي جعفر (ع) قال: إطعام مسلم يعدل عتق نسمة (6).

"Do you love your brothers, Hussain?" I said: "Yes." He said: "Do you benefit their poor?" I said: "Yes." He said: "Indeed, it is your duty to love those who love God. But, by God, you will not benefit any of them until you love him. Do you invite them to your house?" I said: "I do not eat unless I have with me two or three men from them, or less, or more." Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said:

"Their favor upon you is greater than your favor upon them." I said: "I invite them to my house, feed them my food, give them to drink, and make them comfortable, and they are better than us?!" He said: "Yes, when they enter your house, they enter with forgiveness for you and forgiveness for your family. And when they leave your house, they leave with your sins and the sins of your family." (1) 29 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.), from his forefathers (a.s.) who said:

The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: "Share your food with those you love for the sake of God." (2)
30 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from al-Hasan bin Ali bin Yusuf, from Saif bin Umayrah, from Saeed bin al-Walid, who said: We entered with Aban bin Taghlib upon Abi Abdullah (a.s.), and Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said: "To feed a Muslim until he is full is more beloved to me than to feed a multitude of people." It was said: "And what is a multitude of people?" He said: "One hundred thousand people other than you." (3)
31 - From him, from Muhammad bin al-Hasan bin Shamun, from Abdullah bin Amr bin al-Ash'ath, from Abdullah bin Hammad al-Ansari, from Abdullah bin Sinan, from Amr bin Abi al-Miqdam, from his father, who said:

Abu Jaafar (a.s.) said to me: "O Abu al-Miqdam, by God, to feed a man from my Shia is more beloved to me than to feed a multitude of people." I said: "How many is a multitude?" He said: "One hundred thousand." (4)
32 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair, from Muhammad bin Muqrin, from Ubaid Allah al-Wasafi, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) who said: "To feed a Muslim man is more beloved to me than to free a multitude of people." I said: "And how many is a multitude?" He said: "Ten thousand." (5)
33 - From him, from Ali bin al-Hakam, from Saif bin Umayrah, from Hassan bin Mehran, from Salih bin Maytham, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) who said: "Feeding a Muslim is equivalent to freeing a soul." (6)

37 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي بن يعقوب الهاشمي، عن هارون بن مسلم القرشي، عن أيوب بن الحر، عن الوصافي عن أبي جعفر (ع): قال: لأكلة أطعمها أخا لي في الله أحب إلى من أن أشبع مسكينا، ولان أشبع أخا لي في الله أحب إلى من أن أشبع عشرة مساكين، ولان أعطيه عشرة دراهم أحب إلى من أن أعطى مائة درهم في المساكين (4).
38 - عنه، عن أبي عبد الله أبيه، عن النضر بن سويد، عن يحيى الحلبي، عن أيوب بن الحر، عن الوصافي، عن أبي جعفر (ع) قال: لا أطعم أخا في الله أكلة أو لقمة أحب إلى من أن أشبع مسكينا، ولا أشبع أخا لي مواخيا في الله أحب إلى من أن أشبع عشرة مساكين (5).
39 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن معمر بن خلاد، قال: كان أبو الحسن الرضا (ع) إذا أكل أتى بصحفة، فتوضع قرب مائدته، فيعمد إلى أطيب الطعام مما يؤتى به، فيأخذ من كل شئ شيئا، فيوضع في تلك الصحفة، ثم يأمر بها للمساكين، ثم يتلو هذه الآية: " فلا اقتحم العقبة "، ثم يقول: علم الله عز وجل أن ليس كل إنسان يقدر على عتق رقبة، فجعل لهم سبيلا إلى الجنة باطعام الطعام (6).

يا سدير تعتق كل يوم نسمة؟ - قلت: لا، قال: كل شهر؟ - قلت: لا، قال: كل سنة؟ - قلت:
لا، قال: سبحان الله! أما تأخذ بيد واحد من شيعتنا، فتدخله إلى بيتك، فتطعمه شبعة، فوالله لذلك أفضل من عتق رقبة من ولد إسماعيل (1).
49 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن هشام بن الحكم، عن سدير الصيرفي، قال:
قال لي أبو عبد الله (ع): ما يمنعك أن تعتق كل يوم نسمة؟ - فقلت: لا يحتمل ذلك مالي، فقال: لا تقدر أن تشبع كل يوم رجلا مسلما؟ - فقلت: موسرا أو معسرا؟ - فقال: إن الموسر قد يشتهى الطعام (2).
50 - عنه، عن أبيه، صفوان، عن فضيل بن عثمان، عن نعيم الأحول، قال: دخلت على أبى عبد الله (ع) فقال لي: اجلس فأصب معي من هذا الطعام حتى أحدثك بحديث سمعته من أبى، كان أبى يقول: لأن أطعم عشرة من المسلمين أحب إلى من أن أعتق عشر رقبات (3).
51 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن صفوان، عن أبي المغرا، عن بكار الواسطي، عن ثابت - الثمالي، قال: قال لي أبو جعفر (ع): يا ثابت أما تستطيع أن تعتق كل يوم رقبة؟ - قلت:
لا والله جعلت فداك ما أقوى على ذلك، قال: فقال: أما تستطيع أن تعشى أو تغدى أربعة من المسلمين؟ - قلت: أما هذا فأنا أقوى عليه، قال: هو والله يعدل عند الله عتق رقبة (4).
52 - عنه، عن إسماعيل بن مهران، عن صفوان الجمال، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: قال لأن أشبع رجلا من إخواني أحب إلى من أن أدخل سوقكم هذه، فابتاع منها رأسا، فأعتقه (5).
53 - عنه، عن أحمد بن محمد بن أبي نصر، عن صفوان الجمال، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: أكلة يأكلها أخي المسلم عندي، أحب إلى من عتق رقبة (6).
54 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن حماد بن عيسى، عن إبراهيم بن عمر اليماني، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: ما من مؤمن يدخل بيته مؤمنين، فيطعمها شبعهما، إلا كان ذلك أفضل من عتق نسمة (7) 55 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن حسين بن علي بن يوسف، عن زكريا بن محمد، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: من أطعم مؤمنين شبعهما كان ذلك أفضل من عتق رقبة (8)

O Sudair, do you emancipate a soul every day?" I said, "No." He said, "Every month?" I said, "No." He said, "Every year?" I said, "No." He said, "Glory be to God! Cannot you take one of our Shia by the hand, bring him into your house, and feed him to his fill? By God, that is better than emancipating a slave from the children of Ishmael (1)."
49 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair, from Hisham bin Al-Hakam, from Sudair Al-Sairafi, who said:
Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said to me: "What prevents you from emancipating a soul every day?" I said, "My wealth cannot bear that." He said, "Are you not able to satisfy a Muslim man every day?" I said, "Whether he is well-off or poor?" He said, "Indeed, the well-off may desire food (2)."
50 - From him, from his father, from Safwan, from Fudail bin Uthman, from Nu'aim Al-Ahwal, who said: I entered upon Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) and he said to me: "Sit down and partake with me of this food until I tell you a hadith that I heard from my father. My father used to say: 'To feed ten Muslims is more beloved to me than to emancipate ten slaves (3).'"
51 - From him, from his father, from Safwan, from Abi Al-Mughra, from Bakkar Al-Wasiti, from Thabit Al-Thumali, who said: Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him) said to me: "O Thabit, are you not able to emancipate a slave every day?" I said:
"No, by God, may I be your ransom, I cannot afford that." He said: "Are you not able to give dinner or lunch to four Muslims?" I said: "This I can afford." He said: "By God, that is equivalent to emancipating a slave in the sight of God (4)."
52 - From him, from Ismail bin Mehran, from Safwan Al-Jamal, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: "Verily, to satisfy one of my brothers is more beloved to me than to enter this market of yours, buy a head, and emancipate it (5)."
53 - From him, from Ahmed bin Muhammad bin Abi Nasr, from Safwan Al-Jamal, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: "A meal that my Muslim brother eats with me is more beloved to me than emancipating a slave (6)."
54 - From him, from his father, from Hammad bin Issa, from Ibrahim bin Omar Al-Yamani, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: "There is no believer who brings two believers into his house and feeds them to their fill, but that is better than emancipating a soul (7)."
55 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Hussein bin Ali bin Yusuf, from Zakaria bin Muhammad, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: "Whoever feeds two believers to their fill, that is better than emancipating a slave (8)."

56 - From him, from Ali bin al-Hakam, from Saif bin 'Umayrah, from Hassan bin Salih bin Maytham who said: A man asked Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him): What deed is equivalent to freeing a soul? - Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) said: To feed three Muslims is more beloved to me than freeing one soul, and another soul (until he reached seven), and feeding one Muslim is equivalent to freeing a soul (1).
57 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from al-Hasan bin Ali bin Yusuf, from Saif bin 'Umayrah, from Abu Ali Hassan bin Mehran al-Nakha'i, from Salih bin Maytham, who said: A man asked Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) and said: Inform me of a deed that is equivalent to freeing a slave? - Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) said: To invite three Muslims and feed them until they are full, and give them water until they are quenched, is more beloved to me than freeing one soul and another soul (until he counted seven or more) (2).
58 - From him, from Ismail bin Mehran, from Saif bin 'Umayrah, from Dawood bin al-Nu'man, who said: Hussein bin Ali narrated to me that he heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) saying: Whoever feeds three Muslims, Allah will forgive him (3).
59 - From him, from his father, from Safwan bin Yahya, from Aban bin Uthman, from Fudail bin Yasar, who said: Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) said: Satisfying the hunger of four Muslims is equivalent to freeing a slave from the descendants of Ismail (4).
60 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ahmed, from Aban, from Fudail bin Yasar, from Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) who said: Satisfying the hunger of four Muslims is equivalent to freeing a liberated person from the descendants of Ismail (5).
61 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Harun bin Muslim, from Ayyub bin al-Hur, from al-Sumayda', from Malik bin A'yan al-Juhani, from Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) who said: To have a believing man break his fast in my house is more beloved to me than freeing so and so many souls from the descendants of Ismail (6).
62 - From him, from Ismail bin Mehran, from Saif bin 'Umayrah, from Dawood bin al-Nu'man, from Hussein bin Ali who said: I heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) saying: Whoever feeds ten Muslims

64 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Hisham ibn Salim, from Abi Basir, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) who said: "Any believer who feeds a believer one night in the month of Ramadan, Allah will record for him the reward of freeing a believing soul. And whoever feeds throughout the month of Ramadan, Allah will record for him the reward of freeing thirty believing souls, and he will have with Allah a answered prayer (3)."
65 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Abi Ayyub, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Whoever feeds a believer in the month of Ramadan, it is for him the freeing of a slave and forgiveness for his past sins. If he can only afford a sip of milk and offers it to a fasting person to break their fast, or a drink of fresh water and a date and cannot afford more than that, Allah will grant him this reward (4)."
66 - From him, from his father, from Sa'dan, from Musa ibn Bakr, from Abi al-Hasan Musa (a.s.) who said: "Your breaking the fast of your fasting brother is better than your fasting (5)."
67 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Ali ibn Asbat, from Sayaba ibn Durais, from Hamza ibn Humran, from Abi Abdillah (a.s.): He said: Ali ibn al-Hussein (a.s.) would, when it was the day he was fasting, order a sheep to be slaughtered, its limbs cut up and cooked. 69 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن القاسم بن عروة، عن عبد الله بن بكير، عن زرارة، قال:
سألت أبا جعفر (ع) عن قول الله عز وجل " يوم تبدل الأرض غير الأرض " قال: تبدل خبزة نقى يأكل الناس منها حتى يفرغ الناس من الحساب، فقال له قائل: " إنهم لفى شغل يومئذ عن الأكل والشرب " قال: إن الله خلق ابن آدم أجوف، فلابد له من الطعام والشراب، أهم أشد شغلا يومئذ أم من في النار؟ - فقد استغاثوا، والله يقول: " وإن يستغيثوا يفاثوا بماء كالمهل يشوى الوجوه بئس الشراب " (2).
70 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن هشام، عن زرارة، عن أبي جعفر (ع) قال:
سأل الأبرش الكلبي عن قول الله عز وجل: " يوم تبدل الأرض غير الأرض " قال: تبدل خبزة نقى يأكل الانسان منها حتى يفرغ من الحساب، فقال الأبرش: إن الناس يومئذ لفى شغل عن الاكل، فقال أبو جعفر (ع): هم وهم في النار لا يشغلون عن أكل الضريع وشرب الحميم وهم في العذاب، فكيف يشغلون عنه في الحساب (3) 71 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن معمر بن خلاد، عن أبي الحسن الرضا (ع)، في قول الله:
" ويطعمون الطعام على حبه مسكينا " قال: قلت حب الله أو حب الطعام؟ - قال حب الطعام (4) 72 - عنه، عن إبراهيم بن هاشم، عمن ذكره، عن حسين بن نعيم، عن أبي عبد الله

He said: God created the son of Adam hollow (1).
69 - From him, from his father, from al-Qasim ibn Urwa, from Abdullah ibn Bukair, from Zurara, who said:
I asked Abu Jaafar (a.s.) about the saying of God, the Almighty and Sublime, "On the Day when the earth will be changed to another earth," he said: "It will be changed into a loaf of pure bread from which people will eat until people are finished with the reckoning." Then someone said to him: "On that Day, they will be too preoccupied to eat and drink." He said: "God created the son of Adam hollow, so he must have food and drink. Are they more preoccupied on that Day than those in Hell? - for they will cry for relief, and God says: "And if they call for relief, they will be relieved with water like murky oil, which scalds [their] faces. Wretched is the drink," (2).
70 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair, from Hisham, from Zurara, from Abu Jaafar (a.s.) who said:
Al-Abrash al-Kalbi asked about the saying of God, the Almighty and Sublime: "On the Day when the earth will be changed to another earth," he said: "It will be changed into a loaf of pure bread from which man will eat until he is finished with the reckoning." Al-Abrash said: "On that Day, people will be too preoccupied to eat." Abu Jaafar (a.s.) said: "They, even in Hell, are not too preoccupied to eat the bitter, thorny food and drink boiling water while they are in torment. So how can they be too preoccupied with it during the reckoning?" (3) 71 - From him, from his father, from Muammar ibn Khallad, from Abu al-Hasan al-Ridha (a.s.), regarding the saying of God:
"And they give food in spite of love for it to the needy," he said: "I said, 'Love of God or love of food?' - He said, 'Love of food.'" (4) 72 - From him, from Ibrahim ibn Hashim, from someone he mentioned, from Hussein ibn Naim, from Abu Abdullah

يا با خالد كيف رأيت طعامنا؟ - قلت: جعلت فداك ما رأيت أنظف منه قط ولا أطيب، ولكني ذكرت الآية التي في كتاب الله " لتسئلن يومئذ عن النعيم " فقال أبو جعفر (ع): لا إنما تسئلون عما أنتم عليه من الحق (1).
83 - عنه، عن عثمان بن عيسى، عن أبي سعيد، عن أبي حمزة، قال: كنا عند أبي عبد الله (ع) جماعة، فدعا بطعام مالنا عهد بمثله لذاذة وطيبا، حتى تملينا وأتينا بتمر، ينظر فيه إلى وجوهنا من صفائه وحسنه، فقال رجل: " لتسئلن يومئذ عن النعيم " عن هذا النعيم الذي نعمتم عند ابن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله فقال أبو عبد الله (ع): الله أكرم و أجل من أن يطعمكم طعاما فيسوغكموه، ثم يسألكم عنه، ولكنه أنعم عليكم بمحمد وآل محمد صلى الله عليه وآله. ورواه عن محمد بن علي، عن عيسى بن هشام، عن أبي خالد القماط، عن أبي حمزة مثله (2).

"O Abu Khalid, how did you find our food?" I said, "May I be your ransom, I have never seen anything cleaner or more delicious than it, but I remembered the verse in the Book of Allah, 'Then, on that Day, you shall be asked about the delight.'" Abu Ja'far (a.s.) said, "No, you will only be asked about the truth you adhere to." (1)
83 - From him, from Uthman bin Isa, from Abi Saeed, from Abi Hamza, who said: We were with Abu Abdullah (a.s.) as a group, and he called for food the likes of which we had never tasted for deliciousness and goodness, until we were full. Then we were brought dates so clear and beautiful that our faces could be seen reflected in them. A man said, "Then, on that Day, you shall be asked about the delight" about this delight that we enjoyed with the son of the Messenger of Allah, peace be upon him and his family. Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said, "Allah is more generous and sublime than to feed you food and make it easy for you to swallow, then ask you about it. Rather, He has bestowed upon you Muhammad and the family of Muhammad, peace be upon them." This was also narrated from Muhammad bin Ali, from Isa bin Hisham, from Abu Khalid al-Qammat, from Abu Hamza, similar to it (2).
84 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Ibn Bukair, from some of his companions, who said: Abu Abdullah (a.s.) would sometimes feed us al-Farani and al-Akhbisa, then he would feed us bread and olive oil. It was said to him, "Why don't you manage your affairs so that they are balanced?" He said, "Our management is from Allah. When Allah provides abundantly for us, we provide abundantly, and when He restricts, we restrict." (3)
85 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Yunus bin Yaqub, from Abd al-Ala, who said: I ate with Abu Abdullah (a.s.), and he called and brought a stuffed chicken and Khubais. Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said, "This was gifted to Fatima." Then he said, "O girl, bring us our known food." She came with Tharid of vinegar and olive oil. (4)
86 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Ibn Sinan, from Abi al-Jarud, who said: We asked Abu Ja'far (a.s.) about meat and ghee being mixed together. He said: "Eat and feed me." (5)

88 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers, from Ali (peace be upon him), who said: "Colors make the stomach grow and numb the loins." (2)

96 - عنه، عن أبي القاسم، عن القندي، عن ابن سنان وأبى البختري، عن أبي - عبد الله (ع) قال: الثريد طعام العرب، ورواه النهيكي ويعقوب بن يزيد، عن القندي، ورواه أحمد، عن النوفلي، عن السكوني، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) مثله، وزاد فيه ابن فضال، عن محمد بن أبي حمزة، عن عمر بن يزيد قال: العقارجات تعظم البطن، وترخي الأليتين (4) 97 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن هشام بن سلام، عن سلمة بن محرز، قال:

125 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Isa al-Yaqtini, from Abu Muhammad al-Ansari, from Abu al-Husayn al-Ahmasi, from Abu Abd Allah, from his forefathers (peace be upon them), who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: "The believer is sweet, he loves sweetness, and the believer is sweet, he loves sweetness." (1)
126 - From him, from Sahl ibn Ziyad, from Ahmad ibn Harun ibn Muwaffaq al-Madaini, from his father, who said: "[Someone] was sent to al-Madi (peace be upon him) one day, and we ate with him, and they provided a lot of sweets, so I said: 'How much sweets this is!' So he said: 'We and our Shia were created from sweetness, so we love sweets.'" (2)
127 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Yunus ibn Ya'qub, from Abd al-A'la, who said: "I ate with Abu Abd Allah (peace be upon him), and a chicken stuffed with *khabis* was brought, so we disassembled it and ate it." (3)
128 - From him, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Ali ibn Abi Hamza, from Abu Basir, from Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him), who said: "Whoever does not want sweets, wants intoxicants." (4)
129 - From him, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Ali ibn Hamza, from Abu al-Hasan (peace be upon him), who said: "We are a household that loves sweets, and whoever among us does not love sweets, wants intoxicants." And he said: "I have *mawad*, and I love sweets." (5)
130 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Yunus ibn Ya'qub, from Abu Abd Allah (peace be upon him), who said: "We were in Medina, and he sent to us, 'Make us *faludhaj* and make little,' so we sent it to him in a small bowl." (6)
131 - From him, from his father, from Sa'dan, from Yusuf ibn Ya'qub, who said: "Abu Abd Allah (peace be upon him) liked *faludhaj*, and when he wanted it, he would say: 'Make us [some] and make little.'" (7)

And in some versions, 'My father had *mawad*,' meaning my father was *mawad*, loving it, and it is as if it is a misreading, but it is not unlikely that both of them are misreadings."

text:
عن أبي عبد الله (ع) في قوله عز وجل: " ليس عليكم جناح، الآية " قال: باذن وبغير إذن (1).
172 - عنه، عن ابن سنان وصفوان بن يحيى، عن عبد الله بن سنان أو ابن مسكان، عن محمد الحلبي قال سألت أبا عبد الله (ع) عن هذه الآية " ليس عليكم جناح أن تأكلوا من بيوتكم أو بيوت آبائكم، إلى آخر الآية " قلت: ما يعنى بقوله " أو صديقكم "؟ - قال: هو والله الرجل يدخل بيت صديقه فيأكل بغير إذنه (2).
173 - عنه، عن أحمد بن محمد بن أبي نصر، عن حماد بن عثمان، عن زرارة، عن أبي - جعفر (ع) قال: سألته عما يحل للرجل من بيت أخيه من الطعام؟ - قال: المأدوم والتمر، وكذلك يحل للمرأة من بيت زوجها (3).
174 - عنه، عن أحمد ب محمد بن جميل، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: للمرأة أن تأكل وتتصدق، وللصديق أن يأكل من منزل أخيه ويتصدق (4).
185 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن صفوان بن يحيى، عن موسى بن بكر، عن زرارة، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) في قول الله تبارك وتعالى: " أو صديقكم أو ما ملكتم مفاتحه " فقال: هؤلاء الذين سمى الله في هذه الآية يأكل بغير إذنهم من التمر والمأدوم، وكذلك تطعم المرأة بغير إذن زوجها، فأما ما خلا ذلك من الطعام فلا (5).
176 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن القاسم بن عروة، عن عبد الله بن بكير، عن زرارة، قال:
سألت أحدهما عن هذه الآية " ليس عليكم جناح أن تأكلوا من بيوتكم، الآية " قال:
ليس عليك جناح فيما طعمت أو أكلت مما ملكت مفاتحه ما لم تفسد (6).
177 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عمن ذكره، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) في قوله تعالى:

From Abi Abdullah (a.s.) regarding the saying of Allah Almighty and Majestic: "There is no blame upon you..." He said: "With permission and without permission." (1)

172 - From him, from Ibn Sinan and Safwan bin Yahya, from Abdullah bin Sinan or Ibn Muskan, from Muhammad al-Halabi, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (a.s.) about this verse: "There is no blame upon you that you eat from your houses or the houses of your fathers, until the end of the verse." I said: What does He mean by His saying: "Or your friend?" He said: "By Allah, it is a man who enters the house of his friend and eats without his permission." (2)

173 - From him, from Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Abi Nasr, from Hammad bin Uthman, from Zurarah, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.), who said: I asked him about what is lawful for a man to take from his brother's house in terms of food? He said: "Al-Ma'dum (food seasoned with oil) and dates, and likewise it is lawful for a woman from her husband's house." (3)

174 - From him, from Ahmad bin Muhammad bin Jamil, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.), who said: "A woman is allowed to eat and give in charity, and a friend is allowed to eat from his brother's house and give in charity." (4)

175 - From him, from his father, from Safwan bin Yahya, from Musa bin Bakr, from Zurarah, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) regarding the saying of Allah, Blessed and Exalted be He: "Or your friend or what you possess their keys..." He said: "These whom Allah has named in this verse, he may eat without their permission from dates and al-Ma'dum, and likewise a woman feeds others without her husband's permission, but as for other than that of food, then no." (5)

176 - From him, from his father, from al-Qasim bin Urwah, from Abdullah bin Bukayr, from Zurarah, who said:
I asked one of them about this verse: "There is no blame upon you that you eat from your houses..." He said: "There is no blame upon you for what you taste or eat from what you possess its keys, as long as you do not spoil (it)." (6)

177 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from someone who mentioned it, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) regarding the saying of Allah the Exalted: "Or what you possess their keys..." He said: "A man may have an agent who manages his wealth, and he eats without his permission." (7)

ودعوا وأثنوا وقالوا: " لولا أنا عجال لانتظرنا رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله فاقرئوه السلام "، ومضوا، فانفتل النبي صلى الله عليه وآله مغضبا ثم قال لهم: يقف عليكم الركب يسئلونكم عنى ويبلغونني السلام ولا تعرضون عليهم الغداء، يعز على قوم فيهم خليلي جعفر أن يجوزوه حتى يتغدوا عنده (1).
179 - عنه، عن أحمد بن عيسى، عن عدة رفعوا إلى أبى عبد الله (ع) قال، إذا دخل عليك أخوك فاعرض عليه الطعام، فإن لم يأكل فاعرض عليه الماء، فإن لم يشرب فاعرض عليه الوضوء (2).
180 - عنه، عن ابن محبوب، عن علي بن الخطاب الخلال، عن رجل، عن أبي - عبد الله (ع) قال: أتاه مولى له، فسلم عليه ومعه ابنه إسماعيل فسلم عليه وجلس، فلما أنصرف أبو عبد الله (ع) انصرف معه الرجل، فلما انتهى أبو عبد الله (ع) إلى باب داره دخل وترك الرجل، فقال له ابنه إسماعيل: يا أبه، ألا كنت عرضت عليه الدخول؟ - فقال: لم يكن من شأني إدخاله، قال: فهو لم يكن يدخل، قال: يا بنى إني أكره أن يكتبني الله عراضا (3).
23 - باب الدعاء إلى الطعام 181 - عنه، عن النوفلي، عن السكوني، باسناده، قال، قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: الوليمة في أربع، العرس، والخرس، و (هو المولود يعق عنه ويطعم له)، وإعذار (وهو ختان الغلام)، والاياب (وهو الرجل يدعو إخوانه إذا آب من غيبة) (4).

They bid farewell, praised, and said, "If we weren't in a hurry, we would have waited for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) and conveyed our greetings to him." And they left. The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) turned away angrily and then said to them, "A caravan will stop by you asking about me and conveying greetings to me, and you will not offer them lunch. It is hard for a people among whom is my close friend Ja'far to pass by him without having lunch with him (1)."
179 - From him, from Ahmad ibn Isa, from several who attributed to Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "If your brother enters upon you, offer him food. If he does not eat, offer him water. If he does not drink, offer him ablution (2)."
180 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Ali ibn al-Khattab al-Khallal, from a man, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "A freed slave of his came to him, greeted him, and his son Ismail was with him, so he greeted him and sat down. When Abu Abdullah (a.s.) departed, the man departed with him. When Abu Abdullah (a.s.) reached the door of his house, he entered and left the man. His son Ismail said to him, 'O father, why didn't you offer him to enter?' He said, 'It was not my custom to let him enter.' He said, 'So he wouldn't enter?' He said, 'O my son, I dislike that Allah records me as one who is unwilling (3).'"

182 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, raising it to Abu Ja'far (a.s.) who said: "The Walima for a day or two is an honor, and for three days is showing off and seeking reputation (5)."

He said: 'That is because the aroma of Paradise wafts through wedding food, for it is food prepared for what is lawful (4).'"

189 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Sinan, from Ziyad ibn Abi al-Halal, who said: I had dinner with Abu Abdullah (a.s.) and he said: "Dinner after the last evening prayer is the dinner of the prophets (1)."
199 - From him, from his father, from al-Qasim ibn Urwa, from Muhammad ibn Marwan, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "Abandoning dinner is the ruin of the body (2)."
200 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Ali, from Ali ibn Asbat, from Yaqub ibn Salim, from al-Mithami, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "Yaqub's (a.s.) crier used to announce every morning from his house, which was a league away: 'Whoever wants lunch, let him come to the family of Yaqub.' And when evening came, he would announce: 'Whoever wants dinner, let him come to the family of Yaqub.'" From him, who said: Abu al-Qasim, Yaqub ibn Yazid and al-Nuhayki narrated to me, from Ziyad al-Qandi, from Abd al-Rahman ibn Suleiman al-Hashimi (3).
201 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from someone who mentioned it, from Abu Jaafar (a.s.) who said: "The first ruin of the body is abandoning dinner." He said: "My father narrated it from Ibn Abi Umair, from Hisham ibn al-Hakam, like it (4)."
202 - From Jaafar, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Muhammad ibn Abi Hamid, from Muhammad ibn al-Munkadir, from Jabir ibn Abdullah, who said: The Messenger of Allah, may God bless him and his family, said: "Do not abandon dinner, even if it is just a rotten date. I fear for my Ummah from abandoning dinner, senility, for dinner is the strength of the old man and the young man (5)."

آبائه (ع) قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: يا علي، إن الوضوء قبل الطعام وبعده شفاء في الجسد، ويمن في الرزق (1).
223 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن محمد بن سنان، عن الحسن بن محمد الحضرمي، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: الوضوء قبل الطعام وبعده يذيبان الفقر (2).
224 - عنه، عن أحمد بن محمد بن أبي نصر والقاسم بن محمد، عن صفوان الجمال، عن أبي حمزة، عن أبي جعفر (ع) قال: قال لي: يا با حمزة الوضوء قبل الطعام وبعده يذيبان الفقر، قلت: يا بن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله بأبي أنت وأمي كيف يذيبان؟ - قال: يذهبان (3) 225 - عنه، عن بعض من رواه، قال: قال أبو عبد الله (ع): اغسلوا أيديكم قبل الطعام وبعده، فإنه ينفى الفقر ويزيد في العمر (4).
226 - عنه، عن علي بن الحكم، عن سيف بن عميرة، عن أبي بكر الحضرمي، قال: كان أبو عبد الله (ع) يدعو لنا بالطعام، فلا يوضينا قبله ويأمر الخادم فيتوضأ بعد الطعام (5).
227 - عنه، عن إبراهيم بن هاشم، عن إبراهيم بن أبي محمود، قال: أخبرني بعض أصحابنا قال: ذكر للرضا (ع) الوضوء قبل الطعام فقال: ذلك شئ أحدثته الملوك (6).
228 - عنه، عن الفضل بن مبارك، عن الفضل بن يونس، قال: لما تغدى أبو الحسن موسى (ع) عندي وجئ بالطشت بدئ به، وكان في الصدر، فقال: إبدأ بمن عن يمينك، فلما توضأ واحد وأراد الغلام أن يرفع الطشت، فقال له أبو الحسن: أنزعها (7)

31 - Chapter on What Does Not Require Ablution

235 - From him, from his father, from al-Qasim bin Muhammad, from al-Husayn bin Abi al-Ala, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (a.s.) about ablution after eating? - He said: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, was eating when Ibn Umm Maktum came, and in the hand of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, was a shoulder of lamb that he was eating from. He put down what was in his hand and stood up for prayer without performing ablution, so there is no purification in it. (2)

236 - From him, from Uthman bin Issa, from Sama'a bin Mehran, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (a.s.) about someone who ate meat or drank milk, does he have to perform ablution? - He said: No, the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, ate a shoulder of lamb and then prayed without performing ablution. (3)

237 - From him, from Hammad bin Issa, from Yaqub bin Shuaib, from Abu Basir, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (a.s.), should one perform ablution after drinking camel's milk? - He said: No, nor from bread and meat. From him, from his father, from Safwan bin Yahya and Abdullah bin al-Mughira, from Muhammad bin Sinan, the same. From him, from al-Washa' from Muhammad bin Sinan, the same. (4)

238 - From him, from Ibn al-Azrami (a.s.) from Zaynab bint Umm Salama, who said: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, was brought a shoulder of lamb, and he ate from it and prayed without touching water. (5)

239 - From him, from Jaafar bin Muhammad, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Abu Abdullah, from his father, from Ali bin al-Husayn (a.s.) from Zaynab bint Umm Salama, from Umm Salama, who said: The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, was brought a shoulder of lamb and he ate from it, then the call to Asr prayer was given, and he prayed without touching water. (6)

240 - From him, from his father, from al-Nadr bin Suwaid, from Hisham bin Salim, from Sulaiman bin Khalid, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (a.s.), does one perform ablution after eating or drinking milk? - He said: No. (7)

If one performs ablution before eating, he should not use a towel, but if he performs ablution after eating, he should use a towel (1).
245 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Abi al-Mughra Humaid ibn al-Muthanna al-'Ajli, from Zaid al-Shahham, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) that he disliked for a man to wipe his hand with a towel while there is something of food on it, out of respect for the food, until he sucks it, or there is a boy next to him who sucks it (2).
246 - From him, from his father, from Ali ibn al-Nu'man, from Mansur ibn Hazim, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a man wiping his face with a towel? He said: There is nothing wrong with it (3).
247 - From him, from his father, from someone he mentioned, from Abdullah ibn Sinan, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about using a towel after ablution? He said: Ali (peace be upon him) had a cloth in the mosque only for his face, with which he would dry himself. From him, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Aban, from Uthman, from Abdullah ibn Sinan, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), similar to it (4).
248 - And with his chain of narration, he said: Ali (peace be upon him) had a cloth that he would hang in his house's mosque for his face, with which he would dry himself when he performed ablution (5).
249 - From him, from al-Washsha', from Muhammad ibn Sinan, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Commander of the Believers (peace be upon him) had a cloth with which he would wipe his face when he performed ablution for prayer, and he would hang it on a peg, and no one else would touch it (6).
250 - From him, from Ibrahim ibn Muhammad al-Thaqafi, from Ali ibn al-Mu'alla al-Baghdadi, from Ibrahim ibn Muhammad ibn Humran, from his father, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: Whoever performs ablution and then dries himself with a towel will have a good deed recorded for him, and whoever performs ablution and does not dry himself until his ablution dries will have thirty good deeds recorded for him (7).

قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله إذا وضعت المائدة حفها أربعة أملاك فإذا قال العبد: " بسم الله " قالت الملائكة: " بارك الله لكم في طعامكم " ثم يقولون للشيطان: " اخرج يا فاسق لا سلطان لك عليهم "، فإذا فرغوا قالوا: " الحمد لله رب العالمين " قالت الملائكة، " قوم قد أنعم الله عليهم فأدوا شكر ربهم " فإذا لم يسم قالت الملائكة للشيطان: " ادن يا فاسق فكل معهم " وإذا رفعت المائدة ولم يذكر الله قالت الملائكة: " قوم أنعم الله عليهم فنسوا ربهم " (1).
259 - عنه، عن أبي أيوب المدايني، عن محمد بن أبي عمير، عن حسين بن مختار، عن رجل، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: إذا أكلت الطعام فقل: " بسم الله " في أوله وآخره فإن العبد إذا سمى في طعامه قبل أن يأكل لم يأكل معه الشيطان، وإذا لم يسم أكل معه الشيطان، وإذا سمى بعدما يأكل وأكل الشيطان معه تقيأ ما كان أكل (2).
260 - عنه، عن ابن فضال، عن أبي جميلة، عن محمد بن مروان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: إذا وضع الغداء والعشاء فقل: " بسم الله " قان الشيطان يقول لأصحابه: " اخرجوا فليس ههنا عشاء ولا مبيت " وإن هو نسي أن يسمى قال لأصحابه: " تعالوا فإن لكم هناك عشاء ومبيتا " قال: ورواه محمد بن سنان، عن العلاء بن فضيل، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) مثله. قال: ورواه أيضا محمد بن سنان، عن حماد بن عثمان، عن ربعي بن عبد الله،

The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, said: “When the table is set, four angels surround it. When the servant says, "In the name of God (Bismillah)," the angels say, "May God bless you in your food." Then they say to Satan, "Get out, you wicked one, you have no power over them." When they finish, they say, "Praise be to God, Lord of the Worlds." The angels say, "A people whom God has blessed and who have given thanks to their Lord." If they do not mention His name, the angels say to Satan, "Come near, you wicked one, and eat with them." And when the table is removed and God is not mentioned, the angels say, "A people whom God has blessed but who have forgotten their Lord" (1).

259 - From him, from Abu Ayyub al-Mudaini, from Muhammad ibn Abi Umair, from Hussein ibn Mukhtar, from a man, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "When you eat food, say, 'In the name of God (Bismillah)' at the beginning and the end. For if the servant mentions God's name over his food before he eats, Satan does not eat with him. And if he does not mention His name, Satan eats with him. And if he mentions His name after he eats, and Satan has eaten with him, he will vomit what he ate" (2).

260 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Abu Jamila, from Muhammad ibn Marwan, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "When lunch and dinner are set, say, 'In the name of God (Bismillah),' for Satan says to his companions, 'Get out, there is no dinner or lodging here.' And if he forgets to mention His name, he says to his companions, 'Come, for you have dinner and lodging there.'" He said: And Muhammad ibn Sinan narrated it, from al-Ala ibn Fudail, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), similarly. He said: And Muhammad ibn Sinan also narrated it, from Hammad ibn Uthman, from Rib'i ibn Abdullah,

1 - J 14, "Chapter on Saying Bismillah, Praising God, and Supplication," (p. 885, lines 17 and 25), saying after the first hadith: "Clarification - Know that the plural of 'malak' as 'amlak' is not known, rather it is pluralized as 'mala'ika' and 'mala'ik'. There is disagreement about its derivation. The majority hold that it is from 'al-aluka,' which is the message. Al-Khalil said, 'Al-aluk is the message, and it is al-mal'aka, and al-mal'aka is on the pattern of 'mif'ala'. Thus, 'al-mala'ika' is on the pattern of 'mu'afala' because it is the reversed plural of 'malak' in the meaning of 'ma'lak'. So the weight of 'malak' is 'muf'al,' reversed from 'ma'lak'. Some Arabs use it with a hamza according to its origin, but the majority of them drop the vowel of the hamza onto the lam and delete it, so it is said 'malak'. Abu Ubaidah held that its origin is from 'laka' when he sent, so 'malak' is 'muf'al' and 'mala'ika' is 'mufa'ala' not reversed, and the mim on both accounts is extra. Ibn Kisan held that it is from 'al-mulk' (kingship) and that the weight of 'muf'al' is 'malak' like 'sam'al,' and 'mala'ika' is 'fa'aila,' so the mim is original and the hamza is extra. Based on this, it is not far-fetched that it is pluralized as 'amlak' even if it is not transmitted." And saying after the second hadith: "Explanation - It is narrated in al-Kafi: from Ali ibn Ibrahim, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair, from al-Hussein ibn Uthman, and both are possible here, and his (peace be upon him) saying "at the beginning" is a ظرف (temporal adverb) for the saying, meaning say it at both times, or with the related element of the الظرف in the saying of Bismillah, so it will be a part of it."

And he added to it, "So he said: If one of you performs ablution and does not mention the name [of God], the devil has a partnership in his ablution. 261 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Faddal, from Abi Jamila, from Zayd al-Shahham, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: If one of you performs ablution, or eats, or drinks, or wears clothing, he should mention the name [of God] on it, for if he does not do so, the devil has a partnership in it (2).
262 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Abi Umayr, from Ali ibn Abi Hamza, from Abi Basir, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: When the eating cloth [food] is placed, say: "Bismillah (In the name of God)," and when you eat, say: "Bismillah (In the name of God)" at its beginning and end, and when the eating cloth [food] is removed, say: "Alhamdulillah (Praise be to God)" (3).
263 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Abdullah, from Amr al-Mutatabbeb, from Abi Yahya al-San'ani, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Ali ibn al-Hussein (a.s.) when food was placed before him, would say:
"O God, this is from Your grace, bounty, and gifts, so bless it for us and make it easy to swallow, and grant us a replacement when we have eaten it, and [remember] every needy person You provide for and are generous to. O God, make us among the grateful to You." And when the eating cloth [food] was removed, he would say: "Praise be to God who carried us on land and sea and provided us with good things and favored us over many of His creation (or of those He created) with great favor" (4).
264 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Abdullah ibn Sinan, from his father, who said: Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said: O Sinan, whoever has food presented to him and eats it, and says: "Alhamdulillah (Praise be to God) who provided me with it without any power or strength from me," he will be forgiven before he gets up (or he said: "before his food is removed") (5).

عن أبي حمزة، عن علي بن الحسين (ع) أنه كان إذا أطعم قال: الحمد لله الذي أطعمنا، وسقانا، وكفانا، وأيدنا، وآوانا، وأنعم علينا، وأفضل، الحمد لله الذي يطعم ولا يطعم " قال: ورواه إسماعيل بن مهران، عن أيمن بن محرز، عن أبي حمزة ومحمد بن علي، عن أحمد بن محسن الميثمي، عن مهزم، عن رجل، عن أبي جعفر (ع) قال: كان رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله إذا رفعت المائدة قال: " اللهم أكثرت وأطبت فباركه، وأشبعت وأرويت فهنئه، الحمد لله الذي يطعم ولا يطعم (1).
278 - عنه، عن بعض أصحابنا، عن علي بن أسباط، عن عمه يعقوب أو غيره، رفعه قال: كان أمير المؤمنين (ع) يقول: " اللهم إن هذا من عطائك فبارك لنا فيه وسوغناه و أخلف لنا خلفا لما أكلناه أو شربناه من غير حول منا ولا قوة، رزقت فأحسنت فلك الحمد رب اجعلنا من الشاكرين " وإذا فرغ قال: " الحمد الله الذي كفانا وأكرمنا، وحملنا في البر والبحر، ورزقنا من الطيبات، وفضلنا على كثير ممن خلق تفضيلا، الحمد لله الذي كفانا المؤنة وأسبغ علينا " (2).
279 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن حماد بن عيسى، عن الحسن بن المختار، عن أبي بصير، قال: تغديت مع أبي جعفر (ع) فلما وضعت المائدة قال: " بسم الله " فلما فرغ قال:
" الحمد لله الذي أطعمنا وسقانا، ورزقنا وعافانا، ومن علينا بمحمد (صلى الله عليه وآله) وجعلنا مسلمين " (3).
280 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن هشام بن سالم، عن أبي عبد الله (ع)، قال: قال: " الحمد لله الذي أشبعنا في جائعين، وأروانا في طمآنين، وكسانا في عارين، و آوانا في ضاحين، وحملنا في راجلين، وآمننا في خائفين، وأخدمنا في عانين، قال: وروى

From Abi Hamza, from Ali bin Al-Hussein (peace be upon him) that when he fed someone, he would say: "Praise be to Allah who fed us, gave us drink, sufficed us, supported us, sheltered us, bestowed upon us, and favored us. Praise be to Allah who feeds and is not fed." He said: And Ismail bin Mehran narrated it, from Ayman bin Mahrez, from Abi Hamza and Muhammad bin Ali, from Ahmed bin Mohsen Al-Maithami, from Mahzam, from a man, from Abi Jaafar (peace be upon him) who said: When the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) had the table removed, he would say: "O Allah, You have increased and made good, so bless it, and You have satisfied and quenched, so make it pleasant. Praise be to Allah who feeds and is not fed."(1)

278 - From him, from some of our companions, from Ali bin Asbat, from his uncle Yaqub or someone else, raising it (the narration), he said: The Commander of the Believers (peace be upon him) used to say: "O Allah, this is from Your bounty, so bless it for us and make it easy for us to swallow, and replace for us a substitute for what we have eaten or drunk without any power or strength from us. You provided and did well, so praise be to You, Lord, make us among the grateful." And when he finished, he would say: "Praise be to Allah who sufficed us and honored us, and carried us on land and sea, and provided us with good things, and favored us over many of those He created with preference. Praise be to Allah who spared us the burden and lavished upon us."(2)

279 - From him, from his father, from Hammad bin Issa, from Al-Hasan bin Al-Mukhtar, from Abi Basir, who said: I had lunch with Abi Jaafar (peace be upon him), and when the table was set, he said: "In the name of Allah." And when he finished, he said: "Praise be to Allah who fed us and gave us drink, and provided for us and healed us, and bestowed upon us through Muhammad (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) and made us Muslims."(3)

280 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair, from Hisham bin Salem, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: He said: "Praise be to Allah who satiated us amidst the hungry, and quenched our thirst amidst the thirsty, and clothed us amidst the naked, and sheltered us amidst those exposed, and carried us amidst those on foot, and secured us amidst the fearful, and made subservient to us amidst the captive." He said: And it was narrated

283 - From him, from al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn Faddal, from Abu Bukair, from Ubaid ibn Zurara, who said: I ate food with Abu Abdullah (a.s.), and I cannot count how many times he said: "Praise be to Allah who made me desire it" (4).

So I sat down until the tray was placed, and he mentioned God's name when the tray was placed, and when he finished, he said: "Praise be to Allah, O Allah, this is from You and from Muhammad, may God bless him and his family" (5).

285 - From him, from al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn Faddal, from Dawud ibn Farqad, I think from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) guaranteed that whoever mentions God's name on his food will not complain about it. Ibn al-Kawa' said: O Amir al-Mu'minin, I ate food last night and mentioned God's name on it, but it harmed me. He said: Perhaps you ate different types of food and mentioned God's name on some of them but not on others, O fool (6).

286 - From him, from his father, from Hammad bin Issa, from Misma' bin Abdul-Malik, who said: I said to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him): I suffer from indigestion. He said: Do you say Bismillah? I said: I do say Bismillah. He said: Perhaps you eat different types of food? I said: Yes. He said: Do you say Bismillah over each type? I said: No. He said: That is why you suffer from indigestion (1).
287 - From him, from his father, from Abu Talib al-Basri, from Misma', who said: I complained to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about the harm I suffer from food when I eat. He said: Why don't you say Bismillah? I said: I do say Bismillah, but it still harms me! He said: If you interrupt saying Bismillah with speech and then return to the food, do you say Bismillah again? I said: No. He said: That is why it harms you. If you were to say Bismillah when you return to the food, it would not harm you (2).
288 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Abdullah al-Arjani, from Abu Abdullah, from his forefathers (peace be upon them), who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) never suffered from indigestion. It was said to him: Why? He said: I never raise a morsel to my mouth without mentioning the name of Allah upon it (3).
289 - From him, from Yaqub bin Yazid, from Ahmad bin Muhsin al-Mithami, from Abu Maryam al-Ansari, from al-Asbagh bin Nubata, who said: I entered upon Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) and there was grilled meat in front of him. He invited me and said: Come to this grilled meat. I said: If I eat it, it will harm me. He said: Shall I not teach you words that you can say, and I guarantee you that no food will harm you? Say: "O Allah, I ask You by Your Name, the best of names, which fills the earth and the sky, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, with Whose Name no disease can harm." Then it will never harm you (4).
290 - From him, from some of our companions, from al-Asamm, from Abdullah al-Arjani, from Abu Abdullah, from his forefathers (peace be upon them), who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) said: I never suffered from indigestion. 42 - Chapter on Licking Fingers

313 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Abi Umayr, from Hammad ibn Uthman, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) would lick his fingers when he ate. (1)

314 - From him, from Ibn Faddal and Ja’far, from Abdullah ibn Maymun al-Qaddah, from Abi Abdullah, from his father (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) would lick his fingers in his mouth and suck them when he finished his food. (2)

315 - From him, from al-Qasim ibn Yahya, from his grandfather al-Hasan ibn Rashid, from Abi Basir, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: If one of you eats food, and sucks the fingers with which he ate, Allah Almighty and Glorious will say: “May Allah bless you.” (3)

316 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Ali, from al-Hakam ibn Miskeen, from Amr ibn Shimr, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: I lick my fingers so much that I see my servant saying: How greedy is my master! (4)

317 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Abi al-Mughra, from Abi Usama Zayd al-Shahham, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), that he disliked that a man wipe his hand with a handkerchief when there was something of food on it, out of reverence for the food, until he sucked it, or there was a child next to him who would suck it. (5)

318 - From him, from his father, from Yunus from Abd al-Rahman, from Amr ibn Jami’, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) would lick the bowl, saying: Whoever licks a bowl, it is as if he has given its equivalent in charity. (6)

43 - Chapter on Eating What Falls of Crumbs

319 - From him, from Salih ibn al-Sindi, from Ja’far ibn Bashir, from Dawud ibn Kathir, who said:
I had supper with Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) late in the evening. When he finished his supper, he praised Allah and then said: This is my supper and the supper of my forefathers. When the tray was removed, he picked up what had fallen from it and then put it in his mouth. (7)

320 - عنه، عن ابن فضال، عن أبي المعزا، عن أبي أسامة، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال:
إني لاجد الشئ اليسير يقع من الخوان فأعيده، فيضحك الخادم (1).
321 - عنه، عن بعض أصحابنا، عن الأصم، عن عبد الله الأرجاني، قال: كنت عند أبي عبد الله (ع) وهو يأكل، فرأيته يتتبع مثل السمسمة من الطعام ما يسقط من الخوان، فقلت: جعلت فداك تتبع مثل هذا؟! - قال: يا عبد الله هذا رزقك فلا تدعه لغيرك أما إن فيه شفاء من كل داء. عنه قال: ورواه يعقوب بن يزيد، عن ابن فضال، عن أبي - عبد الله الأرجاني (2).
322 - عنه، عن النوفلي، باسناده، قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: من تتبع ما يقع من مائدته فأكله ذهب عنه الفقر وعن ولده وولده إلى السابع (3).
323 - عنه، عن القاسم بن يحيى، عن جده الحسن بن راشد، عن أبي بصير، عن أبي عبد الله، عن آبائه (ع) قال: قال أمير المؤمنين (ع): كلوا ما يسقط من الخوان، فإن فيه شفاء من كل داء بإذن الله لمن أراد أن يستشقى به، قال: ورواه بعض أصحابنا، عن - الأصم، عن شعيب، عن أبي بصير، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) (4).
324 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن إبراهيم بن عبد الله، عن عبد الله بن صالح الخثعمي، قال: شكوت إلى أبى عبد الله (ع) وجع الخاصرة، فقال: عليك بما يسقط من الخوان، فكله، ففعلت ذلك فذهب عنى، قال إبراهيم: قد كنت أجد في الجانب الأيمن والأيسر، فأخذت ذلك فانتفعت به (5).

320 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Abi al-Mu'azza, from Abi Usama, from Abi Abdillah (a.s.) who said:
"I find a small thing falling from the eating surface (Khwan) and I pick it up, and the servant laughs (1)."
321 - From him, from some of our companions, from Al-Asamm, from Abdullah al-Arjani, who said: I was with Abi Abdillah (a.s.) while he was eating, and I saw him following specks like sesame seeds of food that fell from the eating surface (Khwan). I said, "May I be made your ransom, you follow such things?!" He said: "O Abdullah, this is your sustenance, so do not leave it for others. Verily, in it is a cure for every disease." From him, he said: Yaqub bin Yazid narrated it, from Ibn Faddal, from Abi - Abdullah al-Arjani (2).
322 - From him, from al-Nawfali, with his chain of narration, who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Whoever picks up what falls from his dining spread and eats it, poverty will depart from him and from his child and his child to the seventh generation (3)."
323 - From him, from al-Qasim bin Yahya, from his grandfather al-Hasan bin Rashid, from Abi Basir, from Abi Abdillah, from his forefathers (a.s.) who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) said: "Eat what falls from the eating surface (Khwan), for in it is a cure for every disease by the permission of Allah for whoever intends to seek healing with it." He said: And some of our companions narrated it, from - al-Asamm, from Shu'aib, from Abi Basir, from Abi Abdillah (a.s.) (4).
324 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair, from Ibrahim bin Abdullah, from Abdullah bin Salih al-Khath'ami, who said: I complained to Abi Abdillah (a.s.) about pain in my side, so he said: "You should eat what falls from the eating surface (Khwan), so eat it." So I did that, and it went away from me. Ibrahim said: "I used to find it on the right and left sides, so I took that and benefited from it (5)."
325 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Ibrahim bin Mahzam, from Ibn al-Hurr, who said: A man complained to Abi Abdillah (a.s.) about what he suffers from side pain, so he said: "What prevents you from eating what falls from the eating surface (Khwan)?" (6).
326 - From him, from Mansur bin al-Abbas, from al-Hasan bin Muawiya bin Wahb, from his father, who said:
We ate at Abi Abdillah's (a.s.) place, and when the eating surface (Khwan) was lifted, he picked up what fell from it and ate it, then he said: "It negates poverty and increases offspring (7)."

327 - From him, from his father, from Muammar bin Khallad, who said: I heard Abu al-Hasan al-Ridha (peace be upon him) saying: "Whoever eats food in his house and something falls from it, let him pick it up and eat it. And whoever eats in the desert or outside, let him leave it for the birds and beasts of prey." (1)
328 - From him, from his father, from Yunus bin Abd al-Rahman, from Amr bin Jami', from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Whoever finds a piece of bread and eats it, he will have seven hundred good deeds. And whoever finds it in filth and washes it, then picks it up, he will have seventy good deeds." (2)
329 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from one who mentioned it, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said regarding a date or a piece of bread that is lying on the ground, and a person takes it, wipes it, and eats it: "It will not settle in his stomach until Paradise is assured for him." (3)
330 - From him, from Musa bin al-Qasim, from Muhammad bin Saeed bin Ghazwan, from Ismail bin Abi Ziyad, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Whoever finds a piece of bread or a date lying and eats it, it will not settle in his stomach until Allah forgives him." (4)
331 - From him, from his father, from Yunus bin Abd al-Rahman, from Amr bin Jami', from Abu - Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) entered upon Aisha and saw a piece of bread that he was about to step on, so he picked it up and ate it and said: "O Humayra, honor the neighborhood of Allah's blessing upon you, for it does not flee from a people and then almost return to them." (5)
