May God’s peace and blessings be upon him and his family: “What a wretched aid to faith is a cowardly heart, a gluttonous belly, and an intense lust.” (1)

333 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Sinan, from Salih al-Nili, from Abi Abdillah (peace be upon him) who said: “Verily, God, Blessed and Exalted, detests excessive eating.” From him, from Muhammad ibn Ali, from Muhammad ibn Sinan, from Ibn Miskan, from Abi Basir, from Abi Abdillah (peace be upon him), similar to it. (2)

334 - From him, from Abdullah ibn Muhammad al-Hajjal, from Bahlul ibn Muslim, from Yunus ibn Ammar, from Abi Abdillah (peace be upon him) who said: “Excessive eating is disliked.” (3)

335 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn al-Qasim, from al-Husayn ibn al-Mukhtar, from Abi Abdillah (peace be upon him) who said: “Verily, when the belly is full, it rebels.” (4)

336 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Amr, from Bashir al-Dihqan, or from whomever he mentioned it from, who said: Abu al-Hasan (peace be upon him) said: “Verily, God detests the belly that is never satisfied.” (5)

337 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Ali, from Wuhaib ibn Hafs, from Abi Basir, from Abi - Abdillah (peace be upon him) who said: He said to me: “O Abu Muhammad, verily the belly rebels from its eating, and the closest a servant is to God is when his belly is empty, and the most hateful a servant is to God is when his belly is full.” (6)

338 - From him, he said: Bakr ibn Salih narrated to me, from Ja’far ibn Muhammad al-Hashimi from Abi - Ja’far al-Attar, who said: I heard Ja’far ibn Muhammad narrating from his father, from his grandfather (peace be upon him), from the Messenger of God, may God’s peace and blessings be upon him and his family, who said: Gabriel (peace be upon him) said in a statement he conveyed to me from my Lord: “O Muhammad, and another thing, which is the first and the last; your Lord says to you: O Muhammad, I have never detested any vessel except a full belly.” (7)

45 - Chapter on Belching
344 - From him, from al-Nawfali, with his chain of narration, who said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: 'When you belch, do not raise your belches to the sky (6).'"

346 - From him, from several of our companions, from Ali ibn Asbat, from his uncle Yaqub, who traced it back to Ali ibn Abi Talib (peace be upon him), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) said: "Do not leave a soiled cloth in the house, for it is a resting place for Satan (1)."
46 - Chapter on the etiquette of eating 347 - From him, who said: Al-Hasan ibn Ali al-Washsha' narrated to us, from Ahmad ibn A'idh, from Abi Khadija, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), that Amr ibn Ubayd, Wasil, and Bashir al-Rahhal asked him about the limits of eating? - He said: "A person should eat from what is in front of him and not take anything from in front of another person (2)."
348 - From him, from Ja'far, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Abi Abdullah, from his father (peace be upon them), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) said: "When one of you eats, let him eat from what is near him (3)."
349 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Abi Abdullah, from his father (peace be upon them), who said:
The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) would, when eating food with people, be the first to put his hand in and the last to raise it, so that the people could eat (4).
350 - From him, from Yaqub ibn Yazid, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from Abi Salama, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: Abdullah ibn Ali ibn al-Husayn (peace be upon them) came to my father asking permission for Amr ibn Ubayd, Wasil, the client of Hubayra, and Bashir al-Rahhal to enter. He gave them permission, so they entered and sat down. They said: "O Abu Ja'far, does everything have a limit to which it extends?" - Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) said: "Yes, everything has a limit to which it extends, and there is nothing but it has a limit." He said: Then the food tray was brought and placed, and they said among themselves: "By God, we have gained control over Abu Ja'far." They said: "O Abu Ja'far, is this tray from something?" - He said: "Yes." They said: "What is its limit?" - He said: "Its limit is when a man places his hand and says: 'In the name of Allah,' and when he raises it, he says: 'Praise be to Allah,' and each person eats from what is in front of him and does not take from in front of another." He said: And Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) called for water for them to drink, and they said: "O Abu Ja'far, is this pitcher from something?" - He said: "Yes." They said: "What is its limit?" - He said: "Its limit is that he drinks from its middle lip, and mentions the name of Allah upon it, and does not drink from the ear of the pitcher, for it is a drinking place."

قال: أتاني أبو الحسن موسى بن جعفر (ع) في حاجة للحسين بن يزيد، فقلت: إن طعامنا قد حضر، فأحب أن تتغدى عندي، قال: نحن نأكل طعام الفجاء، ثم نزل فجئته بغداء ووضعت منديلا على فخذيه، فأخذه فنحاه ناحية، ثم أكل ثم قال لي: يا فضل كل مما في اللهوات والأشداق، ولا تأكل ما بين أضعاف الأسنان. قال: وروى الفضل بن يونس في حديث: ان أبا الحسن (ع) جلس في المجلس وقال: صاحب المجلس أحق بهذا المجلس، إلا لرجل واحد، وكانت لفضل دعوة يومئذ فقال أبو الحسن (ع):
هات طعامك فإنهم يزعمون أنا لا نأكل طعام الفجاءة، فأتى بالطست فبدأ هو، ثم قال:
أدرها عن يسارك ولا تحملها إلا مترعة، ثم اتكأ على يساره بيده على الأرض، وأكل بيمينه حتى إذا فرغ أتى بالخلال، فقال: يا فضل أدر لسانك في فيك، فما تبع لسانك فكله إن شئت، وما استكرهته بالخلال فالفظه (1).
footnote:
١ ج ١٤، " باب جوامع آداب الاكل "، (ص ٨٩٣، س ٣٣) قائلا بعده: " بيان قوله (ع): " ولا تأكل " ظاهره النهى عن أكل ما بين الأسنان مطلقا وإن أخرج باللسان وهو مخالف لسائر الاخبار، ويمكن أن يحمل على ما يبقى بعد امرار اللسان، ثم الظاهر من كلام من تعرض لهذا الحكم من الأصحاب أنه يكره أكل ما خرج بالخلال وربما يتوهم فيه التحريم للخباثة وهو في محل المنع، مع أنك قد عرفت عدم قيام الدليل على تحريم الخبيث مطلقا بالمعنى الذي فهمه الأصحاب رضي الله عنهم، قال الشهيد (ره) في الدروس: " ويستحب التخلل وقذف ما أخرجه الخلال بالكسر وابتلاع ما أخرجه اللسان " (انتهى) وقد روى الكليني (ره) في الموثق عن إسحاق بن جرير قال: سألت أبا عبد الله (ع) عن اللحم الذي يكون في الأسنان؟ - فقال:
" أماما كان في مقدم الفم فكله، وأما ما كان في الأضراس فاطرحه ". وفى الصحيح عن ابن سنان عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: " أما ما يكون على اللثة فكله وازدرده، وما كان بين الأسنان فارم به " وفى الموثق عن الفضل بن يونس عن أبي الحسن (ع) قال: " يا فضل كل ما بقي في فيك مما أدرت عليه لسانك فكله، وما استكن فأخرجته بالخلال فأنت فيه بالخيار، إن شئت أكلته، وإن شئت طرحته ". وفى المرفوع عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: " لا يزدردن أحدكم ما يتخلل به، فإنه تكون منه الدبيلة " فمقتضى الجمع بين الاخبار الكراهة، وإن كان الأحوط عدم أكل ما يخرج بالخلال، لا سيما إذا تغير ريحه فإن شائبة الخباثة فيه أكثر وستأتي أخبار فيه في باب الخلال، وفى المصباح " اللهام " = اللحمة المشرفة على الحلق في أقصى الفم، والجمع لهى ولهيات مثل حصى وحصيات ولهوات أيضا على الأصل ". وقال: " الشدق " = جانب الفم (بالفتح والكسر) قاله الأزهري وجمع المفتوح شدوق مثل فلس وفلوس، وجمع المكسور أشداق مثل حمل وأحمال وقوله (ع): " إلا لرجل واحد " الظاهر أن المراد به الإمام وسيأتي مكانه " رجل من بني هاشم " ويدل الخبر على أن الاتكاء باليد ليس من الاتكاء المكروه كما مر. وقال أيضا بعد نقل شئ منه في باب غسل اليد قبل الطعام وبعده (883، س 5) " بيان - كأن المراد بطعام الفجاءة الطعام الذي ورد عليه الانسان من غير تقدمة وتمهيد ودعوة سابقة. " فبدأ " يمكن أن يقرأ على بناء المجهول على وفق ما مر وقوله (ع) " عن يسارك " مخالف لما مر، مع أن السند واحد، ويمكن الحمل على التخيير، أو كون اليسار بالنسبة إلى الخارج كما أن اليمين كان بالنسبة إلى الداخل، والأظهر حمل هذا على الغسل الأول وما مر على الغسل الثاني فقوله " فبدأ " هنا على بناء المعلوم وارتفع التنافي من جميع الوجوه ".

He said: Abu al-Hasan Musa bin Ja'far (peace be upon him) came to me seeking something for al-Husayn bin Yazid, so I said: "Our food is ready, and I would love for you to have lunch with me." He said: "We eat the food of al-Fajaa'," then he dismounted. I brought him lunch and placed a napkin on his thighs, but he took it and moved it aside. Then he ate and said to me: "O Fadl, eat what is in the uvulas and corners of the mouth, and do not eat what is between the folds of the teeth." He said: And al-Fadl bin Yunus narrated in a hadith: That Abu al-Hasan (peace be upon him) sat in the gathering and said: "The host of the gathering is more entitled to this gathering, except for one man." And Fadl had an invitation that day, so Abu al-Hasan (peace be upon him) said: "Bring your food, for they claim that we do not eat the food of al-Fajaa'," so the basin was brought and he started first, then he said: "Pass it on your left and do not carry it unless it is full," then he leaned on his left with his hand on the ground, and ate with his right. When he finished, the toothpick was brought, so he said: "O Fadl, move your tongue in your mouth, and whatever your tongue follows, eat if you wish, and whatever you force out with the toothpick, discard it (1)."
---

It can be interpreted as referring to what remains after passing the tongue. Then, what is apparent from the words of those who have addressed this ruling among the companions is that it is disliked to eat what is removed with a toothpick, and perhaps prohibition is suspected due to its foulness, and it is in the place of prohibition, even though you have known that there is no evidence for the absolute prohibition of what is foul in the meaning understood by the companions, may Allah be pleased with them. Al-Shahid (may his soul rest in peace) said in al-Durus: "It is recommended to use a toothpick and discard what the toothpick removes, and swallow what the tongue removes" (end). Al-Kulayni (may his soul rest in peace) narrated in the reliable report from Ishaq bin Jarir who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about the meat that is in the teeth? - He said: "As for what is in the front of the mouth, eat it, and as for what is in the molars, throw it away." And in the authentic report from Ibn Sinan from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "As for what is on the gums, eat it and swallow it, and what is between the teeth, throw it away." And in the reliable report from al-Fadl bin Yunus from Abu al-Hasan (peace be upon him) who said: "O Fadl, eat whatever remains in your mouth of what you have moved your tongue over, and whatever is concealed and you remove with the toothpick, you have a choice in it, if you wish, eat it, and if you wish, throw it away." And in the elevated report from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "Let none of you swallow what he uses as a toothpick, for it causes diphtheria." Therefore, the requirement of reconciling between the narrations is dislike, even if the more cautious approach is to not eat what is removed with the toothpick, especially if its smell has changed, for the tinge of foulness in it is greater, and news about it will come in the chapter on toothpicks. And in al-Misbah "al-Laham" = the flesh overlooking the throat in the farthest part of the mouth, and the plural is luha and luhiyat like hasa and hasayat and lahuwat also on the original." And he also said after نقل شئ منه in the chapter on washing the hand before and after food (883, line 5) "Explanation - it is as if what is meant by food of surprise is the food that came to the human without preparation, arranging, or previous invitation. "So he started" can be read in the passive voice according to what was mentioned previously and his saying (peace be upon him) "on your left" is contrary to what was mentioned previously, even though the chain of transmission is the same, and it can be carried on to mean choice, or that the left is in relation to the outside just as the right was in relation to the inside, and the more apparent is to carry this on the first washing and what was mentioned before on the second washing so his saying "so he started" here on the active voice and the contradiction is removed from all aspects."

375 - عنه عن عدة من أصحابنا، عن العلاء بن رزين، عن محمد عن مسلم قال:
سألت أبا جعفر (ع) عن آنية أهل الذمة؟ - فقال: لا تأكلوا فيها إذا كانوا يأكلون فيها الميتة والدم ولحم الخنزير (1).
376 - عنه، عن ابن محبوب، عن العلاء، عن محمد بن مسلم، قال: سألت أبا جعفر (ع) عن آنية أهل الذمة والمجوس، فقال: لا تأكلوا في آنيتهم، ولا من طعامهم الذي يطبخون، ولا من آنيتهم التي يشربون فيها الخمر (2) 377 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن صفوان، عن إسماعيل بن جابر، قال: قلت لأبي عبد الله (ع) في طعام أهل الكتاب فقال: " لا تأكله " ثم سكت هنيئة ثم قال: " لا تأكله "، ثم سكت هنيئة ثم قال: لا تأكله ولا تتركه تقول: إنه حرام، ولكن تتركه تنزها عنه، إن في آنيتهم الخمر ولحم الخنزير (3).
378 - عنه، عن الوشاء، عن عبد الله بن سنان، قال: سمعت أبا عبد الله (ع) يقول:
لا بأس بكواميخ المجوس ولا بأس بصيدهم للسمك (4).
379 - عنه، عن أبيه وغيره، عن محمد بن سنان، عن أبي الجارود، قال: سألت أبا جعفر (ع) عن قول الله عز وجل: " وطعام الذين أوتوا الكتاب حل لكم "؟ - قال:
الحبوب والبقول (5).
footnote:
١ - ج ١٨، كتاب الطهارة، " باب أسئار الكفار وبيان نجاستهم وحكم ما لاقوه "، (ص ١٢، س ١٧ و ١٨ و ١٩ وص ١١، س ٢٠ و ٢٢) قائلا بعد الحديث الأخير:
" بيان - قال في القاموس " هنية " مصغر " هنة " أصلها " هنوة " أي شئ يسير ويروى " هنيهة " بابدال الياء هاء " وقال الشيخ البهائي قدس الله سره: " ما تضمنه هذا الحديث من نهيه (ع) عن أكل طعامهم أولا ثم سكوته نهيه ثم سكوته ثم أمره أخيرا بالتنزه عنه يوجب الطعن في متنه لاشعاره بتردده (ع) فيه وحاشاهم عن ذلك ثم قال: لعل نهيه (ع) عن أكل طعامهم محمول على الكراهة إن أريد به الحبوب ونحوها ويمكن جعل قوله (ع): " لا تأكله " مرتين للاشعار بالتحريم كما هو ظاهر التأكيد ويكون قوله بعد ذلك: " لا تأكله ولا تتركه " محمولا على التقية بعد حصول التنبيه والاشعار بالتحريم، هذا إن أريد بطعامهم اللحوم والدسوم وما مسوه برطوبة، ويمكن تخصيص الطعام بما عدا اللحوم ونحوها ويؤيده تعليله (ع) باشتمال آنيتهم على الخمر ولحم الخنزير " وقال الشهيد الثاني (ره): " تعليل النهى فيها بمباشرتهم للنجاسات يدل على عدم نجاسة ذواتهم، إذ لو كانت نجسة لم يحسن التعليل بالنجاسة العريضة التي قد تنفق وقد لا تنفق ". وقائلا بعد الحديث الرابع: " بيان - الظاهر أن المراد بالكواميخ ما يعملونه من السمك، ويمكن حمله على ما إذا علم إخراجهم له من الماء ولم يعلم ملاقاتهم وإن بعد " وقال أيضا في كتاب السماء والعالم، في باب الجراد والسمك (ص ٧٨١، س ٣٢) بعد ايراده: " بيان - حمله الشيخ وغيره على ما إذا أخذه المسلم منهم حيا أو شاهد المسلم إخراجه من الماء، والظاهر أن الكواميخ هي المتخذة من السمك وهذا التأويل في في غاية البعد، ويمكن حمله على التقية، أو على ما ادعوا عدم ملاقاتهم لها مع حمل الكامخ على غير المتخذ من السمك " وقال أيضا في هذا الكتاب في باب المرى والكامخ " (ص 870، س 8) بعد نقل حديث يشتمل عليهما: " توضيح - قال في بحر الجواهر: " الكامخ معرب كأمه والجمع كواميخ وهو صباغ يتخذ من الفوذنج واللبن والأبازير، والكواميخ كلها ردية للمعدة معطشة مفسدة للدم " وقال الجوهري: " الكامخ الذي يؤتدم به معرب والكمخ = السلح، وقدم إلى أعرابي خبز وكامخ فلم يعرفه فقيل له: " هذا كامخ " قال: علمت أنه كامخ، أيكم كمخ به؟ يريد سلح " (انتهى) وقال بعضهم: " الكواميخ هي صباغ يتخذ من الفوتنج واللبن والأبازير و " الفوتنج " هي خميرة الكواميخ المتخذة من دقيق الشعير الطحين العجين المدفون في اللبن أربعين يوما فيجدد اللبن حتى يربو ثم يستطرح فيه من الابازير من الانجدان والشبت أو الكبر أو سائر البقول ثم تنسب الكواميخ إلى ذلك " وأقول: يظهر من بعض الأخبار أنها كانت تعمل من السمك أيضا كما مر و. كأنها هي التي تسمى " الصحناة " قال في بحر الجواهر: " الصحناء " (بالكسر ويمد ويقصر) = إدام يتخذ من السمك، و " الصحناة " أخص منه كذا قال الجوهري " وفى المغرب " الصحناة " (بالفتح والكسر) = الصبر وهو بالفارسية " ما هي آبه "، والصحناة الشامية والمصرية إدام يتخذ من السمك الصغار أو السماق أو الليمو أو غير ذلك من الحموضات وهو مقوية مبردة للمعدة ".

375 - From him, from several of our companions, from Al-Alaa bin Razin, from Muhammad from Muslim, who said:
I asked Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him) about the utensils of the People of the Scripture? He said: "Do not eat from them if they eat carrion, blood, and pork in them." (1)
376 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Al-Alaa, from Muhammad bin Muslim, who said: I asked Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him) about the utensils of the People of the Scripture and the Magians, and he said: "Do not eat in their utensils, nor from their food that they cook, nor from their utensils in which they drink wine." (2)
377 - From him, from his father, from Safwan, from Ismail bin Jaber, who said: I said to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about the food of the People of the Book, and he said: "Do not eat it." Then he was silent for a moment, then he said: "Do not eat it." Then he was silent for a moment, then he said: "Do not eat it, and do not leave it saying: It is forbidden, but leave it out of abstinence from it, for in their utensils there is wine and pork." (3)
378 - From him, from Al-Washsha, from Abdullah bin Sinan, who said: I heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) say:
"There is nothing wrong with the *kawamikh* of the Magians, and there is nothing wrong with their hunting of fish." (4)
379 - From him, from his father and others, from Muhammad bin Sinan, from Abu al-Jarud, who said: I asked Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him) about the saying of God Almighty: "And the food of those who were given the Scripture is lawful for you"? He said: "Grains and legumes." (5)

387 - From him, from his father, from Ahmad ibn al-Nadr, from Amr ibn Shimr, from Jabir, from Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) used to eat like a slave and sit like a slave. He used to eat on the bare ground and sleep on the bare ground (1).
388 - From him, from Safwan, from Ibn Miskan, from al-Hasan al-Sayqal, who said: I heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) say: A foul-mouthed woman passed by the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) while he was eating, sitting on the bare ground. She said: O Muhammad, by God, you eat like a slave and sit like one. The Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) said to her: Woe to you, and what slave is more subservient than me?! She said: Give me a morsel of your food. So he gave it to her. She said: No, by God, only the one that is in your mouth. So the Messenger of God (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) took the morsel out of his mouth and gave it to her, and she ate it. Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: No disease afflicted her until her soul departed this world (2).

From al-Wasiti (1).
436 - From him, from his father, from someone he mentioned, from Abu Hafs al-Aban, from Abu Abdullah, from his forefathers, from Ali (a.s.) who said: Eat meat, for meat comes from meat, and meat grows meat. Whoever does not eat meat for forty days, his character will worsen. And if the character of any of you worsens, whether from a person or an animal, then recite the entire Adhan in his ear. Some narrate: "Any household that does not eat meat for forty nights, their morals will worsen" (2).
437 - And from him, from Ahmad ibn Muhammad, from al-Hussein ibn Khalid, who said: I said to Abu al-Hasan (a.s.): People say: Whoever does not eat meat for three days, his character will worsen. He said: They lie, but whoever does not eat meat for forty days, his character and body will change, and that is because of the transfer of the sperm in about forty days (3).
438 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair and al-Nadr ibn Suwaid, from Hisham ibn Salim, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Meat with milk is the broth of the prophets (4).

2 - (And also 1) - Vol. 18, Book of Prayer, "Chapter on the Adhan and Iqama," (p. 173, lines 15 and 17), saying after the first of the two: "Explanation - 'al-qurm = intense desire for meat'" and also saying at the end of the chapter (p. 176, line 12) after mentioning this hadith: "And from Ali (a.s.) that the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, said: 'Whoever has a child born to him, let him recite the Adhan in his right ear and the Iqama in his left ear, for that is a protection from Satan.'" From the book of al-Da'aim: "Explanation - al-Shahid, may his secret be sanctified, said in al-Dhikra: It is recommended to recite the Adhan and Iqama in places other than prayer, including in desolate wildernesses, in al-Ja'fariyat from the Prophet, peace and blessings be upon him and his family: "If the ghouls lead you astray, then recite the Adhan for prayer." And it is narrated in the hadith "There is no ghoul," and it invalidates the words of the Arabs, so it is possible that the Adhan is to ward off the imagination that occurs in the wilderness, even if it has no reality. The people of my house do not eat lamb.” He said, “Why?” I said, “They say it provokes their biliousness, jaundice, headaches, and pains.” He said, “O Sa'd, if Allah knew anything more honorable than lamb, He would have ransomed Ishmael (a.s.) with it.” (1)

56 - Chapter on Kebab
449 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Sinan and Abdullah bin al-Mughira, from Musa bin Bakr, who said: Abu al-Hasan the First (a.s.) said to me: “Why do I see you looking pale?” I said, “A fever has afflicted me.” He said, “Eat meat.” So I ate it, then he saw me after a week and I was still pale, so he said, “Did I not order you to eat meat?” I said, “I have eaten nothing else since you ordered me to.” He said, “How did you eat it?” I said, “Cooked.” He said, “No, eat it as kebab.” So I ate it, then he sent for me and called me after a week, and the blood had returned to my face, so he said: “Yes.” (5)
450 - From him, from Ali bin Hassan, from Musa bin Bakr, who said: “I complained of an ailment in Medina, so I went to Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) and he said to me: ‘I see you are weak?’” I said, “Yes.” He said, “Eat kebab.” So I ate it and recovered.” (6)
451 - From him, from Ahmad bin Abi Nasr, from Hammad bin Uthman, from Muhammad bin Suqa, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: “Kebab eliminates fever.” (7)

57 - باب الشواء 452 - عنه، عن محمد بن الحسن الصفار، عن موسى بن عمر، عن جعفر بن إبراهيم بن مهزم، عن أبي مريم، عن الأصبغ بن نباتة، قال: دخلت على أمير المؤمنين (ع) وقدامه شواء، فقال لي: ادن وكل، فقلت: يا أمير المؤمنين هذا لي ضار، فقال لي:
ادن أعلمك كلمات لا يضرك معهن شئ مما تخاف، قال: " بسم الله خير الأسماء، ملا الأرض والسماء، الرحمن الرحيم الذي لا يضر مع اسمه داء " وتغد معنا (1).
58 - باب الرؤوس 453 - عنه، عن علي بن الريان بن الصلت، عن عبيد الله بن عبد الله الواسطي، عن واصل بن سليمان، (أو عن درست) قال: ذكرنا الرؤوس عند أبي عبد الله (ع) والرأس من الشاة، فقال: الرأس موضع الزكاة، وأقرب من المرعى، وأبعد من الأذى (2).
59 - باب [كذا فيما عندي من نسخ الكتاب] 454 - عنه، عن أبيه، عمن حدثه، عن عبد الرحمن العزرمي، عن أبي عبد الله، (ع) قال: كان علي (ع) يكره إدمان اللحم، ويقول: إن له ضراوة كضراوة الخمر. (3)

إن للحم ضراوة كضراوة الخمر أي ان له عادة ينزع إليها كعادة الخمر " وقال الأزهري: " أراد أن له عادة طلابة لاكله كعادة الخمر مع شاربها، ومن اعتاد الخمر وشربها أسرف في النفقة ولم يتركها وكل من اعتاد اللحم لم يكد يصبر عنه فدخل في دأب المسرف في النفقة " (انتهى) وقال الكرماني: " أي عادة نزاعة إلى الخمر يفعل كفعلها ". وأقول: كأن هذه الأخبار محمولة على التقية لأنها موافقة لاخبار المخالفين وطريقة صوفيتهم وقال الشهيد قدس سره في الدروس: " روى كراهية إدمان اللحم وأن له ضراوة كضراوة الخمر، وكراهة تركه أربعين يوما، وأنه يستحب في كل ثلاثة أيام، ولو دام عليه أسبوعين ونحوها لعلة وفى الصوم فلا بأس، ويكره أكله في اليوم مرتين ".

57 - Chapter on Grilled Meat 452 - From him, from Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Saffar, from Musa ibn Umar, from Ja'far ibn Ibrahim ibn Mahzam, from Abi Maryam, from al-Asbagh ibn Nubata, who said: I entered upon Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) and he had grilled meat in front of him. He said to me: Come closer and eat. I said: O Amir al-Mu'minin, this is harmful to me. He said to me:
Come closer, I will teach you words that will not harm you with anything you fear. He said: "In the name of Allah, the best of names, filling the earth and the sky, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful, with whose name no ailment harms." And have lunch with us (1).
58 - Chapter on Heads 453 - From him, from Ali ibn al-Rayyan ibn al-Salt, from Ubayd Allah ibn Abdullah al-Wasiti, from Wasil ibn Sulaiman, (or from Durust) who said: We mentioned heads in the presence of Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), the head of a sheep. He said: The head is the place of purification, and closer to pasture, and further from harm (2).
59 - Chapter [Thus in my copies of the book] 454 - From him, from his father, from someone who told him, from Abd al-Rahman al-Azrami, from Abi Abdullah, (peace be upon him), who said: Ali (peace be upon him) disliked constantly eating meat, and he said: It has an addiction like the addiction of wine (3).

3 - Volume 14, "Chapter on the Virtue of Meat and Fat," (p. 827, line 9), saying after that, "Clarification - It was said in al-Nihaya: 'One is addicted to something, *dari' bil-shay' yadri dariyan wa dirayatan fahuwa darin* if he is accustomed to it. And from it is the hadith of Umar:
Indeed, meat has an addiction like the addiction of wine, meaning that it has a habit that pulls towards it like the habit of wine.' Al-Azhari said: 'He meant that it has a habit of demanding it like the habit of wine with its drinker, and whoever is accustomed to wine and drinks it, squanders on spending and does not leave it, and everyone who is accustomed to meat can hardly be patient without it, so he enters into the habit of the one who squanders in spending' (end quote). Al-Kirmani said: 'Meaning a habit that inclines towards wine, doing as it does.' And I say: As if these reports are based on dissimulation (taqiyya) because they are in agreement with the reports of the opponents and the way of their Sufism. And al-Shahid, may his secret be sanctified, said in al-Durus: 'It was narrated that it is disliked to constantly eat meat and that it has an addiction like the addiction of wine, and it is disliked to leave it for forty days, and it is recommended every three days, even if it lasts for two weeks or so due to illness and during fasting, there is no harm, and it is disliked to eat it twice in a day.'"

455 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن محمد بن أبي عمير، عن الحكم بن مسكين، عن عمار الساباطي قال: سألت أبا عبد الله (ع) من شراء اللحم فقال: في ثلاث، قلت: لنا أضياف وقوم ينزلون بنا وليس يقع منهم موقع اللحم شئ؟ فقال: في كل ثلاث، قلت: لا نجد شيئا أحضر منه، لو ائتدموا بغيره لم يعدوه شيئا فقال: في كل ثلاث (1).
456 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن القاسم بن محمد، عن زكريا بن عمران أبى يحيى، عن إدريس بن عبد الله، قال: كنت عند أبي عبد الله (ع) فذكر اللحم، فقال: كل يوما بلحم، ويوما بلبن، ويوما بشئ آخر (2).
457 - عنه، عن ابن فضال، عن ابن بكير، عن زرارة، عن أبي جعفر، قال:
كان رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله يعجبه الذراع (3).
458 - عنه، عن جعفر بن محمد، عن ابن القداح، عن أبي عبد الله، عن أبيه (ع) قال: سمت اليهودية رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله في ذراع وكان النبي صلى الله عليه وآله يحب الذراع والكتف و يكره الورك لقربها من المبال (4).
459 - عنه، عن علي بن الريان بن الصلت، رفعه قال: قيل لأبي عبد الله (ع):
لم كان رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله يحب الذراع أكثر منه لحبه لأعضاء الشاة؟ - فقال: إن آدم قرب قربانا عن الأنبياء من ذريته، فسمى لكل نبي من ذريته عضوا، وسمى لرسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله الذراع، فمن ثمة كان يحبها ويشتهيها ويفضلها (5).
460 - عنه، عن علي بن الحكم، عن هشام بن سالم، عن أبي عبد الله (ع)، قال:
سألته عن أكل اللحم النئ؟ فقال: هذا طعام السباع (6).
461 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن حماد بن عيسى، عن حريز، عن زرارة عن أبي - جعفر (ع) أن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله نهى أن يوكل اللحم غريضا، وقال: إنما يأكله السباع،

455 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Abi Umair, from al-Hakam ibn Miskeen, from Ammar al-Sabbati, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (a.s.) about buying meat, and he said: "Every three days." I said: "We have guests and people who visit us, and they don't find anything as appealing as meat." He said: "Every three days." I said: "We can't find anything more readily available than meat; if they were to eat anything else with bread, they wouldn't consider it anything." He said: "Every three days." (1)
456 - From him, from his father, from al-Qasim ibn Muhammad, from Zakariya ibn Imran Abi Yahya, from Idris ibn Abdullah, who said: I was with Abu Abdullah (a.s.) when meat was mentioned, and he said: "Eat meat one day, milk one day, and something else one day." (2)
457 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Ibn Bukair, from Zurara, from Abu Jaafar, who said:
The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) liked the forearm. (3)
458 - From him, from Jaafar ibn Muhammad, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Abu Abdullah, from his father (a.s.) who said: A Jewish woman poisoned the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) in a forearm. The Prophet (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) liked the forearm and the shoulder, and disliked the hip because of its proximity to the urinary passage. (4)
459 - From him, from Ali ibn al-Rayyan ibn al-Salt, raising it (the narration), who said: It was said to Abu Abdullah (a.s.):
"Why did the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) love the forearm more than other parts of the sheep?" He said: "Adam offered a sacrifice on behalf of the prophets from his descendants, and he designated a part for each prophet from his descendants. He designated the forearm for the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family). That is why he loved it, desired it, and preferred it." (5)
460 - From him, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Hisham ibn Salim, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.), who said:
I asked him about eating raw meat, and he said: "This is the food of predators." (6)
461 - From him, from his father, from Hammad ibn Issa, from Huraiz, from Zurara, from Abu - Jaafar (a.s.) that the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings be upon him and his family) forbade eating meat raw, and said: "Only predators eat it."

462 - عنه، عن يعقوب بن يزيد، عن ابن فضال، عن القاسم بن محمد، عن العلاء، عن محمد بن مسلم، عن مسمع، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: اتقوا الغدد من اللحم، فلربما حرك عرق الجذام (2).

462 - From him, from Yaqub bin Yazid, from Ibn Faddal, from al-Qasim bin Muhammad, from al-Ala, from Muhammad bin Muslim, from Misma', from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "Beware of the glands in the meat, for they may stir a leprosy vein." (2)
463 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Abi Umair, from Ibrahim bin Abd al-Hamid, from Abi al-Hasan (a.s.) who said: "Seven things are forbidden from the sheep: blood, testicles, penis, the two tendons, spleen, glands, and gallbladder." (3)
464 - From him, from al-Sayari, from Muhammad bin Jumhur al-Ammi, from someone he mentioned, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "Ten things are forbidden from the slaughtered animal, and twelve things are permissible from the dead animal. As for what is forbidden from the slaughtered animal: blood, excrement, glands, spleen, penis, the two tendons, uterus, hoof, horn, and hair. As for what is permissible from the dead animal: hair, wool, fur, canine tooth, horn, molar, hoof, eggs, rennet, nail, claw, and feathers." (4)

60 - Chapter: Gnawing on Bones

492 - From him, from Harun ibn Muslim, from Mas'adah ibn Sadaqah, who said: Ja'far ibn Muhammad narrated to me, from his father, that Ali (a.s.) used to ride the Messenger of Allah's mule, may God bless him and his family, then pass by the fish market and say: "Beware, do not eat or sell what does not have scales (3)."
493 - From him, from Harun ibn Muslim, from Mas'adah ibn Sadaqah, from Ja'far, from his father (a.s.) who said: I heard my father say: "If the owner of the net casts it, then whatever he catches in it, whether alive or dead, is lawful except for what does not have scales, and floating fish should not be eaten (4)."
494 - From him, from Muhammad ibn al-Hamadani, from Mu'attib, who said: Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) said to me one day: "O Mu'attib, find us some fresh fish, for I want to be cupped." So I sought it for him and brought it to him.

(End quote). It may also be interpreted as referring to when it is not known whether it died before or after leaving the water. Al-Shaykh (may God have mercy on him) narrated with a sound chain of narration from Muhammad ibn Muslim, from Abi Ja'far (a.s.), concerning a man who set up a net in the water, then returned to his house and left it set up, then came to it later and some fish had fallen into it and died. At high tide, the fish enter the net, and at low tide, they remain in it and the water goes out of it, so at that time their death is not in the water. Therefore, his saying (a.s.): "What his hand has done" is to clarify that the death in it is like taking by hand, and this is a near and common explanation."

إسماعيل الميثمي، عن يحيى بن ميمون البصري، عن رجل، عن مقسم مولى ابن عباس قال: لما سير ابن الزبير عبد الله بن العباس إلى الطائف زاره محمد بن علي بن الحنفية قال فبينا هو ذات يوم عنده، إذ جئ بالخوان للغداء، فجاء جرادة ضخمة حتى تقع على المائدة، فسمع ابن عباس صوت وقعها، فقال: ما هذا الصوت الذي أسمع؟ - قالوا: جرادة سقطت على المائدة، قال: فمن تناولها؟ - قالوا مقسم، قال: يا مقسم انشر جناحها فانظر ما ذا ترى تحتها؟ - قال: أرى نقطا سوداء، فقال: صدقت، قال: فضرب بيده على فخذ محمد بن علي ، (وكان إلى جنبه) فقال: هل عندكم في هذا شئ؟ - فقال: حدثني أبي، عن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله أنه ليس من جرادة إلا وتحت جناحها مكتوب بالسريانية: " إني أنا الله رب العالمين، قاصم الجبابرة، خلقت الجراد وجعلته جندا من جنودي، أهلك به من شئت من خلقي " قال: فتبسم ابن عباس ثم قال: يا بن عم، هذا والله من مكنون علمنا، فاحتفظ به (1).
503 - عنه، عن أبي أيوب المدايني وغيره، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن عبد الله بن المغيرة، عن رجل، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: الجراد ذكى حيه وميته (2).
504 - عنه، عن أبي طالب عبد الله بن الصلت، عن أنس بن عياض الليثي، عن جعفر، عن أبيه، أن عليا (ع) كان يقول: الجراد ذكى، والحيتان ذكى، فما مات في البحر فهو ميت (3).
505 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن عون بن جرير، عن عمرو بن هارون الثقفي عن أبي - عبد الله (ع) قال: قال أمير المؤمنين (صلوات الله عليه:): الجراد ذكى كله والحيتان ذكى كله، وأما ما هلك في البحر فلا تأكله (4).

Isma'il al-Mithami, from Yahya ibn Maymun al-Basri, from a man, from Miqsam, the freedman of Ibn Abbas, who said: When Ibn al-Zubayr exiled Abdullah ibn Abbas to al-Ta'if, Muhammad ibn Ali ibn al-Hanafiyyah visited him. He said: While he was with him one day, a tray was brought for lunch, and a huge locust came and landed on the table. Ibn Abbas heard the sound of its landing and said: "What is this sound I hear?" They said: "A locust fell on the table." He said: "Who picked it up?" They said: Miqsam. He said: "O Miqsam, spread its wing and see what you see underneath it." He said: "I see black dots." He said: "You are right." Then he struck Muhammad ibn Ali on the thigh (who was next to him) and said: "Do you have any knowledge about this?" He said: "My father told me, from the Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, that there is no locust but underneath its wing is written in Syriac: 'Indeed, I am God, Lord of the Worlds, breaker of the tyrants. I created the locust and made it a host from my hosts, with which I destroy whom I will from my creation.'" He said: Ibn Abbas smiled and then said: "O cousin, this, by God, is from the hidden knowledge we possess, so preserve it" (1).
503 - From him, from Abu Ayyub al-Mada'ini and others, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from Abdullah ibn al-Mughira, from a man, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "The locust is ritually pure, whether alive or dead" (2).
504 - From him, from Abu Talib Abdullah ibn al-Salt, from Anas ibn Iyad al-Laythi, from Ja'far, from his father, that Ali (a.s.) used to say: "The locust is ritually pure, and the fish are ritually pure, but what dies in the sea is dead meat (unlawful to eat)" (3).
505 - From him, from his father, from Awn ibn Jarir, from Amr ibn Harun al-Thaqafi, from Abu - Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) said: "The locust is entirely ritually pure, and the fish is entirely ritually pure, but what dies in the sea, do not eat it" (4).

86 - باب البيض 506 - عنه، عن علي بن الحكم، عن أبيه، عن سعد، عن الأصبغ، عن علي (ع) قال: إن نبيا من الأنبياء شكا إلى الله قلة النسل في أمته، فأمره أن يأمرهم بأكل البيض، ففعلوا، فكثر النسل فيهم (1).
507 - عنه، عن أبي القامس الكوفي ويعقوب بن يزيد، عن القندي، عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: شكا نبي من الأنبياء إلى ربه قلة الولد، فأمره بأكل البيض (2).
508 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي اليقطيني، عن عبيد الله بن عبد الله الدهقان، عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: إن نبيا من الأنبياء شكا إلى الله قلة النسل، فقال له: كل اللحم بالبيض (3).
509 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن أحمد بن النضر، عن عمر بن أبي حسنة الجمال، قال: شكوت إلى أبى الحسن (ع) قلة الولد، فقال: استغفر الله وكل البيض بالبصل (4).
510 - عنه، عن علي بن حسان، عن موسى بن بكر، قال: سمعت أبا الحسن (ع) يقول: أكثروا من البيض فإنه يزيد في الولد (5).
511 - عنه، عن نوح بن شعيب، عن كامل، عن محمد بن إبراهيم الجعفي، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: من عدم الولد فليأكل البيض وليكثر منه (6).
512 - عنه، عن جعفر بن محمد، عن يونس بن مرازم قال: ذكر عند أبي عبد الله (ع) البيض، فقال: " أما إنه خفيف يذهب بقرم اللحم (7).
513 - عنه، عن محمد بن إسماعيل، عن جعفر بن محمد بن حكيم، عن مرازم وزاد في " وليست له غائلة اللحم " (8).
514 - عنه، عن محمد بن عيسى، عن أبيه، عن جده، وهو عن ميسر بن عبد العزيز، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: مخ البيض خفيف، والبياض ثقيل (9).

86 - Chapter on Eggs

506 - From him, from Ali bin al-Hakam, from his father, from Sa'd, from al-Asbagh, from Ali (a.s.) who said: "A prophet among the prophets complained to God about the lack of offspring in his nation, so He commanded him to order them to eat eggs, and they did so, and offspring increased among them." (1)

507 - From him, from Abu al-Qamis al-Kufi and Ya'qub bin Yazid, from al-Qandi, from Abdullah bin Sinan, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "A prophet among the prophets complained to his Lord about the lack of children, so He commanded him to eat eggs." (2)

508 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali al-Yaqtini, from Ubaidullah bin Abdullah al-Dehghan, from Abdullah bin Sinan, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "A prophet among the prophets complained to God about the lack of offspring, so He said to him: 'Eat meat with eggs.'" (3)

509 - From him, from his father, from Ahmad bin al-Nadr, from Umar bin Abi Hasna al-Jamal, who said: "I complained to Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) about the lack of children, so he said: 'Seek forgiveness from God and eat eggs with onions.'" (4)

510 - From him, from Ali bin Hassan, from Musa bin Bakr, who said: "I heard Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) saying: 'Eat plenty of eggs, for they increase offspring.'" (5)

511 - From him, from Nuh bin Shuaib, from Kamel, from Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Ja'fi, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "Whoever lacks children should eat eggs and eat plenty of them." (6)

512 - From him, from Jaafar bin Muhammad, from Yunus bin Marazem who said: "Eggs were mentioned in the presence of Abu Abdullah (a.s.), so he said: 'Indeed, it is light and removes the craving for meat.'" (7)

513 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ismail, from Jaafar bin Muhammad bin Hakim, from Marazem and he added, "And it does not have the harmful effects of meat." (8)

514 - From him, from Muhammad bin Isa, from his father, from his grandfather, and he from Maisar bin Abdul Aziz, from Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "The marrow of the egg is light, and the white is heavy." (9)

'Abd Allah (a.s.) and with Abi al-Hasan al-Awwal (a.s.) in the month of Ramadan, the first thing brought to him was a bowl of *tharid* with vinegar and oil. He would first take three bites from it, then the large bowl (*jafna*) would be brought.
520 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi 'Abd Allah (a.s.) who said: "The most beloved of dyes to the Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, was vinegar and oil, the food of the prophets." (2)
521 - From him, from his father, from one who mentioned it, from Ayyub ibn al-Hurr, from Muhammad ibn 'Ali al-Halabi, who said: "I asked Abu 'Abd Allah (a.s.) about food, and he said: 'You should have vinegar and oil, for it is wholesome.' And 'Ali (a.s.) used to eat it a lot, and I eat it a lot because it is wholesome." (3)
522 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Yunus ibn Ya'qub, from 'Abd al-A'la, who said: "I ate with Abu 'Abd Allah (a.s.), and he said: 'O girl, bring us our known food.' So a bowl containing vinegar and oil was brought, and we ate." (4)
523 - From him, from 'Uthman ibn 'Isa, from Hammad ibn 'Uthman, from Salama al-Qalanisi, who said:
"I entered upon Abi 'Abd Allah (a.s.), and when I spoke, he said: 'Why do I hear your speech has weakened?' - I said: 'My mouth has fallen.' He said: As if that was hard on him, he said: 'So what do you eat?' - I said: 'I eat what is in the house.' 529 - From him, from Yaqub bin Yazid, from Muhammad bin Ubayd Allah Al-Mutahhari, from someone he mentioned, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Olive oil increases sperm (4).

The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: Eat olive oil and anoint yourselves with it, for it is from a blessed tree (5).
531 - From him, from Mansur bin Abbas, from Muhammad bin Abdullah bin Wasi', from Ishaq bin Ismail, from Muhammad bin Yazid, from Abi Dawud Al-Nakha'i, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers (a.s.) who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) said: Anoint yourselves with olive oil and use it as relish, for it is the oil of the virtuous and the relish of the chosen ones. 564 - عنه، عن بكر بن محمد، عن عثيمة أم ولد عبد السلام، قالت: قال أبو عبد الله (ع):

565 - عنه، عن إبراهيم بن محمد الثقفي، عن قتيبة الأعشى، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال:

567 - عنه، عن موسى بن القاسم، عن يحيى بن مساور، عن أبي عبد الله (ع)، وعن صفوان بن يحيى، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: السويق يجرد المرة والبلغم جردا، ويدفع سبعين نوعا من أنواع البلاء (6).
568 - عنه، عن علي بن الحكم، عن النضر بن قرواش الجمال، قال: قال أبو الحسن

569 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن بكر بن محمد الأزدي، عن عثيمة، قالت: قال أبو عبد الله (ع) من شرب السويق أربعين صباحا امتلأ كتفاه قوة (2).

572 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن محمد بن عمرو قال: سمعت أبا الحسن الرضا (ع) يقول: نعم القوت السويق، إن كنت جائعا أمسك، وإن كنت شبعان أهضم طعامك. عنه، عن علي بن جعفر وموسى بن القاسم، عن أبي همام، عن سليمان الجعفري عن أبي - الحسن (ع) مثله (5).
573 - عنه، عن النوفلي، عن السكوني، عن أبي عبد الله، عن آبائه (ع) قال: قال:
إن النبي صلى الله عليه وآله أتى بسويق لوز فيه سكر طبرزد، فقال: هذا طعام المترفين بعدى (6).

" أيش، منحوتة من أي شئ، وقد وقعت في كلام العلماء ".

From Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers (peace be upon them) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) loved milk as a drink. (1) 575 - From him, from Uthman bin Isa, from Khalid bin Nujaih, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said:
Milk is the food of the prophets. (2)
576 - From him, from Ali bin al-Hakam, from al-Rabee bin Muhammad al-Musalami, from Abdullah bin Sulaiman, from Abi Jaafar (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) would not eat food or drink a beverage except that he would say: "O Allah, bless us in it and replace it with something better than it," except for milk, for he would say: "O Allah, bless us in it and increase us in it." (3)
577 - From him, from his father, from Abdullah bin al-Mughira, from Abi al-Hasan (peace be upon him) who said: When the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) drank milk, he would say: "O Allah, bless us in it and increase us in it." From him, from Jaafar bin Muhammad al-Ash'ari, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Abi Abdullah, from his father, from his forefathers (peace be upon them), similar to it. (4) 578 - From him, from his father and Muhammad bin Ismail bin Bazee, from Muhammad bin Yahya al-Khazzar, from Ghiyath bin Ibrahim, from Jaafar, from his forefathers that Ali (peace be upon him) liked to break his fast with milk. (5)
579 - From him, from some of our companions, from the nephew of al-Awza'i, from Mas'ada bin al-Yasa' al-Bahili, from Jaafar, from his father (peace be upon him) who said: Ali (peace be upon him) liked to break his fast with milk. (6)
580 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Abdul Rahman bin Abi Hashim, from Muhammad bin Abi Hamza, from Abi Basir, who said: We ate with Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), and he brought us camel meat, and I thought it was from his offering, so we ate. Then he brought us a bowl of milk, and he drank, then he said: Drink, O Abu Muhammad. So I tasted it and said: What is this, may I be sacrificed for you? He said: It is al-Fitra (the natural disposition). Then he brought us dates, and we ate. (7)

And one of its commentators said: "Iliya (with a madd, and it may be shortened) = Jerusalem, and in the narration there is something omitted, its meaning is: two cups were brought, and it was said to him: Choose whichever you want. So Allah inspired him to choose the milk because of what He, the Most Glorious, wanted of the success of this nation, and Gabriel's (peace be upon him) saying: 'You have attained the Fitra' is said in its meaning several sayings, the most chosen of which is that Allah, the Most High, informed Gabriel (peace be upon him) that the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) if he chose the milk, it would be such and such, and if he chose the wine, it would be such and such, and as for the Fitra, what is meant by it here is Islam and uprightness, and its meaning, and Allah knows best, is that you have chosen the sign of Islam and uprightness, and made milk a sign of that because it is easy, good, apparent, palatable to drinkers, and has a sound outcome, and as for wine, it is the mother of all evils and brings about all kinds of evil in the present and the future" (end). And al-Tibi said: "To the Fitra" that is, which people were created upon, for it includes turning away from what contains harm and corruption, such as wine, which impairs the mind, which invites to all good and deters from all evil, and inclining to what contains benefit free from harm, such as milk" (end). I say that according to these aspects, the meaning is that milk is something blessed, and the Prophet's (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) choice of it was a sign of the Fitra, so it would be a reference to that story because of the narrator's knowledge of it. And I say: this report may have other aspects, the first is that it is what man is nourished with at the beginning of what he desires of food when he comes out of his mother's womb and grows up on it, as if he were created upon it and created from it. The second is that what is meant by it is what is recommended to break the fast with, due to the reports stating the recommendation of breaking the fast with it. The third is that the purpose is to praise that specific milk as being freshly milked. Al-Fayrouzabadi said: "Al-Fitr (with a dammah and two dammahs) = something from the separation of milk that is milked at that time." And he said: He was asked about al-Madhi (pre-ejaculatory fluid) and he said: It is al-Fitr, it was said: The Madhi is likened in its smallness to what is milked in al-Fitr, and it was narrated with a dammah, and its origin is what appears from the milk on the teat of the udder" (end). And it was said: "Al-Fitra = the fresh, recently produced milk." I say: The first is the clearest of the aspects, then they are arranged in closeness and distance." I say: It said in the appendix of Aqrab al-Mawarid:
"Aysh, carved from what thing, and it has occurred in the speech of scholars."

Milk after seminal emission is beneficial; so are fresh milk and honey (1).
584 - From him, from Abi Humam, from Kamel bin Muhammad bin Ibrahim al-Ja'fi, from his father, who said:
Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said: Fresh milk is beneficial for the one who suffers from seminal emission (2).
585 - From him, from al-Sayyari, from Ubaidullah bin Abi Abdullah al-Farsi, from one who mentioned him, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.): He said: A man said to him: I ate milk and it harmed me. Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said: No, by God, it never harms anything, but you ate it with something else, and that which you ate with it harmed you, and you thought that it was from the milk (3).
586 - From him, from Abi Ali Ahmad bin Ishaq, from Abd Salih (a.s.) who said: Whoever eats milk and says: "O God, I eat it according to the desire of the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him and his family," it will not harm him (4).
74 - Chapter on the Milk of Pregnant Camels
587 - From him, from Nuh bin Shuaib, from some of his companions, from Musa bin Abdullah bin al-Hasan, who said: I heard our elders say: The milk of pregnant camels is a cure for every disease and affliction (5).
75 - Chapter on Cow's Milk
588 - From him, from more than one, from Aban bin Uthman, from Zurara, from one of the two (a.s.) who said:
The Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, said: You must drink cow's milk, for it grazes on every tree (6).

75 - باب الجبن 595 - عنه، عن ابن محبوب، عن عند العزيز العبدي، قال قال أبو عبد الله (ع):
الجبن والجوز في كل واحد منهما الشفاء، وإن افترقا كان في كل واحد منهما الداء (1) 596 - عنه، عن ابن محبوب، عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن عبد الله بن سليمان، قال:
سألت أبا جعفر (ع) عن الجبن؟ - فقال: لقد سألتني عن طعام يعجبني، ثم أعطى الغلام دراهم فقال: يا غلام ابتع لي جبنا ودعا بالغداء فتغدينا معه، وأتى بالجبن فقال: كل، فلما فرغ من الغداء قلت: ما تقول في الجبن؟ - قال: أولم ترني أكلت؟ - قلت: بلى ولكني أحب أن أسمعه منك، فقال: سأخبرك عن الجبن وغيره، كل ما يكون فيه حلال وحرام فهو لك حلال حتى تعرف الحرام بعينه فتدعه (2).
597 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن محمد بن سنان، عن أبي الجارود، قال: سألت أبا جعفر (ع) عن الجبن؟ - وقلت له: أخبرني من رأى أنه جعل فيه الميتة فقال: أمن أجل مكان واحد يجعل فيه الميتة حرم في جميع الأرضين؟! إذا علمت أنه ميتة فلا تأكل، وإن لم تعلم فاشتر وبع وكل، والله إني لاعترض السوق فاشترى بها اللحم والسمن والجبن، والله ما أظن كلهم يسمون هذه البربر وهذه السودان (3).
footnote:
١ - ج ١٤، " باب الجبن "، (ص ٨٣٥، س ٦ وص ٨٣٤، س ٢٨ و ٣١). قائلا بعد الحديث الأول: " بيان - في المصباح " الجبن المأكول فيه ثلاث لغات، أجودها سكون الباء، والثانية ضمها للاتباع، والثالثة وهي أقلها التثقيل، ومنهم من يجعل التثقيل من ضرورة الشعر " وقائلا أيضا بعد نقل مضمونه لكن من الكافي بهذه العبارة " إن الجبن والجوز إذا اجتمعا كانا دواء، وإذا افترقا كانا داءا ": " بيان - قد يقال: إن الجوز إنما يصلحه إذا لم يكن مالحا فإنه حينئذ بارد رطب في الثالثة، وأما مالحه فهو حار يابس في الثالثة والجوز حار إما في الثانية أو في الثالثة يابس في الأولى فتزيد غائلته ".
وأيضا نقل الحديث الثاني والثالث في " باب جوامع ما يحل وما يحرم "، (ص ٧٦٩، س ٤ و ١٣) قائلا بعد الأول منهما: " بيان - في القاموس: " الجبن بالضم وبضمتين وكعتل معروف " (انتهى) والظاهر أن السؤال عن الجبن لأن العامة كانوا يتنزهون عنه لاحتمال أن تكون الإنفحة التي يأخذون منها الجبن مأخوذة من ميتة والإنفحة عندنا من المستثنيات من الميتة، فيمكن أن يكون جوابه (ع) على سبيل التنزل أي لو كانت الإنفحة بحكم الميتة لكان يجوز لنا أكل الجبن لعدم العلم باتخاذه منها فكيف وهي لا يجرى فيها حكم الميتة، أو باعتبار نجاستها قبل الغسل على القول بها، أو باعتبار أن المجوس كانوا يعملونها غالبا كما يظهر من بعض الأخبار، وقال في النهاية: " في حديث ابن الحنفية: " كل الجبن عرضا " أي اشتره ممن وجدته ولا تسأل عن عمله من مسلم أو غيره، مأخوذ من عرض الشئ أي ناحيته ". وبعد الثاني منهما: " تبين - اعتراض السوق أن يأتيه و يشترى من أي بائع كان من غير تفحص وسؤال، قال الجوهري: " وخرجوا يضربون الناس عن عرض أي عن شق وناحية كيف ما اتفق: لا يبالون من ضربوا، وقال محمد بن الحنفية: كل الجبن عرضا، قال الأصمعي يعنى اعترض واشتره ممن وجدته ولا تسأل عن عمله، أمن عمل أهل الكتاب أم من عمل المجوس، ويقال: استعرض العرب أي سل من شئت منهم " وفى القاموس: " بربرجيل، والجمع برابرة وهم بالغرب، وأمة أخرى بين الحبوش والزنج يقطعون مذاكير الرجال ويجعلونها مهور نسائهم " (انتهى). ثم إن الخبر يدل على جواز شراء اللحوم وأمثالها من سوق المسلمين ومرجوحية التفحص والسؤال. وقال المحقق (ره) وغيره: " ما يباع في أسواق المسلمين من الذبائح و اللحوم يجوز شراؤه ولا يلزم الفحص عن حاله " وقال في المسالك: " لا فرق في ذلك بين رجل معلوم الاسلام ومجهوله، ولا في المسلم بين كونه ممن يستحل ذبيحة الكتابي وغيره على أصح القولين، علما بعموم النصوص والفتاوى، ومستند الحكم أخبار كثيرة، ومثله ما يوجد بأيديهم من الجلود واعتبر في التحرير كون المسلم ممن لا يستحل ذبائح أهل الكتاب، وهو ضعيف جدا لأن جميع - المخالفين يستحلون ذبائحهم فيلزم على هذا أن لا يجوز أخذه من المخالفين مطلقا والاخبار ناطقة بخلافه، واعلم أنه ليس في كلام الأصحاب ما يعرف به سوق الاسلام من غيره فكأن الرجوع فيه إلى العرف، وفى موثقة إسحاق بن عمار عن الكاظم (ع) أنه قال: " لا بأس بالفرو اليماني فيما صنع في أرض الاسلام قلت له: وإن كان فيها غير أهل الاسلام؟ - قال: إذا كان الغالب عليها المسلمون فلا بأس " وعلى هذا ينبغي أن يكون العمل، وهو غير مناف للعرف أيضا، فيتميز سوق الاسلام بأغلبية المسلمين فيه، سواء كان حاكمهم مسلما وحكمهم نافذا أم لا عملا بالعموم، ولو قيل بالكراهة كان وجها للنهي عنه في الخبر الذي أقل مراتبه الكراهة، وفى الدروس اقتصر على نفى الاستحباب ". أقول: ليس في البحار عبارة " عن عبد الله بن سنان " في سند الحديث الثاني كبعض نسخ المحاسن بخلاف غالب النسخ.

75 - Chapter on Cheese

595 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Abd al-Aziz al-Abdi, who said that Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said: "Cheese and walnuts each contain healing, and if separated, each contains disease." (1)

596 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Abdullah ibn Sinan, from Abdullah ibn Suleiman, who said: "I asked Abu Jaafar (a.s.) about cheese, and he said: 'You have asked me about a food that I like.' Then he gave the boy some dirhams and said: 'Boy, buy me some cheese.' He called for lunch, and we had lunch with him. He brought the cheese and said: 'Eat.' When he finished lunch, I said: 'What do you say about cheese?' He said: 'Did you not see me eat?' I said: 'Yes, but I would like to hear it from you.' He said: 'I will tell you about cheese and other things. Everything in which there is halal and haram is halal for you until you know the haram specifically and leave it.'" (2)

597 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Sinan, from Abu al-Jarud, who said: "I asked Abu Jaafar (a.s.) about cheese, and I said to him: 'Inform me if someone saw that carrion was put in it.' He said: 'Is it because of one place where carrion is put in it that it is forbidden in all the lands?! If you know that it is carrion, then do not eat it, and if you do not know, then buy, sell, and eat. By God, I go to the market and buy meat, ghee, and cheese, and by God, I do not think they all mention these Berbers and these Sudanese.'" (3)
---

T Footnote:
---
1 - J 14, "Chapter on Cheese," (p. 835, l. 6 and p. 834, l. 28 and 31). Saying after the first hadith: "Explanation - In al-Misbah: 'The edible cheese has three forms, the best of which is with a silent ba, the second is with a damma for following, and the third, which is the least, is with tashdid, and some of them make the tashdid necessary for poetry.'" And also saying after transmitting its meaning but from al-Kafi with this phrase: "If cheese and walnuts are combined, they are medicine, and if they are separated, they are a disease": "Explanation - It may be said that walnuts only improve it if it is not salty, for then it is cold and moist in the third degree, but salty walnuts are hot and dry in the third degree, and walnuts are hot, either in the second or third degree, dry in the first, thus increasing its harm."
Also, the second and third hadiths are transmitted in "Chapter on Compilations of What is Permissible and What is Forbidden," (p. 769, l. 4 and 13), saying after the first of them: "Explanation - In al-Qamus: 'Al-jubn with a damma and two dammas is well known' (end). It is apparent that the question about cheese is because the common people were avoiding it due to the possibility that the rennet from which the cheese is taken is taken from carrion, and rennet is one of the exceptions to carrion for us. So, his answer (a.s.) may be by way of concession, i.e., even if the rennet were considered carrion, it would be permissible for us to eat the cheese due to lack of knowledge that it was made from it. So how could it not be when it does not fall under the ruling of carrion? Or considering its impurity before washing, according to the saying about it, or considering that the Magians were often making it, as appears from some reports. And it says in al-Nihayah: 'In the hadith of Ibn al-Hanafiyyah: "Eat cheese 'ardan," i.e., buy it from whomever you find and do not ask about its making from a Muslim or non-Muslim, taken from 'ard al-shay', i.e., its side.'" And after the second of them: "Clarification - 'I'tirad al-suq' is to come to it and buy from any seller without investigation or questioning. Al-Jawhari said: 'And they went out striking the people 'an 'ard, i.e., from a side and direction as it happened: not caring who they struck.' And Muhammad ibn al-Hanafiyyah said: 'Eat cheese 'ardan.' Al-Asma'i said, meaning intercept and buy it from whomever you find and do not ask about its making, whether from the work of the People of the Book or from the work of the Magians. And it is said: 'Ista'rad al-'Arab,' i.e., ask whomever you wish from them." And in al-Qamus: "'Berber: Jil, and the plural is Barabirah, and they are in the West, and another nation between the Abyssinians and the Zanj who cut off the penises of men and make them the dowries of their women' (end). Then the report indicates the permissibility of buying meats and the like from the market of the Muslims and the discouragedness of investigation and questioning. And al-Muhaqqiq (may God have mercy on him) and others said: 'What is sold in the markets of the Muslims of slaughtered animals and meats, it is permissible to buy it, and it is not necessary to investigate its condition.' And it says in al-Masalik: 'There is no difference in that between a man known to be a Muslim and one unknown, nor in the Muslim between being one who deems the slaughter of the People of the Book permissible or not according to the more correct of the two opinions, knowing the generality of the texts and fatwas, and the basis of the ruling is numerous reports. And likewise is what is found in their hands of hides, and it is considered in al-Tahrir that the Muslim is one who does not deem the slaughter of the People of the Book permissible, and it is very weak, because all of the opponents deem their slaughter permissible, so it is necessary according to this that it is not permissible to take it from the opponents absolutely, and the reports are clear to the contrary. And know that there is nothing in the words of the companions by which the market of Islam is known from other than it, so it is as if the return in it is to custom. And in the reliable report of Ishaq ibn Ammar from al-Kazim (a.s.) that he said: 'There is no harm in the Yemeni furs in what is made in the land of Islam.' I said to him: 'Even if there are non-Muslims in it?' He said: 'If the Muslims are predominant over it, then there is no harm.' And according to this, the practice should be, and it is not contrary to custom either, so the market of Islam is distinguished by the predominance of Muslims in it, whether their ruler is a Muslim and their ruling is effective or not, acting on the generality, and if it were said that it is disliked, it would be a reason for the prohibition of it in the report, the lowest levels of which is dislike, and in al-Durus it is limited to negating recommendation.'" I say: There is no phrase "from Abdullah ibn Sinan" in the chain of transmission of the second hadith in some copies of al-Mahasin, unlike most copies.

80 - باب السمن 605 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن المطلب بن زياد، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: نعم الادام السمن (1).
606 - عنه، عن أبيه، عمن ذكره، عن أبي حفص الابار، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال:

80 - Chapter on Ghee 605 - From him, from his father, from al-Muttalib bin Ziyad, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "The best condiment is ghee." (1).
606 - From him, from his father, from one who mentioned it, from Abi Hafs al-Abbar, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "Ghee is what enters the stomach of one like me, and I dislike it for the elderly." (2).
607 - From him, from al-Washsha', from Hammad bin Uthman, who said: I was with Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) when an old man from the people of Iraq spoke to him and said: "Why do I see your speech changing?" Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "Some of my teeth have also fallen out, so much so that Satan whispers to me and says: 'If the rest go, what will you eat with?' - So I say: 'There is no might nor power except with God.'" Then he said to him: "You must eat Tharid (bread soaked in broth), for it is good, and avoid ghee, for it does not suit the elderly." (3).
608 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah, from his father, from Ali (peace be upon him) who said: "Cow's ghee is a cure." From him, from Abdullah bin Shuaib, from Abi Basir, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) similarly (4).
609 - From him, from his father, from one who mentioned it, from Abi Hafs al-Abbar, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers, from Ali (peace be upon him) who said: "Cow's ghee is a medicine." (5).

And in al-Masabih: "السُكَّر (al-sukkar) is well-known." Some said: "The first to be made was tabarzad, and for this reason it is said *sukkar tabarzadi*." And he said: "طبرزد (Tabarzad)" with the weight of "سفرجل (safarjal)" is an arabized word, and it has three forms: with a *dhal* with a dot, a *nun*, and a *lam*. And al-Azhari narrated the *nun* and *lam* and did not narrate the *dhal*. And Ibn al-Jawaliqi said: "Its origin in Persian is "تبرزد (tabarzad) and التبر (al-tabar) = the ax, as if it is cut from its sides with an ax, so according to this, tabarzad is an adjective following the sugar in - *al-i'rab*, so it is said: "هو سكر طبرزد (it is tabarzad sugar)." And some people said: "Tabarzad is the white sugar." And Ibn al-Bitar said: "Tabarzad is arabized, meaning that it is solid, neither loose nor soft." And he said: "طبرزد salt is the solid one that has no clarity." (End quote). And I say: It appears from some of their words that tabarzad is what is known as نبات (*nabat*), and from most of them that it is قند (*qand*). Al-Baghdadi said in his الجامع (*al-Jami'*) "Sugar is hot in the early second degree and moist in the first degree, and it may be refined repeatedly and different colors are made from it, so the purest, most transparent, and clearest of it is called نبات (*nabat*) by convention, and below this, which is coarsely ground, rough, pure, and not transparent, is الأبلوج (*al-abluj*), and below that, which is the عصیر (*'asir*), is called القلم (*al-qalam*) because it is cut elongated like fingers, and *nabat* is less hot, followed by *al-abluj*, followed by *al-qalam*, followed by the cooked juice, and the finest of them is *nabat*, then *al-abluj*, then *al-qalam*, the slightly white one, and the solid *al-abluj* is called tabarzad."

83 - (Chapters on Grains) Chapter on Rice 626 - From him, from his father, from Uthman bin Isa, from someone who informed him, from Abi Abdullah (as) who said: "Yes, rice is a good food, and we store it for our sick."
627 - From him, from Ali bin al-Hakam and Ibn Faddal, from Yunus bin Yaqoub, who said: Abu Abdullah (as) said: "Nothing comes to us from your area that is more beloved to me than rice and violets. I complained of that severe pain, and I was inspired to eat rice, so I ordered it to be washed, dried, then fried and ground. Then it was made for me into a dry powder with oil and a decoction which I sipped, and Allah removed that pain with it."
628 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Yunus bin Yaqoub, from some of his companions, from Abi Abdullah (as) who said: "I was sick for two years or more, and Allah inspired me to use rice, so I ordered it to be washed and dried, then exposed to the fire and ground, and I made some of it into a dry powder and some into soup."
629 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Sinan, from Huthaifa bin Mansur, from Abi Abdullah (as) who said: "I was afflicted with a stomach ailment, and my flesh wasted away and I became very weak. It was cast into my mind to take rice and wash it, then fry it and grind it, then make it into a soup. My flesh grew back because of it, and my bones were strengthened by it." He said: "The people of Medina still come and say: O Abu Abdullah, let us benefit from what the Iraqis used to send to you, so I sent some of it to them."

630 - From him, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from Hisham bin Salim, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "I fell severely ill and suffered from diarrhea, which wasted my body. I was instructed to fry rice, then grind it into *sawiq*. I consumed it, and my body regained its strength." (1)
631 - From him, from his father, from Al-Nadr bin Suwaid, from Muhammad bin Ismail, from Muhammad bin Marwan, who said: "I was with Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) and he had severe diarrhea. I left him in the evening being one of the most worried people about him. I came to him the next day and found that his condition had subsided. I said to him: May I be sacrificed for you, I left you yesterday evening with such an illness? - He said: I was instructed to take some rice, wash it, dry it, grind it, and then ingest it dry. This strengthened my stomach.” (2)
632 - From him, from Uthman bin Isa, from Khalid bin Najih, who said: Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "My stomach ached, and someone said to me: 'Take rice, wash it, then dry it in the shade, then crush it and take a handful of it every morning.'" Ishaq al-Jurairi added to it: "Fry it a little.” (3)
633 - From him, from Ibn Suleiman al-Hadhdha', from Muhammad bin al-Faydh, who said: "I was with Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) when a man came to him and said: 'My daughter has withered and suffers from diarrhea.' He said: 'What prevents you from using rice with fat?! Take four or five stones and place them under the fire, and put the rice in the pot and cook it until it is ready. Take fresh kidney fat, and when the rice is cooked, put the fat in a bowl with the stones and cover it with another bowl, then shake it vigorously and hold it tight so that its steam does not escape. When the fat has melted, put it in the rice and sip it.” (4)

85 - باب الحمص 643 - عنه، عن أحمد بن أبي نصر، عن أبي الحسن الرضا (ع) قال: الحمص جيد لوجع الظهر، وكان يدعو به قبل الطعام وبعده (2).
644 - عنه، عن نوح بن شعيب، عن نادر الخادم، قال: كان أبو الحسن الرضا (ع) يأكل الحمص المطبوخ قبل الطعام وبعده (3).
645 - عنه، عن بعض أصحابنا، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن معاوية بن عمار، قال: قلت لأبي عبد الله (ع): إن الناس يروون أن النبي صلى الله عليه وآله قال: " إن العدس بارك عليه سبعون نبيا " قال: هو الذي تسمونه عندكم الحمص، ونحن نسميه العدس (4).
646 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن فضالة بن أيوب، عن رفاعة بن موسى، قال: سمعت أبا - عبد الله (ع) يقول: إن الله لما عافى أيوب (ع) نظر إلى بني إسرائيل قد ازدرعت، فرفع طرفه إلى السماء فقال: الهى وسيدي أيوب عبدك المبتلى الذي عافيته، ولم يزدرع شيئا، وهذا لبنى إسرائيل زرع، فأوحى الله يا أيوب خذ من سبحتك أكفا فابذره، وكانت لأيوب سبحة فيها ملح فأخذ أيوب أكفا منها، فبذره، فخرج هذا العدس، وأنتم تسمونه الحمص، ونحن نسميه العدس (5).

Abu Abdullah was eating lentil soup, and I said: May I be your ransom, these people say that eighty prophets have sanctified lentils? He said: They lie, no, by God, not even twenty prophets. And it was narrated that it softens the heart and quickens the tears in the eyes (1).
85 - Chapter on Chickpeas
643 - From him, from Ahmad bin Abi Nasr, from Abi Al-Hasan Al-Ridha (peace be upon him) who said: Chickpeas are good for back pain, and he would ask for them before and after meals (2).
644 - From him, from Nuh bin Shuaib, from Nader the servant, who said: Abu Al-Hasan Al-Ridha (peace be upon him) would eat cooked chickpeas before and after meals (3).
645 - From him, from some of our companions, from Ibn Abi Umair, from Muawiyah bin Ammar, who said: I said to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him): People narrate that the Prophet, may God bless him and his family, said: "Seventy prophets blessed lentils." He said: That is what you call chickpeas, and we call it lentils (4).
646 - From him, from his father, from Fadala bin Ayyub, from Rifa'a bin Musa, who said: I heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) say: When God healed Job (peace be upon him), he looked at the Children of Israel who had sown crops, so he raised his gaze to the sky and said: My God and Master, Job is your afflicted servant whom you have healed, and he has not sown anything, and this is a crop for the Children of Israel. So God revealed to him: O Job, take handfuls from your rosary and sow it. Job had a rosary containing salt, so Job took handfuls of it and sowed it, and these lentils came out, which you call chickpeas, and we call lentils (5).

Chapters on Vegetables 87 - Chapter 651 - From him, from Sahl bin Ziyad, who said: Ahmad bin Harun narrated to me, from Muwaffaq al-Madini, from his father, who said: Al-Madi (a.s.) sent for me one day and kept me for lunch. When they brought the table, there were no vegetables on it. He held back his hand and then said to the servant: "Didn't you know that I don't eat at a table that doesn't have greens on it? Bring me the greens." He said: The servant went and brought the vegetables and put them on the table, and he stretched out his hand and ate (1).
652 - From him, from several of our companions, from Hanan, who said: I was with Abu Abdullah (a.s.) at the table, and he leaned towards the vegetables, and I refrained from them because of an ailment I had. He turned to me and said: "O Hanan, didn't you know that Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) was never brought a plate or breakfast unless it had vegetables on it?" I said: "Why is that, may I be made your ransom?" He said: "Because the hearts of the believers are green, so they yearn for their forms (2)."
88 - Chapter on Chicory 653 - From him, from Abu Abdullah al-Sayari, from Ahmad bin al-Fadl, from Muhammad bin Saeed, from Abu Jamila, from Jabir, from Abu Jaafar (a.s.) who said: "Chicory is a tree at the gate of Paradise (3)."
654 - From him, from his father, from someone who narrated to him, from Abu Hafs al-Abbar, from Abu Abdullah, from his forefathers, from Ali (a.s.) who said: "You must have chicory, for it came out of Paradise (4)."

Leeks are from al-Misharah, meaning al-Dibrah. He washes it with water and eats it (1).
686 - From him, from al-Washsha', from Ibn Sinan, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (a.s.) about leeks. He said: There is no harm in eating them cooked or uncooked, but if one eats something from it that is offensive, then he should not go to the mosque for fear of offending those who sit with him (2).

الأول يقطع الكراث بأصوله فيغسله بالماء فيأكله (1).
691 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن وهب بن وهب، عن جعفر بن محمد، عن آبائه (ع) قال: ذكر البقول عند رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله فقال: سنام البقول ورأسها الكراث، وفضله على البقول كفضل الخبز على سائر الأشياء، وفيه بركة، وهي بقلتي وبقلة الأنبياء قبلي، وأنا أحبه وآكله، وكأني أنظر إلى نباته في الجنة يبرق ورقه خضرة وحسنا (2).
692 - عنه، عن إبراهيم بن عقبة الخزاعي، عن يحيى بن سليمان، قال: رأيت أبا الحسن الرضا (ع) بخراسان في روضة وهو يأكل الكراث، فقلت له: جعلت فداك، إن الناس يروون أن الهندبا يقطر عليه كل يوم قطرة من الجنة، فقال: إن كان الهندبا يقطر عليه قطرة من الجنة، فإن الكراث منغمس في الماء في الجنة، قلت: فإنه يسمد، فقال: لا يعلق به شئ (3).
693 - عنه، عن بعض أصحابنا، عن حنان بن سدير، قال: كنت مع أبي عبد الله (ع) على المائدة، فملت على الهندبا، فقال لي: يا حنان لم لا تأكل الكراث؟ - فقلت: لما جاء عنكم من الرواية في الهندبا، قال: وما الذي جاء عنا فيه؟ - قال: قلت: إنه يقطر عليه قطرات من الجنة في كل يوم، قال: فقال لي: فعلى الكراث إذا سبع، قلت: فكيف آكله؟ - قال: اقطع أصوله، واقذف رؤوسه (4).
90 - باب الباذروج 694 - عنه، عن علي بن حسان، عمن حدثه، عن السكوني، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: كأني أنظر إلى نبات الباذروج في الجنة، قال: قلت له: الهندبا؟ - قال: لا، بل الباذروج (5).

The first cuts the leek with its roots, washes it with water, and eats it (1).
691 - From him, from his father, from Wahb bin Wahb, from Ja'far bin Muhammad, from his forefathers (peace be upon them) who said: Vegetables were mentioned in the presence of the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family), and he said: "The choicest and best of vegetables is the leek, and its superiority over other vegetables is like the superiority of bread over all other things. There is blessing in it, and it is my vegetable and the vegetable of the prophets before me, and I love it and eat it, and I see its growth in Paradise, its leaves gleaming with greenery and beauty (2)."
692 - From him, from Ibrahim bin Uqba al-Khuza'i, from Yahya bin Sulaiman, who said: I saw Abu al-Hasan al-Ridha (peace be upon him) in Khurasan in a garden, and he was eating leek. I said to him: "May I be sacrificed for you, people narrate that chicory receives a drop from Paradise every day." He said: "If chicory receives a drop from Paradise, then leek is immersed in the water of Paradise." I said: "But it is fertilized." He said: "Nothing sticks to it (3)."
693 - From him, from some of our companions, from Hanan bin Sudair, who said: I was with Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) at the table, and I leaned towards the chicory. He said to me: "O Hanan, why don't you eat leek?" I said: "Because of what has come from you in the narration about chicory." He said: "And what has come from us about it?" I said: "That it receives drops from Paradise every day." He said: "Then the leek receives seven." I said: "How do I eat it?" He said: "Cut off its roots and discard its heads (4)."
90 - Chapter on Basil (Bādhruj)
694 - From him, from Ali bin Hassan, from someone who narrated to him, from al-Sakuni, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "I see the growth of basil in Paradise." He said: "I said to him: 'Chicory?'" He said: "No, but basil (5)."
695 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Isa bin Abdullah al-Alawi, from his father, from his grandfather, from Ali (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace be upon him) looked at the basil and said: "This is sweet basil (al-ḥawk), I see its growth in Paradise (6)."
696 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Amr bin Uthman, from Ahmad bin Zakaria al-Kisa'i

From al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers (peace be upon them), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "It is as if I am looking at the growth of sweet basil in Paradise." I said to him: "Endive?" He said: "No, but sweet basil." (1)
697 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from al-Hajjal, from Issa bin al-Walid, from al-Shu'airi, who said: "The most beloved of the greens to the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) was sweet basil." (2)
698 - From him, from his father, from Ahmad bin Suleiman, from his father, from Abi Basir, who said: "A man asked Aba Abdullah (peace be upon him) about greens while I was with him, and he said: 'Sweet basil is ours.'" And Muhammad bin Ali narrated it, from Wuhaib bin Hafs, from Abi Basir. (3)
699 - From him, from Ismail bin Mehran, from Ali bin Abi Hamza, from Abi Basir, from one of them (peace be upon them), who said: "Sweet basil is ours." (4)
770 - From him, from Jaafar bin Muhammad al-Ahwal, from Ali bin Abi Hamza, who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "From the greens, sweet basil is ours." (5)
701 - From him, from Muhammad bin Issa al-Yaqtini or others, from Qutaiba bin Mehran, from Hammad bin Zakariya al-Nakhai, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "It is as if I am looking at its tree growing in Paradise." (6)
702 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: Ali (peace be upon him) said: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) admired rue among the greens." He said: And Aba Abdullah (peace be upon him) was asked about rue, and he said:
"It is loved by people, except that it causes flatulence, and worms rush to it, and it is sweet basil." (7)

"You should eat lettuce, for it purifies the blood." (8)

732 - عنه، عن أبيه، عمن حدثه، عن موسى بن جعفر، عن أبيه، عن جده (ع) قال: كان فيما أوصى به رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله عليا (ع) أن قال: يا علي عليك بالدباء فكله، فإنه يزيد في العقل والدماغ (2) 732 - عنه، عن النوفلي، عن السكوني، عن أبي عبد الله، عن آبائه، (ع) أن النبي صلى الله عليه وآله كان يعجبه من القدور الدباء (3).
734 - عنه، عن ابن فضال، عن ابن القداح، عن جعفر، عن أبيه، قال: قال علي (ع):
كان يعجب رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله من المرقة الدباء. وباسناده قال: كان رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله يعجبه الدباء ويلتقطه من الصحفة (4).
735 - عنه، عن جعفر بن محمد الأشعري، عن ابن القداح، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: كان رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله يعجبه الدباء وهو القرع (5).
736 - عنه، عن السياري، يرفعه إلى النبي صلى الله عليه وآله أنه كان يعجبه الدباء، وكان يأمر نساءه فيقول: إذا طبختن قدرا فأكثروا فيها من الدباء وهو القرع (6).

101 - Chapter on Onions
737 - From him, from his father, from Ahmad ibn al-Nadr, from Amr ibn Shimr, from Jabir, who said that Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "Onions eliminate fatigue, strengthen the nerves, increase semen and walking ability, and eliminate fever." (1)

738 - From him, from al-Sayyari, from Ahmad Khalid, from Ahmad ibn al-Mubarak al-Dinawari, from Abu Uthman, from Durust, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "Onions freshen the mouth, strengthen the back, and refine the skin." (2)

739 - From him, from Mansur ibn al-Abbas, from Abd al-Aziz ibn Hassan al-Baghdadi, from Salih ibn Uqba, from Abdullah ibn Muhammad al-Ju'fi, who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) mentioned onions and said: "They freshen the breath, eliminate phlegm, and increase sexual potency." And in another hadith, he said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "Eat onions, for they have three qualities: they freshen the breath, strengthen the gums, and increase semen." (3)

740 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Ali, from Muhammad ibn al-Fudail, from Abd al-Rahman ibn Yazid ibn Aslam, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: "When you enter a town, eat of its onions, for it will ward off its epidemic from you."

103 - باب الثوم 744 - عنه، عن عثمان بن عيسى، عن عبد الله بن مسكان، عن الحسن الزيات قال: لما أن قضيت نسكي مررت بالمدينة، فسألت عن أبي جعفر (ع) فقالوا: هو بينبع فأتيت ينبع، فقال: يا حسن أتيتني إلى ههنا؟ - قلت: نعم، جعلت فداك، كرهت أن أخرج ولا ألقاك، فقال: إني أكلت هذه البقلة (يعنى الثوم)، فأردت أن أتنحى عن مسجد رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله (4).
745 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن فضالة، عن داود بن فرقد، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: من أكل هذه البقلة فلا يقرب مسجدنا ولم يقل: إنه حرام (5).
