And I ask You to decree good for me by Your power over it, for You are able and I am not, You know and I do not know, and You are the Knower of the unseen. O Allah, whatever matter is closest to Your obedience and furthest from Your disobedience, and most pleasing to Yourself, and most fulfilling to Your right, then make it easy for me and make me easy for it. And whatever is other than that, then turn it away from me and turn me away from it, for You are Kind and Capable of that (1).
11 - From him, from Uthman bin Isa, who said: Amr bin Shimr narrated to us, from Jabir, from Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him), who said: Ali bin Al-Hussein (peace be upon him) would, whenever he intended to do something like Hajj or Umrah or buying or selling or freeing a slave, perform ablution and then say: "O Allah, if such and such is good for me in my religion, and good for me in my world and my Hereafter, and for my immediate and future affairs, then make it easy for me. Lord, resolve me to my righteousness, even if I dislike it and my soul refuses it (2)."
12 - From him, from a number of our companions, from Ali bin Asbat, who said: Someone narrated to me that Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) said to him: "When I want to seek guidance in a great matter, I seek guidance from Allah in the sitting position one hundred times, and if it is buying a head (of livestock) or something similar, I seek guidance three times in the sitting position, saying: 'O Allah, I ask You by virtue of Your being the Knower of the seen and the unseen, if You know that such and such is good for me, then decree it for me and make it easy. And if You know that it is evil for me in my religion, my world, and my Hereafter, then turn it away from me to what is better for me, and make me content with Your decree in that, for You know and I do not know, You are able and I am not, and You decree and I do not decree. Indeed, You are the Knower of the unseen (3).'"
13, From him, from a number of our companions, from Ali bin Asbat, who raised it to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: "You say in seeking guidance: 'I seek guidance from Allah, and I ask Allah to decree good, and I put my trust in Allah, and there is no might nor power except with Allah. I intended a matter, so I ask my God if that is pleasing to Him to fulfill my need, and if it is displeasing to Him to turn me away from it, and to guide me to His pleasure (4)."
3 - Chapter on Seeking Counsel 14 - From him, from Ja'far bin Muhammad al-Ash'ari, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Ja'far bin Muhammad, from his father (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah, peace and blessings be upon him and his family, was asked: "What is prudence?" He said: "Consulting those with sound judgment and following them (5)."

(1)

16 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad bin Sinan, from Abi al-Jarud, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) who said: In the Torah are four lines: "He who does not consult will regret, poverty is the greatest death, as you judge you will be judged, and he who rules monopolizes." (2)

17 - From him, from Musa bin al-Qasim, from his grandfather Muawiya Wahb, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "Consult in your affairs those who fear their Lord." (3)

18 - From him, from Uthman bin Isa, from Sama'a bin Mehran, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "No man will perish after consultation." (4)

19 - From him, from his father, from the one who mentioned it, from al-Hussein bin al-Mukhtar, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Ali (a.s.) said in a statement of his: "Consult in your conversation those who fear Allah." (5)

20 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Abdullah bin Sinan, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: A man came to the Commander of the Believers, Ali (a.s.) and said to him: "I have come to you seeking counsel. Al-Hasan (a.s.), al-Hussein (a.s.), and Abdullah bin Jaafar (may Allah be pleased with them) have proposed to my daughter." So the Commander of the Believers (a.s.) said: "The consultant is trusted. As for al-Hasan, he divorces women frequently, but marry her to al-Hussein, for he is better for your daughter." (6)

21 - From him, from his father, from Muammar bin Khallad, who said: A freed slave of Abi al-Hasan al-Ridha (a.s.), named Sa'd, died. So he (a.s.) said: "Advise me about a man who has virtue and trustworthiness." I said: "Am I to advise you?!" So he said in a manner resembling anger: "The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) used to consult his companions and then decide on what he wanted." (7)

23 - From him, from several of our companions, from Ali ibn Asbat, from al-Hasan ibn al-Jahm, who said: We were with Abu al-Hasan al-Ridha (peace be upon him) and we mentioned his father (peace be upon him), so he said: "His intellect could not be weighed against other intellects. And he would sometimes consult the black people from his Sudanese." So it was said to him: "You consult someone like this?!" He said: "Indeed, Allah, Blessed and Exalted is He, sometimes opens his tongue." He said: "So they would sometimes suggest something to him, and he would act upon it regarding the estate and the garden." (1)

24 - From him, from Abu Abdullah al-Jamurani, from al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn Abi Hamza, from Sandal, from Ibn Miskan, from Sulaiman ibn Khalid, who said: I heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) say: "Consult the wise man from among the men, the pious, for he only commands good. And beware of disagreement, for disagreeing with the pious, wise man is a corruption in religion and this world." (2)

25 - From him, from al-Jamurani, from al-Hussein ibn Ali, from Saif ibn Umayra, from Mansur ibn Hazim, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Consultation with the wise, sincere advisor is guidance, blessing, and success from Allah. So when the sincere, wise advisor advises you, beware of disagreement, for in that is destruction." (3)

26 - From him, from al-Jamurani, from al-Hasan ibn Ali ibn Abi Hamza, from al-Hussein ibn Ali, from al-Mu'alla from Khunais, who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "What prevents one of you, when wealth comes to him that he cannot manage, from consulting a man who is wise, religious, and pious?!" Then Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: "Indeed, if he does that, Allah will not forsake him, but rather Allah will raise him and guide him to the best of matters and the closest of them to Allah." (4)

27 - From him, from some of our companions, from al-Hussein ibn Hazim, from Hussein ibn Umar ibn Yazid, from his father, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "Whoever consults his brother and he does not advise him with pure opinion, Allah will take away his opinion." (5)

28 - From him, from Ahmad ibn Nuh, from Shuaib al-Naysaburi, from Ubaidullah ibn Abdullah al-Dihqan, from Ahmad ibn A'idh, from al-Halabi, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: "Indeed, consultation is only with its limits. Whoever knows it with its limits, otherwise its harm to the one consulting is greater than its benefit to him. The first of them is that the one who is consulted must be wise, the second is that he must be free and religious, and the third is that he must be a friend."

And the fourth is that he is privy to your secret, so his knowledge of it is like your knowledge of yourself, then he conceals it and keeps it secret. 4 - Chapter on Casting Lots

29 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Jamil bin Salih, from Fudail bin Yasar, who said: I asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a newborn who has neither the characteristics of men nor women. He said: "The Imam casts lots for him, writing on one arrow 'Abdullah (Servant of Allah)' and on another arrow 'Amatullah (Maidservant of Allah).' Then the Imam or the one casting the lots says: 'O Allah, You are Allah, there is no god but You, Knower of the unseen and the seen. You will judge between Your servants on the Day of Resurrection concerning that in which they used to differ. Make clear to us the matter of this newborn so that we may bequeath to him what You have prescribed for him in Your Book.'" He said: Then the two arrows are thrown into a set of ambiguous arrows, then they are shuffled, and whichever one comes out, he is inherited upon it (2).

30 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Jamil bin Salih, from Mansur bin Hazim, who said: Some of our companions asked Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) about a question, and he said to him: "This is to be decided by drawing lots." Does not Allah, Blessed and Exalted, say: 'So he drew lots and was among the losers' (3)."

33 - عنه، عن محمد بن عيسى، عن بعض أصحابه رفعه قال: قال أبو عبد الله (ع) لا يستغنى المؤمن عن خصلة وبه الحاجة إلى ثلاث خصال، توفيق من الله عز وجل، وواعظ من نفسه، وقبول ممن ينصحه (2).
تم كتاب المنافع بحمد الله ومنه وحسن توفيقه، وصلى الله على محمد النبي وآله وسلم تسليما كثيرا.

From Salih, who said: Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) said: Follow the one who makes you weep while being a sincere advisor to you, and do not follow the one who makes you laugh while deceiving you. You will all return to Allah together, and then you will know (1).
33 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Isa, from some of his companions, raising it [in authority], who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: The believer cannot dispense with one characteristic, and he is in need of three characteristics: success from Allah, the Mighty and Sublime, a monitor from himself, and acceptance from the one who advises him (2).
The Book of Benefits is completed with the praise, grace, and excellent success of Allah, and may Allah bless Muhammad the Prophet and his family and grant them much peace.

In the name of God, the Most Gracious, the Most Merciful. 1 - Chapter on Construction. 1 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Abi 'Umayr, from Hisham ibn al-Hakam, from Abu 'Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: "Whoever earns wealth unlawfully, construction, mud, and water will be imposed upon him." 2 - From him, from Abu Yusuf Ya'qub ibn Yazid, from Sulayman ibn Abi Shaykh, who traced it back (yarfa'uh) who said:
The Commander of the Believers (peace be upon him) passed by the door of a man who had built it of baked brick and said: "Whose door is this?" - It was said: "It belongs to the deluded so-and-so." 3 - From him, from his father, from Safwan, from Abi Jumayla, from Humayd al-Sayrafi, from Abu 'Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: "Every building that is not sufficient (bikafaf) is a burden upon its owner on the Day of Resurrection." And some narrate it as corruption (bifasad). (3)
4 - From him, from his father, from Abu Yusuf, from Ibn Abi 'Umayr, from a man, from Abu 'Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: "Whoever builds above his dwelling will be burdened with carrying it on the Day of Resurrection." (4)
5 - From him, from Ibn Abi 'Umayr, from someone who mentioned it, from Abu 'Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: "Whoever builds and is moderate in his construction will not be rewarded." (5)
6 - From him, from his father, from Abdullah ibn al-Fadl al-Nawfali, from Ziyad ibn Umar al-Ju'fi, from someone who narrated to him, from Abu 'Abd Allah (peace be upon him) who said: "God has assigned an angel to construction who says to whoever raises a roof above eight cubits: 'Where do you intend to go, you transgressor?!'" 22 - From him, from his father in a mursal hadith, who said: Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: Part of a Muslim's happiness is a spacious dwelling. From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers (a.s.), from the Prophet (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family), similarly (1).

26 - From him, from Sulaiman, from his father, from al-Mufaddal, that Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) was praised.
And Bishr said: Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) was in the Sacred Mosque in the circle of Bani Hashim, and in it was al-Abbas ibn Muhammad and others, and they discussed the life of this world, and each of them mentioned a meaning. Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) was asked, and he said: Spaciousness in the house and abundance in servants (5).
27 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Isa, from Mu'ammar ibn Khallad, who said: Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) bought a house and ordered a mawla of his to move to it, and said: Your house is cramped. He said: This house is sufficient for my father. Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) said: If your father was foolish, do you want to be like him?! (6).
28 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Ismail, from Ibrahim ibn Abi al-Bilad, from Ali ibn Abi al-Mughira, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) who said: Part of the misery of life is a cramped house. And Yahya ibn Ibrahim narrated it, from his father (a.s.) (7).

بالجيم ومعناه " نبش قبرا " لا من نبش قبرا فقد جدده وأحوج إلى تجديده وقد جعله جدثا محفورا، وأقول: إن " التجديد " على المعنى الذي ذهب إليه محمد بن الحسن الصفار، و " التحديد " بالحاء غير المعجمة الذي ذهب إليه سعد بن عبد الله والذي قاله البرقي من أنه " جدث " كله داخل في معنى الحديث، وأن من خالف الإمام (ع) في التجديد والتسنيم والنبش واستحل شيئا من ذلك فقد خرج من الاسلام والذي أقوله في قوله (ع) " من مثل مثالا ": إنه يعنى به من أبدع بدعة ودعا إليها أو وضع دينا فقد خرج من الاسلام وقولي في ذلك قول أئمتي عليهم السلام، فإن أصبت فمن الله على ألسنتهم وإن أخطأت فمن عند نفسي " وقال الشيخ (ره) في التهذيب بعد نقل كلام البرقي: " ويمكن أن يكون المعنى بهذه الرواية النهى أن يجعل القبر دفعة أخرى قبرا لانسان آخر لأن الجدث هو القبر فيجوز أن يكون الفعل مأخوذا منه، ثم قال: وكان شيخنا محمد بن محمد بن النعمان يقول: " إن الخبر بالخاء والدالين " خدد " وذلك مأخوذ من قوله تعالى " قتل أصحاب الأخدود " والخد هو الشق يقال: خددت الأرض أي شققتها وعلى هذه الروايات يكون النهى تناول شق القبر، إما للدفن فيه، أو على جهة النبش على ما ذهب إليه محمد بن علي ، وكل ما ذكرناه من الروايات والمعاني محتمل والله أعلم بالمراد والذي صدر الخبر عنه (ع) " و قال الشهيد (قده) في الذكرى: " قلت: اشتغال هؤلاء الأفاضل بتحقيق هذه اللفظة مؤذن بصحة الحديث عندهم وإن كان طريقه ضعيفا كما في أحاديث كثيرة اشتهرت وعلم موردها وإن ضعف اسنادها فلا يرد ما ذكره في المعتبر من ضعف محمد بن سنان وأبى الجارود راويه، على أنه قد ورد نحوه من طريق أبى الهياج قال: قال علي (ع) " أبعثك على ما بعثني عليه رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله لا ترى قبرا مشرفا إلا سويته ولا تمثالا إلا طمسته " وقد نقله الشيخ في الخلاف وهو من صحاح العامة وهو يعطى صحة الرواية بالحاء المهملة لدلالة الاشراف والتسوية عليه ويعطى أن المثال هنا هو المثال هناك وهو الصورة وقد روى في النهى عن التصوير وإزالة التصاوير أخبار مشهورة وأما الخروج عن الاسلام بهذين فاما على طريقة المبالغة زجرا عن الاقتحام على ذلك، وإما لأنه فعل ذلك مخالفة للإمام (ع) " (انتهى) وربما يقال: على تقدير أن يكون اللفظ " جدد " (بالجيم والدال) و " جدث " (بالجيم والثاء <يحتمل أن يكون المراد قتل مؤمن من عدوانا لأن من قتله فقد جدد قبرا مجددا بين القبور وجعله جدثا وهو مستقل في هذا التجديد فيجوز إسناده إليه بخلاف ما لو قتل بحكم الشرع وهذا أنسب بالمبالغة بخروجه من الاسلام، ويحتمل أن يكون المراد بالمثال الصنم للعبادة " أقول: لا يخفى بعدما ذكره في التجديد وأما المثال فهو قريب، وربما يقال: " المراد به إقامة رجل بحذاءه كما يفعله المتكبرون ويؤيده ما ذكره الصدوق (ره) في كتاب معاني الأخبار، عن محمد بن علي ماجيلويه، عن عمه 4 - Chapter on Taking a Mosque in the House

29 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Isa, from Safwan, from Abdullah ibn Muskan, from al-Halabi, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Ali (a.s.) had a house in which there was nothing but a mattress, a sword, and a Quran, and he would pray in it, (or he said:) he would rest in it (1).

30 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Ibn Bukayr, from Ubayd ibn Zurara, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Ali (a.s.) had made a room in his house, neither small nor large, for his prayer. And when it was night, he would take a boy with him to spend the night with him and pray in it (2).

31 - From him, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Aban, from Mism'a who said: Abu Abdullah (a.s.) wrote to me: I would like you to take a mosque in your house in some of your rooms, then wear two coarse, thick garments, then ask God to free you from the Fire and admit you to Paradise, and do not speak a false word or a word of transgression (3).

5 - Chapter on Decorating Houses and Pictures

32 - From him, from his father, from al-Nadr ibn Suwayd, from al-Qasim ibn Sulayman, from Jarrah al-Madaini, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Do not build on graves, and do not depict the ceilings of houses, for the Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, disliked that. And it was narrated from Yusuf ibn Aqil, from Muhammad ibn Qays, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) (4).

33 - From him, from his father, from Ibn Sinan, from Abi al-Jarud, from al-Asbagh ibn Nubata who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) said: Whoever renovates a grave or makes a statue has left Islam (5).

"Clarification - Al-Saduq (may God be pleased with him) said in al-Faqih after mentioning this report in a mursal form: "Our scholars differed in the meaning of this report. Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Saffar (may God have mercy on him) said that it is "jaddada" (renovated) with a "jeem" only. And our Sheikh Muhammad ibn al-Hasan ibn Ahmad ibn al-Walid (may God be pleased with him) used to narrate from him that he said: It is not permissible to renovate the grave or plaster all of it after the passage of days on it and after it was plastered in the first instance. But if a deceased person dies and his grave is plastered, then it is permissible to repair the rest of the graves without renovating. And it was mentioned from Sa'd ibn Abdullah that he used to say: "It is only "haddada qabran" with a "haa" without a dot, meaning by it one who makes a grave convex." And it was mentioned from Ahmad ibn Abi Abdullah al-Barqi that it is only "man jaddatha qabran" and the explanation of al-jaddath is the grave, so we do not know what he meant by it. And what I adhere to is that it is "jaddada" with a "jeem," and its meaning is "nabasha qabran" (exhumed a grave). Whoever exhumed a grave has renovated it and made it in need of renovation and has made it a dug-up grave (jaddath). And I say: that "renovation" according to the meaning that Muhammad ibn al-Hasan al-Saffar adhered to, and "tahdid" with a "haa" without a dot, which Sa'd ibn Abdullah adhered to, and what al-Barqi said, that it is "jaddatha," all fall within the meaning of the hadith, and that whoever opposes the Imam (a.s.) in renovation, making it convex, and exhuming it, and deems any of that permissible, has left Islam. And what I say regarding his saying (a.s.) "whoever makes a statue": is that he means by it whoever invents an innovation and calls to it or establishes a religion, has left Islam, and my saying in that is the saying of my Imams, peace be upon them. If I am right, then it is from God through their tongues, and if I am wrong, then it is from myself." And Sheikh (may God have mercy on him) said in al-Tahdhib after quoting the words of al-Barqi: "And it is possible that the meaning of this narration is the prohibition of making the grave another grave for another person, because al-jaddath is the grave, so it is permissible that the verb is taken from it. Then he said: And our Sheikh Muhammad ibn Muhammad ibn al-Nu'man used to say: "That the report is with a "khaa" and two "daals" "khaddada," and that is taken from His saying, may He be exalted, "Slain were the makers of the pit (al-ukhdood)." And al-khadd is the crack. It is said: I made a crack in the land, meaning I split it. And according to these narrations, the prohibition includes splitting the grave, either for burial in it, or in terms of exhumation according to what Muhammad ibn Ali went to. And all that we have mentioned from the narrations and meanings is possible, and God knows best what is intended, and what the report was issued from him (a.s.)" And al-Shahid (may his secret be sanctified) said in al-Dhikra: "I said: The preoccupation of these virtuous people with verifying this word indicates the soundness of the hadith according to them, even if its path is weak, as in many hadiths that became famous and their source is known, even if their isnad is weak, so what he mentioned in al-Mu'tabar about the weakness of Muhammad ibn Sinan and Abi al-Jarud, its narrator, is not refuted. However, something similar has been reported from the path of Abi al-Hayyaj, who said: Ali (a.s.) said: "I am sending you on what the Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, sent me on: that you do not see a raised grave except that you level it, and no statue except that you obliterate it." And Sheikh has narrated it in al-Khilaf, and it is from the Sahih of the common people, and it gives the soundness of the narration with the unpointed "haa," due to the indication of the elevation and leveling on it, and it gives that the statue here is the statue there, which is the image. And famous reports have been narrated in the prohibition of drawing and removing images. As for leaving Islam with these two, it is either in the way of exaggeration as a deterrent from encroaching on that, or it is because he did that in opposition to the Imam (a.s.)" (End). And perhaps it is said: on the assumption that the word is "jaddada" (with a "jeem" and a "daal") and "jaddatha" (with a "jeem" and a "thaa") <It is possible that what is meant is killing a believer out of aggression, because whoever kills him has renovated a renewed grave among the graves and made it a jaddath, and he is independent in this renewal, so it is permissible to attribute it to him, unlike if he was killed by the ruling of Sharia, and this is more appropriate to the exaggeration in his leaving Islam. And it is possible that what is meant by the statue is the idol for worship." I say: What he mentioned in the renovation is not hidden, and as for the statue, it is close, and perhaps it is said: "What is meant by it is erecting a man in front of him as the arrogant do, and it is supported by what al-Saduq (may God have mercy on him) mentioned in the book of Ma'ani al-Akhbar, from Muhammad ibn Ali Majilawayh, from his uncle Muhammad ibn Abi al-Qasim, from Ahmad ibn Abi Abdullah, from al-Nahiki with his isnad, raising it to Abi Abdullah (a.s.) that he said: "Whoever makes a statue or acquires a dog has left Islam." So it was said to him: Many people have perished, then he said: It is not where you went. I meant by my saying: "Whoever makes a statue" is whoever establishes a religion other than the religion of God and calls people to it, and by my saying: "Whoever acquires a dog" hates us, the people of the house, acquires it, feeds it, and gives it water. Whoever does that has left Islam." Then know that Islam and faith have various meanings in the reports, so it is possible that what is meant here is a meaning that some sins entail leaving it, as for proving a ruling solely based on those readings and possibilities with a single report, its problems are not hidden. And what the people mentioned from interpretations and explanations does not indicate their correctness and acting upon them. Yes, it is suitable as a support for other reports that have been mentioned in each of those rulings, and perhaps it is suitable for proving dislike or recommendation, even if there is also room for discussion in it."

41 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن أحمد بن النضر، عن عمرو بن شمر، عن جابر، عن عبد الله بن يحيى الكندي، عن أبيه (وكان صحاب مطهرة على)، عن علي (ع) قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله:
يا علي إن جبرئيل أتاني البارحة، فسلم على من الباب، فقلت: ادخل، فقال: إنا لا ندخل بيتا فيه ما في هذا البيت، فصدقته وما علمت في البيت شيئا، فضربت بيدي، فإذا جر وكلب كا للحسين بن علي يلعب به الأمس، فلما كان الليل دخل تحت السرير، فنبذته من البيت ودخل، فقلت: يا جبرئيل أو ما تدخلون بيتا فيه كلب؟ - قال: لا، ولا جنب ولا تمثال لا يوطأ (4).
42 - عنه، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن رجل، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: من مثل تماثيل

39 - From him, from Ali ibn Muhammad, from Ayyub ibn Nuh, from Safwan, from Ibn Miskan, from Muhammad ibn Marwan, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: The Messenger of Allah, may God bless him and his family, said: "Gabriel came to me and said: We, the angels, do not enter a house in which there is a dog, nor a statue of a body, nor a vessel in which urine is passed (2)."
40 - From him, from his father, from Al-Hasan ibn Mukhallad, from Aban, from Omar ibn Khallad, from Abi Jaafar (peace be upon him):
He said: Gabriel said: "O Messenger of God, we do not enter a house in which there is a picture of a human being, nor a house in which urine is passed, nor a house in which there is a dog (3)."
41 - From him, from his father, from Ahmed ibn Al-Nadr, from Amr ibn Shamar, from Jaber, from Abdullah ibn Yahya Al-Kindi, from his father (who was a companion of the purification place), from Ali (peace be upon him), who said: The Messenger of Allah, may God bless him and his family, said:
"O Ali, Gabriel came to me last night and greeted me from the door, and I said: Enter. He said: We do not enter a house in which there is what is in this house. When it was night, it entered under the bed, so I threw it out of the house and he entered. So I said: O Gabriel, do you not enter a house in which there is a dog? He said: No, nor a person in a state of major ritual impurity, nor a statue that is not trodden upon (4)."

Al-Qadi pointed to something similar to what Al-Khattabi said, and Al-Nawawi said: "The most apparent is that it is general in every dog and picture and that they abstain from all of it due to the generality of the hadiths."

الأصحاب كراهة الصلاة فيما ذكر وقال الشيخ (ره) في المبسوط: الثوب إذا كان فيه تماثيل وصور لا تجوز الصلاة فيه، وقال فيه: لا يصلى في ثوب فيه تماثيل ولا في خاتم كذلك، وكذا في الفقيه، وحرم ابن البراج الصلاة في الخاتم الذي فيه صورة ولم يذكر الثوب، والأشهر أقرب وإن كان الأحوط الترك. الثاني ظاهر الأكثر عدم الفرق بين صور الحيوان وغيره وقال ابن إدريس: إنما تكره الصلاة في الثوب الذي عليه الصور والتماثيل من الحيوان وأما صور غير الحيوان فلا بأس، وما ذكره الأكثر وإن كان أوفق بكلام اللغويين فإن أكثرهم فسروا الصورة والمثال والتمثال بما يعم و يشمل غير الحيوان أيضا لكن ظاهر إطلاق أكثر الاخبار التخصيص، ففي بعض He disliked images in houses. And it was narrated from him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Ibn Faddal, from al-Muthanna (1).
46 - From him, from Ali bin al-Hakam and Muhsin bin Ahmad, from Aban al-Ahmar, from Yahya bin al-Ala, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) that he disliked images in houses (2).
47 - From him, from Ibn al-Azrami, from Hatem bin Ismail al-Madaini, from Jaafar, from his father, that Ali (a.s.) disliked images in houses (3).
48 - From him, from several of our companions, from Ali bin Asbat, from Ali bin Jaafar, who said: I asked Abu al-Hasan Musa bin Jaafar (a.s.) about a house that has a curtain with statues on its door, is it permissible to pray in that house? - He said: No. He said: And I asked him about houses in which there are statues, is it permissible to pray in them? - He said: No (4).
49 - From him, from Musa bin al-Qasim, from Ali bin Jaafar, from his father, who said: I asked him about - a man, is it permissible for him to pray in a house on whose door there is an outer curtain with statues on it, and below it, near the house, there is another curtain without statues, is it permissible for him to lower the curtain that does not have statues, does it separate between him and the curtain that has statues, or does he shut the door from it and pray in it? - He said: There is no harm. He said:
And I asked him about a garment that has statues on it or on its border, is it permissible to pray in it? - He said: It is not permissible to pray in it (5).
50 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from al-Ala, from Muhammad bin Muslim, from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) who said: I said to Abi Jaafar (a.s.): Should I pray while the statues are in front of me and I am looking at them? - He said: Throw a garment over them, and there is nothing wrong with them if they are on your right, or your left, or behind you, or under your feet, or above your head, but if they are in the direction of the Qibla, then throw a garment over them and pray (6).

And saying after the second hadith within an explanation: "It appears from it and from what will come that if in the house in which one prays there is an image of an animal according to what we have chosen, or absolutely anything that has a resemblance in the outside world (according to what was said), then it is disliked to pray in it, and the dislike is lessened by the image being in a direction other than the Qibla, or under the feet, or by it being covered with a garment or something else, or by a deficiency in it, especially the loss of its eyes or one of them, and if its head is gone, then it is better, and it is possible that the dislike goes away with one of these things, even if the more cautious approach is to avoid it absolutely," I say, his saying (may God have mercy on him):
"According to what we have chosen" is a reference to what he mentioned in "Chapter on the Prohibition of Prayer in Silk, Gold, Iron, and What Contains Statues and Other Things that Prayer is Prohibited in," (p. 102 of the Book of Prayer) and his speech there, although long, I have included it here because it is like an explanation of the narrations of the text, and this is half of it: "Al-Uyoun - from Jaafar bin Naeem bin Shadhan, from his uncle Muhammad bin Shadhan, from al-Fadl bin Shadhan, from Muhammad bin Ismail bin Bazi' who said: I asked al-Ridha (a.s.) about the decorated garment, and he disliked what had statues in it," Explanation - it indicates the lack of dislike of praying in the decorated and dislike in what has statues in it, and there is no apparent disagreement among the companions in the preference of avoiding statues and images on the ring and garment and it is attached to the sword and the disagreement in two positions, the first is the well-known among the companions is the dislike of praying in what was mentioned and Sheikh (may God have mercy on him) said in al-Mabsout: If the garment has statues and images on it, it is not permissible to pray in it, and he said in it: It is not permissible to pray in a garment that has statues in it or in a ring like that, and likewise in al-Faqih, and Ibn al-Barraj forbade praying in the ring that has an image in it and did not mention the garment, and the more well-known is closer, even if the more cautious approach is to leave it. is "an example of a bird and other than that," and in some of them "an image of an animal," and in some of them "a statue of a body," and from Abi Jaafar (a.s.) that he said: "Indeed, those who harm God and His Messenger" are the image-makers who are compelled on the Day of Resurrection to breathe into them the soul, and in the report of al-Manahi from the Prophet, may God bless him and his family, "Whoever makes an image, God will compel him on the Day of Resurrection to breathe into it, and he will not be able to breathe," and in al-Khisal from Ibn Abbas, who said that the Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, said: "Whoever makes an image is compelled to breathe into it, and he will not be able to do," the report, so these reports and the like indicate the general As for their saying, "Images and statues are disliked," the conjunction is for explanation. As for statues of trees, it is metaphorical, if it is correct." And it was said in al-Misbah al-Munir: "The example is the depicted image, and in his garment are resemblances, that is, images of depicted animals." And it was said in al-Dhikra: "Ibn Idris singled out the dislike for statues of animals only, not others such as trees, and perhaps he considered the interpretation of His saying, may He be exalted: 'They made for him what he willed of sanctuaries and statues.' From the People of the House (peace be upon them), 'that they are like images of trees.' And the common people have narrated in the Sahih that a man said to Ibn Abbas: 'I make these images and acquire them.' He said: 'I heard the Messenger of God, peace and blessings be upon him, say: 'Every image-maker is in the Fire, and for every image he makes, a soul is made for him to torment him in Hell.'' He said: 'If you must do it, then make trees and what has no soul.'" And in a mursal report from Ibn Abi Umayr from al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) regarding statues on the carpet that have two eyes and you are praying? He said: "If it has one eye, then there is no problem, but if it has two eyes, then no." And from Muhammad ibn Muslim, from Abi Ja'far (peace be upon him), who said: "There is no problem with the statues being in the garment if the image is altered from it." Most of this indicates what Ibn Idris said, even if many of the companions have made it general." (End quote). I say: Regardless of the indication of those reports on specifying the meaning of statues and images, we say: If it is permissible to pray and the dislike is removed merely by a defect in a limb of the animal, even though the rest of its parts are similar to what is found of them externally, then trees and the like are more deserving of permissibility. In general, being certain of generalization with that is problematic, with the support of specification for the principle of innocence and its suitability for the tolerant Sharia and for His saying, may He be exalted: "Take your adornment at every mosque," even if it is more cautious to leave wearing images absolutely. As for the reports indicating permissibility, they are numerous, including what al-Shaykh narrated in the Sahih from Muhammad ibn Muslim, who said: I asked Abu Ja'far (peace be upon him) about a man praying while wearing a garment with dirhams in it that have statues? He said: "There is no problem with that." And al-Kulayni narrated in the Sahih from al-Bazanti from al-Rida (peace be upon him) that he showed him the ring of Abu al-Hasan (peace be upon him) and in it was a rose and a crescent at its top. And the reports narrated with the words "dislike" and "I do not desire" and "I do not like" are numerous, and it was narrated in the Sahih from Zurara, from Abi Ja'far (peace be upon him), who said: "There is no problem with statues of trees." And in the Sahih from Muhammad ibn Muslim, from Abi Abd Allah (peace be upon him), who said: "I asked him about statues of trees and the sun and the moon. He said: There is no problem as long as it is not something from the animal." And it was said in al-Muntaha: If the image is altered from the garment, the dislike is removed, and he mentioned the sahih report of Muhammad ibn Muslim that he narrated in al-Dhikra."

95 - From him, from several of our companions, from Ali ibn Asbat, from his uncle, who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) said that the Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: Three people should not ride on an animal unless one of them is cursed, and that is the one in front.
96 - From him, from al-Hasan ibn Yazid al-Nawfali, from Ismail ibn Abi Ziyad al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: An animal has six rights over its owner: he should not load it beyond its capacity, he should not use its back as a place to sit and talk, he should start by feeding it when he dismounts, he should not brand it on its face, and he should not strike it on its face, for it glorifies God, and he should offer it water when he passes by it.
97 - From him, from some of our companions, who traced it back (to the Imam) who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) said: Do not strike them when they stumble, but strike them when they bolt. And he said: Do not sing on their backs. Is one of you not ashamed to sing on the back of an animal while it is glorifying God?

'Al-'Adw' is as mentioned in al-Qamus, and the verb is like 'Nasr.' His saying 'not intending to hunt' has two possible meanings: the first is that he does not hunt, but he rides behind the game, and the second is that he hunts, but his purpose is not amusement by hunting nor hunting in itself, but rather his purpose is to seek bodily health and what necessitates it, such as digesting food and expelling excess moisture from the body. The latter is more apparent in meaning and the former in wording, and it is not far-fetched that this type of hunting is permissible from the implications of the words of the companions, for they have ruled that hunting for amusement and vanity is forbidden, and hunting for sustenance and trade is permissible, and their evidence for prohibiting the former and permitting the latter two requires the permissibility of this and similar cases. It is stated in al-Tadhkira: 'The one who amuses himself on his journey is like a pleasure-seeker who hunts out of vanity and amusement, he does not shorten (the prayer) according to our scholars, because amusement is forbidden, so traveling for it is a sin. But if the hunting is for his sustenance and the sustenance of his family, then shortening (the prayer) is obligatory because it is a permissible act. And if it is for trade, then the preferred view is shortening the prayer and fasting because it is permissible' (end quote). And the permissibility of this purpose is obvious." 104 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Abi Umair, from Hisham ibn Salim, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him) went out to his companions while riding, and they walked with him. He turned to them and said: "Do you have a need?" They said: "No, O Amir al-Mu'minin, but we like to walk with you." He said to them: "Go back, for the walking of the walker with the rider is a corruption for the rider and a humiliation for the walker."
He said: And he rode another time, and they walked behind him, so he said: "Go back, for the sound of sandals behind the heels of men is a corruption for the hearts of the foolish (1)."
13 - Chapter on the equipment of animals 105 - From him, from Ali ibn Asbat, from Ali ibn Jaafar, from his brother who said: I asked about riding on the skins of predators? He said: "There is no harm, as long as one does not prostrate upon them (2)."
106 - From him, from Uthman, from Sama'a, who said: Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) was asked about the skins of predators?
He said: "Ride them, but do not wear anything of them in which you pray (3)."
107 - From him, from Uthman, from Sama'a, who said: I heard Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him) say: The Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Beware of riding on a red saddle blanket, for it is the saddle blanket of Iblis (4)." 108 - From him, from his father, from Muhammad ibn Ali, from Abd al-Rahman ibn Abi Hashim, from Ibrahim ibn Yahya al-Madini, from Abi Abdullah, that Ali ibn al-Hussein (peace be upon him) used to ride on a red velvet cloth (5).

Do not wear a gold ring, for it is our adornment in the Hereafter, and do not wear crimson, for it is from the garments of Iblis, and do not ride on a red saddle blanket, for it is from the mounts of Iblis, and do not wear silk, for Allah will burn your skin on the Day of Resurrection,'" within a statement of his that reads: "And Ibn al-Athir said in al-Nihaya: 'In it is that he forbade a purple saddle blanket. Its origin is "mu'thira," but the waw was changed to a ya' because of the kasra of the mim, and it is from the mounts of the Persians, made of silk or brocade. And al-Arjuwan is a red dye and is taken as a small mattress and stuffed with cotton or wool, which the rider puts under him on the saddles on top of the camels. 14 - Chapter on the Virtue of Horses and their Tethering

109 - From him, from more than one of our companions, from Aban al-Ahmar, who traced it back to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: "Horses were wild animals in the lands of the Arabs. Then Ibrahim (Abraham) (peace be upon him) and Ismail (Ishmael) (peace be upon him) ascended high-quality horses and shouted, 'Ala hala, ala halumma (Come here! Come on!)' No horse failed to give its hand and allow its forelock to be grasped (1)."

110 - From him, from his father, from Fadala bin Ayyub, from Aban, from Zurara, from Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him), and Abdul Rahman bin Abi Abdullah, from Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Goodness is in the forelocks of horses (2)."

111 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Tha'laba bin Maymun, from Muammar, from Abu Jaafar (peace be upon him), who said: "I heard him say: 'Indeed, all goodness is in the forelocks of horses until the Day of Resurrection (3).'"

I say, he نقل [ نقل is used here to mean " نقل" to mean quoted"] it there also from al-Kafi, and something close to it from al-Ilal, and he said after the hadith of al-Ilal, verbatim: "Explanation - Al-Fayrouzabadi said: 'Hala = a rebuke to horses, and Tahli al-Faras = it sped up, and Hahlal = he rebuked it with hala.' 112 - From him, from Ali bin al-Hakam, from Umar bin Aban, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Goodness is tied to the forelocks of horses until the Day of Resurrection (1)."
113 - From him, from al-Qasim bin Yahya, from his grandfather al-Hasan bin Rashid, from Yaqub bin Jafar bin Ibrahim bin Muhammad al-Ja'fari, who said: I heard Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) saying: "Whoever keeps a thoroughbred horse, three bad deeds are erased from him every day, and eleven good deeds are written for him. And whoever keeps a hybrid horse, two bad deeds are erased from him every day, and seven good deeds are written for him. And whoever keeps a mule, intending beauty, or fulfilling needs, or repelling an enemy, one bad deed is erased from him every day, and six good deeds are written for him (2)."
114 - From him, from Bakr bin Salih, from Sulaiman al-Ja'fari, who said: I heard Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) saying: "Whoever keeps a blond horse with a white blaze and a white sock, and if the blaze is flowing and there is whiteness on its legs, then it is more beloved to me. Poverty will not enter his house as long as that horse is in it, and as long as it is in the possession of its owner, injustice will not enter his house." He said: And I heard him saying: "Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) gifted the Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) four horses from Yemen, and he said: 'Name them for me.' He said: 'They are of different colors.' He said: 'Is there whiteness in them?' He said: 'Yes, a blond one with whiteness.' He said: 'Keep it, Ali.' And he said: 'Are there two bay horses with whiteness?' He said: 'Give them to your two sons.' He said: 'And the fourth is a solid black one.' He said: 'Sell it and use its price as sustenance for your family. The blessing of horses is in those with whiteness.'" He said: And I heard Abu al-Hasan (a.s.) saying: "We dislike solid black animals, except for the camel and the mule, and I dislike variegated whiteness in donkeys and mules of colors, and I dislike white socks in mules unless it has a flowing blaze, and I do not desire it in any case." And he said: "If the animal stumbles under a man and he says to it: 'May you perish,' it says: 'May you perish.'"

And 'Al-Birdhawn' (with a kasrah) = what has nothing of Arabian in its parents. Al-Dumairi said: 'Horses are of two types, thoroughbred and hybrid, and the difference between them is that the bone of the mule is greater than the bone of the horse, and the bone of the horse is more solid and heavier than the bone of the mule, and the mule carries more than the horse, and the horse is faster than the mule, and the thoroughbred is like the gazelle and the mule is like the sheep. So, the thoroughbred of horses is what both parents are Arabian, named so for its freedom from defects and its safety from being impugned by diminishing matters.'"

116 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Ali bin Asbat, who traced it back to the Prophet, that Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: Do not strike the faces of animals or anything that possesses a soul, for it glorifies Allah with praise (1).
117 - From him, from al-Qasim bin Yahya, from his grandfather al-Hasan bin Rashid, from Ibn Muslim, from Abi - Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Amir al-Mu'minin (a.s.) said: Do not strike animals on their faces, for they glorify their Lord with praise, and in another hadith: "Do not brand them on their faces" (2).
118 - From him, from some of our companions, who conveyed it to Abu Abdullah (a.s.) who said: Is one of you not ashamed to sing while riding his animal while it is glorifying Allah? It was narrated from the Prophet (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) that he said: Strike them when they shy, and do not strike them when they stumble (3).
119 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.), from his forefathers (a.s.) who said: An animal has six rights over its owner: he should not load it beyond its capacity, he should not use its back as a gathering place to talk on it, he should begin by feeding it when he dismounts, he should offer it water when he passes by it, he should not brand it on its face, and he should not strike it on its face, for it glorifies Allah (4).
120 - From him, from some of our companions, who traced it back to the Prophet, that Abu Abdullah (a.s.) when he placed his foot in the stirrup would say: "Glory be to Him Who has subjected this to us, and we were not capable of it." And he would glorify Allah seven times, praise Allah seven times, and declare Allah's greatness seven times (5).

Whoever leaves his house or someone else's house early in the morning and encounters a light chestnut horse with white markings, and if it has a flowing blaze, then that is the essence of life itself; he will only encounter joy on that day. And if he goes out for a need and encounters the horse, Allah will fulfill his need (1).
123 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers (peace be upon them), who said: A man offered Ali an animal to ride, and Ali said to him: "May Allah carry your feet on the Day of Bare Feet (2)."
124 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers, that Ali (peace be upon him) passed by an animal and a male mounting it in the middle of the road. Ali (peace be upon him) turned his face away, and it was said to him: "Why did you do that, O Commander of the Believers?" He said: "Because they should not do what they are doing, which is reprehensible, except that they conceal it where no man or woman can see it (3)."
125 - From him, from his father, from Abdullah bin al-Mughira and Muhammad bin Sinan, from Talha bin Zaid, from Abi Abdullah, from his father (peace be upon him), that he disliked castrating animals and inciting them against each other (4).
126 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers (peace be upon them), who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "If an animal refuses to move for one of you (meaning if it stops in the land of the enemy in the path of Allah), then he should slaughter it and not hamstring it (5)."
127 - From him, from Jaafar, from his father, who said: On the day of Mu'tah, Jaafar was on his horse, and when they met, he dismounted his horse and hamstrung it with the sword, and he was the first to hamstring in Islam (6).
128 - From him, from al-Qasim bin Yahya, from his grandfather al-Hasan bin Rashid, from Yaqub bin Jaafar bin Ibrahim, who said: I heard Abu al-Hasan the First (peace be upon him) say: "The devil is on every nostril of the horse."

There is no camel that stands at Arafat for seven pilgrimages but that God makes it from the bounties of Paradise and blesses its offspring. When they died, Abu Jaafar (a.s.) dug for them and buried them (1).
134 - From him, from Yaqub bin Yazid, from Muhammad bin Marazim, from his father, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, said: There is no animal that has been known to be present in five stands (at Arafat) except that it will be from the bounties of Paradise. From him, he said: Some of them narrated "stood in it for three stands" (2).
135 - From him, from Muhammad bin Sinan, from Abd al-A'la, from one of the two (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, said: There is no camel but that there is a devil on its hump, so make use of them, and let none of you say: "Let my camel rest," for it is God who carries (3).
136 - From him, from Muhammad bin Yahya, from Ghiyath bin Ibrahim, from Abi Abdullah, from his forefathers (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, said: Indeed, on the hump of every camel is a devil, so make use of them for yourselves and subdue them, and mention the name of God upon them, for it is only God who carries (4).
137 - From him, from Abi Talib, from Anas bin Ayaz al-Laythi, from Abi Abdullah, from his father (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, said: Indeed, on the hump of every camel is a devil, so make use of them for yourselves and subdue them, and mention the name of God upon them as God has commanded you (5).

138 - عنه، عن جعفر بن محمد، عن ابن القداح، عن أبي عبد الله (ع): وعن أبيه ميمون، قال: خرجنا مع أبي جعفر (ع) إلى أرضه بطيبة، ومعه عمرو بن دينار وأناس من أصحابه، فأقمنا بطيبة ما شاء الله، وركب أبو جعفر (ع) على جمل صعب، فقال له عمرو:
ما أصعب بعيركم! فقال له: أما علمت أن رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله قال: إن على ذروة كل بعير شيطانا فامتهنوها وذللوها واذكروا اسم الله عليها فإنما يحمل الله؟! ثم دخل مكة ودخلنا معه بغير إحرام (1).
139 - قال: وحدثني أبي، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن هشام بن الحكم، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: لو يعلم الحاج ماله من الحملان ما غالى أحد بالبعير (2) 140 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن الحجال، عن صفوان الجمال قال: قال أبو - عبد الله (ع): لو يعلم الناس كنه حملان الله على الضعيف ما غالوا ببهيمة (3).
141 - قال: وحدثني أبي، عن محمد بن عمرو، عن سليمان الرحال، عن عبد الله بن أبي يعفور، قال مر بي أبو عبد الله (ع) وأنا أمشى على ناقتي، وأردت أن أخفف عنها، فقال:
رحمك الله اركب، فإن الله يحمل على الضعيف والقوى (4).

138 - From him, from Ja'far bin Muhammad, from Ibn al-Qaddah, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.): And from his father Maymun, who said: We went out with Abi Ja'far (a.s.) to his land in Tayba, and with him were Amr bin Dinar and some of his companions, and we stayed in Tayba as long as God willed. Abi Ja'far (a.s.) rode on a difficult camel, and Amr said to him: "How difficult is your camel!" He said to him: "Did you not know that the Messenger of God, may God’s prayers and peace be upon him and his family, said: 'Indeed, on the hump of every camel is a devil, so humble them, subdue them, and mention the name of God upon them, for it is God who carries them?'" Then he entered Mecca, and we entered with him without Ihram (1).
139 - He said: And my father narrated to me, from Ibn Abi Umayr, from Hisham bin al-Hakam, from Abi Abdullah (a.s.) who said: "If the pilgrims knew what they receive of carrying (burdens), no one would exaggerate the price of a camel (2)."
140 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from al-Hajjal, from Safwan al-Jamal, who said: Abu Abdullah (a.s.) said: "If people knew the essence of God's carrying (burdens) on the weak, they would not exaggerate the price of an animal (3)."
141 - He said: And my father narrated to me, from Muhammad bin Amr, from Sulaiman al-Rahhal, from Abdullah bin Abi Ya'fur, who said: Abu Abdullah (a.s.) passed by me while I was walking beside my she-camel, and I wanted to lighten her load, so he said: "May God have mercy on you, ride, for God carries both the weak and the strong (4)."

142 - عنه، عن النهيكي ويعقوب بن يزيد، عن أبي وكيع، عن أبي إسحاق، عن الحارث، عن أمير المؤمنين (ع) قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله وقد سئل عن الإبل فقال: تلك أعنان الشياطين، ويأتي خيرها من الجانب الأشئم، قيل: إن سمع الناس هذا تركوها، قال:
إذا لا يعدمها الأشقياء الفجرة (1).
143 - عنه، عن ابن فضال، عن صفوان الجمال، قال: أرسل إلى المفضل بن عمر أن أشترى لأبي عبد الله (ع) جملا فاشتريت جملا بثمانين درهما، فقدمت به على أبى - عبد الله (ع) فقال لي: أتراه يحمل القبة؟ فشددت عليه القبة وركبته فاستعرضته، ثم قال:
لو أن الناس يعلمون كنه حملان الله على الضعيف ما غالوا ببهيمة (2).

142 - From him, from al-Nahiki and Yaqub bin Yazid, from Abi Waki', from Abi Ishaq, from al-Harith, from Amir al-Mu'minin (peace be upon him), who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said, when asked about camels: "Those are the reins of the devils, and their good comes from the ominous side." It was said: "If people hear this, they will abandon them." He said: "Then only the wretched libertines will lack them (1)."
143 - From him, from Ibn Faddal, from Safwan al-Jammal, who said: "Al-Mufaddal bin Omar sent to me to buy a camel for Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), so I bought a camel for eighty dirhams. I brought it to Abu Abdullah (peace be upon him), and he said to me: 'Do you think it can carry the dome (qubba)?' So I fastened the dome on it and rode it, and showed it to him. Then he said: 'If people knew the essence of God's carrying on the weak, they would not be extravagant with an animal (2).'"

text:
144 - عنه، عن الحجال، عن صفوان الجمال، قال: قال أبو عبد الله (ع): إشتر لي جملا وليكن أسود، فإنها أطول شئ أعمارا، ثم قال: لو يعلم الناس كنه حملان الله على - الضعيف ما غالوا ببهيمة. وفى حديث آخر قال: قال أبو عبد الله: اشتر السواد القباح منها، فإنها أطول أعمارا (1).
145 - عنه، عن الحسن بن محبوب، عن الحسين بن عمر بن يزيد، قال: اشتريت إبلا وأنا بالمدينة مقيم، فأعجبتني إعجابا شديدا، فدخلت على أبى عبد الله (ع) فذكرته فقال: مالك وللإبل؟ أما علمت أنها كثيرة المصائب؟! قال: فمن إعجابي بها اكتريتها وبعثت بها غلماني إلى الكوفة، قال فسقطت كلها، فدخلت عليه فأخبرته، فقال:
" فليحذر الذين يخالفون عن أمره أن تصيبهم فتنة أو يصيبهم عذاب أليم " (2).
146 - عنه، عن يعقوب بن يزيد، عن ابن سنان، ومحمد بن أبي عمير، عن عبد الله ابن سنان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: كان علي بن الحسين (ع) ليبتاع الراحلة بمائة دينار يكرم بها نفسه (3).
147 - عنه، عن يعقوب بن يزيد، عن ابن أبي عمير، عن عبد الله بن سنان، قال: سئل أبو عبد الله (ع) عن صلاة المغرب؟ - فقال: أنخ إذا غابت الشمس، قال فإنه يشتد على إناخته مرتين قال: افعل فإنه أصون للظهر (4).

16 - باب الغنم 149 - عنه، عن علي بن الحكم، عن عمرو بن أبان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: نعم المال الشاة (1) 150 - عنه، عن الحسن بن علي الوشاء، عن إسحاق بن جعفر، قال: قال لي أبو - عبد الله (ع): يا بنى اتخذ الغنم ولا تتخذ الإبل (2).
151 - عنه، عن النوفلي، عن السكوني، عن أبي عبد الله، عن آبائه (ع) قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: إذا كانت لأهل بيت شاة قدستهم الملائكة (3).
152 - عنه، عن ابن محبوب، عن محمد بن مارد، قال: سمعت أبا عبد الله (ع) يقول:
ما من مؤمن يكون في منزله عنز حلوب إلا قدس أهل ذلك المنزل وبورك عليهم، فإن كانتا اثنتين قدسوا وبورك عليهم كل يوم مرتين، قال: فقال بعض أصحابنا: وكيف يقدسون؟ - قال: يقف عليهم كل صباح ملك أو مساء فيقول لهم: " قدستم وبورك عليكم وطبتم وطاب إدامكم " قال: قلت له: وما معنى " قدستم "؟ - قال: طهرتم (4).
153 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن عبيس بن هشام، عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: إذا اتخذ أهل البيت الشاة قدستهم الملائكة كل يوم تقديسة، قلت: كيف يقولون؟ - قال: يقولون قدستم قدستم قال: وفى حديث آخر قال: إذا اتخذ أهل البيت ثلاث شياة (5).
154 - عنه، عن أبيه، عن سليمان الجعفري، رفعه قال: قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: من كانت في بيته شاة قدستهم الملائكة تقديسة وانتقل عنهم الفقر منتقلة، ومن كانت في بيته شاتان قدستهم الملائكة مرتين وارتحل عنهم الفقر منقلتين، فإن كانت ثلاث شياة قدستهم الملائكة ثلاث تقديسات وانتقل عنهم الفقر (6).

16 - Chapter on Sheep 149 - From him, from Ali ibn al-Hakam, from Amr ibn Aban, from Abi Abdillah (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Excellent wealth is the sheep." (1) 150 - From him, from al-Hasan ibn Ali al-Washsha', from Ishaq ibn Jaafar, who said: Abu Abdillah (a.s.) said to me: "O my son, acquire sheep and do not acquire camels." (2)
151 - From him, from al-Nawfali, from al-Sakuni, from Abi Abdillah, from his forefathers (a.s.) who said: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "If a household has a sheep, the angels sanctify them." (3)
152 - From him, from Ibn Mahbub, from Muhammad ibn Marid, who said: I heard Abu Abdillah (a.s.) saying:
"There is no believer in whose house there is a milking goat except that the people of that house are sanctified and blessed. If there are two, they are sanctified and blessed twice every day." He said: So some of our companions said: "How are they sanctified?" - He said: "Every morning or evening, an angel stands over them and says to them: 'You are sanctified and blessed, and you are good, and your stew is good.'" He said: I said to him: "What does 'you are sanctified' mean?" - He said: "You are purified." (4)
153 - From him, from Muhammad ibn Ali, from Ubays ibn Hisham, from Abdullah ibn Sinan, from Abi Abdillah (a.s.) who said: "If the people of a house acquire a sheep, the angels sanctify them every day with a sanctification." I said: "What do they say?" - He said: "They say, 'You are sanctified, you are sanctified.'" He said: And in another hadith, he said: "If the people of a house acquire three sheep." (5)
154 - From him, from his father, from Sulaiman al-Ja'fari, who raised it [said]: The Messenger of Allah (peace and blessings of Allah be upon him and his family) said: "Whoever has a sheep in his house, the angels sanctify them with one sanctification, and poverty departs from them in one departure. And whoever has two sheep in his house, the angels sanctify them twice, and poverty departs from them in two departures. And if there are three sheep, the angels sanctify them with three sanctifications, and poverty departs from them." (6)

155 - عنه، عن عبد الرحمن بن أبي نجران وعثمان عن أبي جميلة، عن جابر، عن أبي جعفر (ع) قال قال النبي صلى الله عليه وآله لعمته: ما يمنعك من أن تتخذي في بيتك بركة؟ - فقالت:
يا رسول الله ما البر البركة؟ - فقال: شاة تحلب، فإنه من كانت في داره شاة تحلب أو نعجة أو بقرة فبركات كلهن. قال: وروى أبي، عن أحمد بن النضر، عن جابر، عن أبي جعفر مثله (1) 156 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن عبد الرحمن بن أبي هشام، عن أبي خديجة، عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: دخل رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله على أم أيمن فقال: مالي لا أرى في بيتك البركة؟ - فقالت: أوليس في بيتي بركة؟ - قال: لست أعنى ذلك، ذاك شاة تتخذينها، تستغنى ولدك من لبنها، وتطعمين من سمنها، وتصلين في مربضها (2).

158 - عنه، عن أبي نصر بن مزاحم، قال: حدثني حميد الآبي، عن أم راشد مولاة أم هاني أن أمير المؤمنين (ع) دخل على أم هاني فقالت أم هاني: قدمي لأبي الحسن طعاما فقدمت ما كان في البيت، فقال: مالي لا أرى عندكم البركة؟ - فقالت أم هاني: أوليس هذا بركة؟ - فقال: لست أعنى هذا، إنما أعنى الشاة، فقالت: فمالنا من شاة فآكل وأستسقي (4).
159 - عنه، عن محمد بن علي، عن عبيس بن هشام، عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن أبي - عبد الله (ع) قال: إذا اتخذ أهل البيت شاة أتاهم الله برزقها وزاد في أرزاقهم وارتحل الفقر

155 - From him, from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Najran and Uthman from Abi Jamila, from Jabir, from Abi Jaafar (peace be upon him) who said: The Prophet (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said to his aunt: What prevents you from keeping a *baraka* (blessing) in your house? She said: O Messenger of God, what is the *baraka* (blessing)? He said: A sheep that gives milk, for whoever has a sheep, a ewe, or a cow in their house, all of them are blessings. He said: And my father narrated from Ahmad bin al-Nadr, from Jabir, from Abi Jaafar similarly (1).
156 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Abd al-Rahman bin Abi Hisham, from Abi Khadija, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) entered upon Umm Ayman and said: Why do I not see the *baraka* (blessing) in your house? She said: Is there not a *baraka* (blessing) in my house? He said: I do not mean that. That is a sheep that you keep, your child will be independent from its milk, and you will feed from its fat, and you will pray in its pen (2).
157 - From him, from some of his companions, raising it (to the Prophet) who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him and his family) said: Clean the sheep pens and wipe their rheum, for they are among the animals of Paradise (3).
158 - From him, from Abu Nasr bin Muzahim, who said: Hamid al-Abi narrated to me, from Umm Rashid, the freedwoman of Umm Hani, that the Commander of the Faithful (peace be upon him) entered upon Umm Hani, and Umm Hani said: Present food to Abu al-Hasan. So she presented what was in the house. He said: Why do I not see the *baraka* (blessing) with you? Umm Hani said: Is this not a *baraka* (blessing)? He said: I do not mean this, I only mean a sheep. She said: We have no sheep, so I can eat and drink (from it) (4).
159 - From him, from Muhammad bin Ali, from Ubayyis bin Hisham, from Abdullah bin Sinan, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) who said: When the people of a household keep a sheep, God brings them its sustenance, increases their provision, and poverty departs from them.

يحتمل هذا الخبر زائدا على ما مر أن يكون المراد بالسن مطلق السن وبالذكي الطاهر أو ما يقبل التذكية " أقول: مراده بقوله " ما مر " ما ذكره قبيل ذلك بعد نقل حديثين ولا بأس بنقل الحديثين مع البيان المشار إليه هنا لكثرة ما فيهما من الفائدة وعبارته " مكارم الأخلاق - عن عبد الله بن سنان، عن أبي عبد الله (ع): قال سألته عن الرجل ينفصم سنه أيصلح له أن يشدها بالذهب؟ - وإن سقطت أيصلح أن يجعل مكانها سن شاة؟ - قال: نعم إن شاء ليشدها بعد أن تكون ذكية، وعن الحلبي عن أبي عبد الله (ع) مثله، وعن زرارة عن أبي عبد الله (ع) قال: سأله أبى وأنا حاضر عن الرجل يسقط سنه فيأخذ سن إنسان ميت فيجعله مكانه قال: لا بأس " بيان - يدل الخبر الأول على جواز شد الأسنان بالذهب وهو موافق للأصل، وتحريم مطلق التزين بالذهب غير ثابت وقال العلامة في المنتهى: " لا بأس باتخاذ الفضة اليسير كالحلية للسيف والقصعة والسلسلة التي شعب بها الاناء وأنف الذهب وما يربط به أسنانه لما رواه الجمهور في قدح رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله والخاصة في مرآة موسى (ع) روى الجمهور أن عرفجة بن سعد أصيب أنفه يوم الكلاب فاتخذ أنفا ودرت فانتن عليه فأمره النبي صلى الله عليه وآله أن يتخذ أنفا من ذهب وللحاجة وبدونها خلافا لبعض " وقال في التذكرة " لو اتخذ أنفا من ذهب أو فضة أو سنا أو أنملة لم يحرم لحديث عرفجة ولو اتخذ أصبعا أو يدا فللشا - فعية قولان، الجواز قياسا على الانف والسن، والتحريم لأنه زينة محضة إذ لا منفعة به " (انتهى) أما السن فظاهر الأصحاب اتفاقهم على كونه مما لم تحل فيه الحياة ويجوز استعماله من الميتة وظاهر الخبر توقف جواز الاستعمال على التذكية ويمكن حمله على الاستحباب، أو على أن المراد بها الطهارة، أو عدم كونه مخلوطا بلحم وإن كان الأحوط اعتبارها إذ الأخبار الدالة على كونه مما لا تحله الحياة وكونه مستثنى من الميتة لا تخلو من ضعف ومن الأطباء من يعده عصبا لا عظما لطريان الوجع عليه مع معارضة هذه الأخبار وصحة بعضها وعدم تحقق الاجماع على خلافها. وأما سن الانسان فهو إما محمول على ما إذا سقط في حال حياته وقلنا بعدم وجوب دفنه معه وحملنا الخبر به على الاستحباب، أو على ما إذا سقط بعد تفرق الأعضاء ولم نقل بوجوب دفن الأعضاء

Some Comments from the End of the Book: An Explanation Related to the 74th Hadith After the Hundredth from the Hadiths of the Book of Al-Marafiq (see p. 644, lines 9-11). Al-Allama Al-Majlisi (may God have mercy on him) said after quoting it in Al-Bihar (vol. 18, Book of Prayer, "Chapter on What is Permissible to Pray in of Wool, Hair, and Leather and What is Not Permissible" (p. 100, line 26) with the following wording: "Explanation - This report may imply, in addition to what has been mentioned, that what is meant by 'tooth' is any tooth, and by 'slaughtered' is the pure or what is acceptable to be slaughtered." I say: What he means by "what has been mentioned" is what he mentioned before that after quoting two hadiths, and there is no harm in quoting the two hadiths along with the explanation referred to here because of the abundance of benefit in them, and his wording: "Makarim al-Akhlaq - from Abdullah bin Sinan, from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him): He said, I asked him about a man whose tooth breaks, is it permissible for him to fix it with gold? - And if it falls out, is it permissible to put a sheep's tooth in its place? - He said: Yes, if he wills, to fix it after it has been slaughtered, and from Al-Halabi from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) similar to it, and from Zurara from Abi Abdullah (peace be upon him) he said: My father asked him, and I was present, about a man whose tooth falls out and he takes the tooth of a dead person and puts it in its place, he said: There is no harm." Explanation - The first report indicates the permissibility of fixing teeth with gold, and it is in accordance with the principle, and the prohibition of absolute adornment with gold is not established, and Al-Allama said in Al-Muntaha: "There is no harm in taking a small amount of silver, such as jewelry for the sword, the bowl, and the chain with which the vessel is patched, and a nose of gold and what his teeth are tied with, because of what the public narrated about the cup of the Messenger of God, may God bless him and his family, and the private about the mirror of Moses (peace be upon him). The public narrated that Arfaja bin Saad was injured in his nose on the Day of al-Kilab, so he took a nose (made of silver), and it festered on him, so the Prophet, may God bless him and his family, ordered him to take a nose made of gold, both for need and without need, contrary to some." And he said in Al-Tadhkira: "If he took a nose of gold or silver, or a tooth or a fingertip, it would not be forbidden because of the hadith of Arfaja, and if he took a finger or a hand, then there are two opinions for the Shafi'is, permissibility by analogy with the nose and the tooth, and prohibition because it is pure adornment since there is no benefit in it." (End quote) As for the tooth, it is apparent that the companions agree that it is something in which life does not dwell and it is permissible to use it from the carrion, and the apparent meaning of the report is that the permissibility of use depends on slaughtering it, and it can be interpreted as recommended, or that what is meant by it is purity, or that it is not mixed with meat, even if it is more cautious to consider it, as the reports indicating that it is something in which life does not dwell and that it is excluded from the carrion are not without weakness, and some doctors consider it a nerve, not a bone, because of the occurrence of pain in it with the opposition of these reports and the soundness of some of them and the non-realization of consensus to the contrary. As for the human tooth, it is either interpreted as being if it fell out during his life and we said that it is not obligatory to bury it with him and we interpreted the report by it as recommended, or as being if it fell out after the dismemberment of the limbs and we did not say that it is obligatory to bury the limbs.

" المعاني والخصال " - عن علي بن أحمد بن موسى، عن محمد الأسدي، عن صالح بن أبي حماد، عن إسماعيل بن مهران، عن أبيه، عن آبائه، عن علي (ع) قال قال رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله:
الغنم إذا أدبرت أدبرت، والإبل أعنان الشياطين إذا أقبلت أدبرت وإذا أدبرت أدبرت، ولا يجئ خيرها إلا من الجانب الأشأم، قيل: يا رسول الله فمن يتخذها بعد ذا؟ - قال: فأين الأشقياء الفجرة...!
قال صالح: وأنشد إسماعيل بن مهران (شعر):
" هي المال لولا قلة الخفض حولها * فمن شاء داراها ومن شاء باعها " المعاني - عن محمد بن هارون الزنجاني، عن علي بن عبد العزيز، عن أبي عبيد أنه قال: قوله: " أعنان الشياطين " أعنان كل شئ نواحيه، وأما الذي يحكيه أبو عمرو فأعنان الشئ نواحيه قالها أبو عمرو وغيره فإن كانت الأعنان محفوظة فأراد أن الإبل من نواحي الشياطين أي انها على أخلاقها وطبايعها، وقوله: " لا تقبل إلا مولية ولا تدبر إلا مولية " فهذا عندي كالمثل الذي يقال فيها: إنها إذا أقبلت أدبرت وإذا أدبرت أدبرت، وذلك لكثرة آفاتها أو سرعة فنائها، وقوله " لا يأتي خيرها إلا من جانبها الأشأم " يعنى الشمال يقال لليد الشمال الشومى، ومنه قول الله عز وجل " وأصحاب المشئمة " يريد أصحاب الشمال ومنه قوله: " لا يأتي خيرها إلا من هناك " يعنى أنها لا تحلب ولا تركب إلا من شمالها وهو الجانب الذي يقال له الوحشي في قول الأصمعي لأنه الشمال قال: والأيمن هو الأيسر وقال بعضهم: لا ولكن الأيسر يأتيه الناس في الاحتلاب و الركوب، والوحشي هو الأيمن لأن الدابة لا تؤتى من جانبها الأيمن إنما تؤتى من الأيسر قاله أبو عبيد: فهذا هو القول عندي وإنما الجانب الوحشي هو الأيمن لأن الخائف إنما يفر من موضع المخافة إلى موضع الامن توضيح - قال الزمخشري في الفائق، سئل عن الإبل فقال: أعنان

Then, or on the tooth of someone pure who is not required to be buried (until he said:) In all cases, it indicates that the prohibition of praying with parts of animals whose meat is not eaten is specific to non-humans, but it is one of the clearest texts. Al-'Allama said in Al-Tadhkira: "If his bone is mended with a bone that is pure in substance, it is permissible because death does not make his bone or hair impure. And if he mends it with a human bone, then there is ambiguity arising from the obligation to bury it and its purity, and the narration of Zurara from al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) about a man whose tooth falls out and he takes a dead man's tooth in its place, he said: There is nothing wrong with it." And he said in al-Dhikra: "He is not allowed to put an impure tooth in place of his tooth, and the pure one is permissible, even if it is a human tooth, or mended with a human bone, it is possible to be permissible because of its purity, and the permission of al-Sadiq (peace be upon him) to take the tooth of the dead for one whose tooth has fallen out, and returning his fallen tooth is more worthy of permissibility because of its purity according to us. It is possible to prohibit the bone due to the obligation of burying it, and if we obligate the burial of the tooth, then the prohibition is also directed." And al-Fayrouzabadi said: "Fasmuhu yafsumuhu = he broke it, so it broke and shattered."
Another explanation related to the forty-second hadith after the one hundredth from the hadiths of the Book of Companions (see p. 638, lines 1-4). Al-'Allama al-Majlisi (may God have mercy on him) said in al-Bihar (vol. 14, chapter on the conditions of livestock, their benefits, harms, and acquisition, pp. 684-685) the following:
"Al-Ma'ani wal-Khisal" - from Ali bin Ahmad bin Musa, from Muhammad al-Asadi, from Salih bin Abi Hammad, from Ismail bin Mehran, from his father, from his forefathers, from Ali (peace be upon him) who said: The Messenger of God (peace and blessings of God be upon him) said:
Sheep, when they turn away, they turn away, and camels are the reins of devils; when they come, they turn away, and when they turn away, they turn away, and no good comes from them except from the ominous side. It was said: O Messenger of God, who will take them after that? - He said: Where are the wretched evildoers...?
Salih said: And Ismail bin Mehran recited (poetry):
"It is wealth, were it not for the scarcity of humility around it * So whoever wants to cherish it, and whoever wants to sell it." Al-Ma'ani - from Muhammad bin Harun al-Zanjani, from Ali bin Abd al-Aziz, from Abu Ubaid, who said: His saying: "Reins of devils" - the reins of everything are its sides. As for what Abu Amr narrates, the reins of something are its sides, Abu Amr and others said. If the reins are preserved, then he meant that camels are from the sides of devils, that is, they are of their morals and natures. And his saying: "It does not accept except turning away, and it does not turn away except turning away" - this to me is like the proverb that is said about them: that when they come, they turn away, and when they turn away, they turn away, and that is due to the abundance of their misfortunes or the speed of their demise. And his saying: "No good comes from them except from their ominous side" - meaning the north. The left hand is called al-shumi, and from it is the saying of God Almighty "And the companions of the left," meaning the companions of the north, and from it is his saying: "No good comes from them except from there" - meaning that they are not milked or ridden except from their left side, which is the side that is called the wild side in the saying of al-Asma'i because it is the north. He said: And the right is the easier. And some of them said: No, but the left is where people come to milk and ride, and the wild side is the right because the animal is not approached from its right side, but is approached from its left, said Abu Ubaid: This is what I say, and the wild side is the right because the fearful only flees from the place of fear to the place of safety. Clarification - Al-Zamakhshari said in al-Faiq, he was asked about camels and said: Reins

الشياطين لا تقبل إلا مولية ولا تدبر إلا مولية ولا يأتي نفعها إلا من جانبها الأشأم، الأعنان = النواحي جمع عنن وعن، يقال: أخذنا كل عن وسن وفن، أخذ من عن كما أخذ العرض من عرض، وفى الحديث: انهم كرهوا الصلاة في أعطان الإبل لأنها خلقت من أعنان الشياطين، قال الجاحظ: يزعم بعض الناس أن الإبل لكثرة آفاتها أن من شأنها إذا أقبلت أن يتعقب إقبالها الادبار وإذا أدبرت أن يكون إدبارها ذهابا وفناء ومستأصلا، و " لا يأتي نفعها " يعنى منفعة الركوب والحلب إلا من جانبها الذي ديدن العرب أن يتشاءموا به، وهو جانب الشمال ومن ثم سموا الشمال شومى قال: فانحى على شومى يديه " فدارها " فإذا هي للفتنة مظنة وللشياطين مجال متسع حيث تسببت أولا إلا إغراء المالكين على إخلالهم بشكر النعمة العظيمة فيها، فلما زواها عنهم لكفرانهم أغرتهم أيضا على إغفال ما لزمهم من حق جميل الصبر على المرزئة بها وسولت لهم في الجانب الذي يستملون منه الركوب والحلب انه الجانب الأشأم وهو في الحقيقة الأيمن والابرك، وقال أيضا: قيل أي لرسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله: أي أموالنا أفضل؟ - قال: الحرث، وقيل:
يا رسول الله صلى الله عليه وآله فالإبل؟ - قال: تلك عناجيج الشياطين، العنجوج يعطف عنقه لطولها في كل جهة ويلويها ليا وراكبه يعنجها إليه بالعنان والزمام يريد أنها مطايا الشياطين ومنه قوله إن على ذروة كل بعير شيطانا، وقال في النهاية: " ولا يأتي خيرها إلا من جانبها الأشأم " يعنى الشمال ومنه قولهم لليد الشمال الشومى تأنيث الأشأم يريد بخيرها لبنها لأنها إنما تحلب وتركب من جانبها الأيسر (انتهى) وقال الجوهري:
" الوحشي الجانب الأيمن من كل شئ هذا قول أبى زيد وأبى عمرو، قال عنترة:
" وكأنما تنأى بجانب دفها - * - الوحشي من هزج العشى مأوم " وإنما تنادى بالجانب الوحشي لأن سوط الراكب بيده اليمنى، وقال الراعي:
" فمالت على شق وحشيها * وقد ريع جانبها الأيسر " ويقال: ليس من شئ يفزع إلا مال على جانبه الأيمن لأن الدابة لا تؤتى من جانبها الأيمن وإنما تؤتى في الاحتلاب والركوب من جانبها الأيسر فإنما خوفه منه والخائف إنما يفر من موضع المخافة إلى موضع الامن وكان الأصمعي يقول: الوحشي الجانب الأيسر من كل شئ، وفى المصباح المنير: الوحشي من كل دابة الجانب الأيمن قال الأزهري: قال أئمة العربية: الوحشي من جميع الحيوان غير الانسان الجانب الأيمن وهو الذي يركب منه الراكب ولا يحلب منه الحالب والانسى الجانب الآخر وهو الأيسر وروى أبو عبيد عن الأصمعي أن الوحشي هو الذي يأتي منه الراكب ولا يحلب منه الحالب لأن الدابة تستوحش عنده فتفر منه إلى الجانب الأيمن، قال الأزهري: وهو غير صحيح عندي، قال ابن الأنباري: ويقال: ما من شئ يفزع إلا مال إلى جانبه الأيمن لأن الدابة إنما تؤتى للحلب والركوب من الجانب الأيسر فتخاف منه فتفر من موضع المخافة وهو الجانب الأيسر إلى موضع الامن وهو الجانب الأيمن فلهذا قيل:
الوحشي الجانب الأيمن (انتهى)

Devils only accept what is given entirely to them, and they only manage what is entirely theirs. Their benefit only comes from their sinister side. Al-A'nan = Al-Nawahi (sides, directions), plural of 'Anan and 'Ann. It is said: "We took every 'Ann, Sinn, and Finn," meaning we took from one side as we took the عرض from عرض. And in the Hadith: "They disliked praying in the resting places of camels because they were created from the 'Anan of the devils." Al-Jahiz said: "Some people claim that due to the many afflictions of camels, it is their nature that their coming is followed by retreat, and their retreat is going away, annihilation, and extirpation. "And their benefit does not come" meaning the benefit of riding and milking, except from the side that the Arabs are accustomed to be superstitious about, which is the north side, and hence they called the north "Shoumy." He said: "So he leaned on the Shoumy side of his hands." "So he managed it." It is a place prone to temptation and a vast field for devils, as it first caused the owners to neglect gratitude for the great blessing in it. When He removed it from them due to their ingratitude, He also incited them to neglect the beautiful right of patience upon the affliction with it, and it enticed them on the side from which they draw riding and milking that it is the sinister side, which is in reality the right and blessed side. He also said: It was said to the Messenger of God, peace and blessings of God be upon him: "Which of our wealth is best?" - He said: "Agriculture." And it was said: O Messenger of God, peace and blessings of God be upon him, then the camels? - He said: "Those are the 'Anajij of the devils." The 'Anjuj bends its neck due to its length in every direction and twists it, and its rider draws it to him with the rein and leash, meaning that they are the mounts of the devils, and from it is his saying: "Indeed, on the summit of every camel is a devil." And he said in al-Nihayah: "And no good comes from it except from its sinister side," meaning the north, and from it is their saying for the left hand "al-Shoumy," the feminine of al-Ash'am, meaning by its goodness, its milk, because it is only milked and ridden from its left side (End). Al-Jawhari said:
"Al-Wahshi is the right side of everything. This is the saying of Abu Zayd and Abu Amr." Antarah said:
"And as if it turns away with the side of its chest - * - the Wahshi, from the hum of the evening, defeated." And it is called al-Wahshi side because the rider's whip is in his right hand. And al-Ra'i said:
"So it leaned on a Wahshi side of it * And its left side was frightened." It is said: Nothing is frightened except that it leans on its right side because the animal is not approached from its right side, but is only approached in milking and riding from its left side, so it is afraid of it, and the one who is afraid only flees from the place of fear to the place of safety. Al-Asma'i used to say: Al-Wahshi is the left side of everything. And in Al-Misbah Al-Munir: Al-Wahshi of every animal is the right side. Al-Azhari said: The Imams of Arabic said: Al-Wahshi of all animals other than humans is the right side, which is the side from which the rider rides and the milker does not milk. And the Insi is the other side, which is the left. And Abu Ubaid narrated from Al-Asma'i that Al-Wahshi is the side from which the rider comes and the milker does not milk, because the animal becomes frightened by it and flees from it to the right side. Al-Azhari said: This is not correct in my opinion. Ibn al-Anbari said: It is said: Nothing is frightened except that it leans to its right side because the animal is only approached for milking and riding from the left side, so it fears it and flees from the place of fear, which is the left side, to the place of safety, which is the right side. Therefore, it was said: Al-Wahshi is the right side (End).
